According to a <a href=\"https://www.globalwebindex.com/hubfs/Downloads/Social-H2-2018-report.pdf\">2018 GlobalWebIndex Study</a>, 40% of digital consumers use social media as a tool when researching products. With the right person at the helm of your company's social media accounts, your posts could catch the eye of these users.</p> \n<h3>8. Project Manager and Campaign Coordinator</h3> \n<p>Many people across a company may want certain things posted, responded to, favorited or \"liked.\" It's up to the social media manager to decide which requests to honor and when to honor them. This means they need to be highly organized and able to manage multiple requests.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/project%20manager.jpg?width=598&amp;name=project%20manager.jpg\" alt=\"A project manager meets with colleagues to plan social projects or campaigns.\" width=\"598\" style=\"width: 598px; display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\">They need to be able to quickly assess whether a request would resonate with the company's followers, or whether it's too niche or too narrow. For example, a location-specific post might be too narrow to send to a company's entire Twitter following.</p> \n<p>Social media community managers also need to effectively coordinate with different departments to organize campaign launches, while still pushing launches and growth initiatives of their own.</p> \n<h4>Skills Necessary</h4> \n<ul> \n <li>Strong Organization</li> \n <li>Strong Communication</li> \n <li>Ability to Negotiate</li> \n <li>Data-Based Decision-Making</li> \n</ul> \n<h4>How This Drives Results</h4> \n<p>Social media plays a big role in promoting initiatives from different departments and teams across a company. When a social media community manager effectively balances these promotions <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/visual-content-variety-social-media?_ga=2.241207621.658418733.1558660591-995061728.1558660591\">with other engaging and relevant content</a>, they'll be able to win the hearts and minds of their followers <em>and</em> internal stakeholders.</p> \n<h3>How to Think About Social Media Management</h3> \n<p>With this diverse and highly visible role, it's hard to believe that the social media community manager position is often still considered entry-level.</p> \n<p>These eight jobs should be in the back of any hiring manager's mind as they interview potential social media managers. If we can change the perception of the role, we'll have a good chance of mastering the ability to measure and value social media's ROI.</p> \n<p><em>Editor's note: This post was originally published in May 2019 and has been updated for comprehensiveness.</em></p> \n<p><em></em></p> \n<p><em></em></p>  \n<img src=\"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&amp;k=14&amp;r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fbest-social-media-manager-job-description&amp;bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&amp;bvt=rss\" alt=\"\" width=\"1\" height=\"1\" style=\"min-height:1px!important;width:1px!important;border-width:0!important;margin-top:0!important;margin-bottom:0!important;margin-right:0!important;margin-left:0!important;padding-top:0!important;padding-bottom:0!important;padding-right:0!important;padding-left:0!important; \">","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Mon, 19 Oct 2020 11:00:00 +0000","feedId":54,"bgimg":"","linkMd5":"6b555410bc1403ca9abf48174935acaf","bgimgJsdelivr":"","metaImg":"","author":"lkolowich@hubspot.com (Lindsay Kolowich Cox)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/content%20creator%20small.jpg?width=598&name=content%20creator%20small.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn45@2020_1/2020/10/27/16-54-07-100_b9ddac9fc081d698.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/analyst.jpg?width=598&name=analyst.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn43@2020_3/2020/10/27/16-54-08-332_33b78f5374d5b753.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/news%20small.jpeg?width=603&name=news%20small.jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn9@2020_1/2020/10/27/16-53-55-616_668f271206f52509.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/small%20customer%20service.jpeg?width=598&name=small%20customer%20service.jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn17@2020_6/2020/10/27/16-53-59-405_ebb6f67299860066.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/small%20community.jpg?width=598&name=small%20community.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn31@2020_3/2020/10/27/16-54-10-048_a24501e57d80725f.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/funnel-3.jpg?width=598&name=funnel-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn1@2020_5/2020/10/27/16-54-06-532_5689819b82b08f00.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/project%20manager.jpg?width=598&name=project%20manager.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn50@2020_1/2020/10/27/16-54-11-299_93f9e6c278cc7253.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fbest-social-media-manager-job-description&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn57@2020_2/2020/10/27/16-54-05-702_49c4f3eb542abd42.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1603817624926},{"createdTime":"2020-10-28 00:53:44","updatedTime":"2020-10-28 00:53:44","title":"YouTube Ads for Beginners: How to Launch & Optimize a YouTube Video Advertising Campaign","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/youtube-video-advertising-guide","description":"<p>You've spent months perfecting the script, storyboarding, finding the right talent, shooting, and editing. The end result? A blockbuster brand or product video.</p>  \n<p>With all that time invested, you can't stop at just embedding the video on a homepage or sharing it on social media and hoping someone watches.</p> \n<p>While great content is bound to be found, it's also important to be proactive about gaining the attention of and educating prospects and those unfamiliar with your brand. Running a series of YouTube ads is one way to make sure more of your target audience finds the video content you've produced.</p> \n<p>And with new formats and tracking capabilities, you can also use this information to report on its ROI.</p> \n<p></p> \n<p>The thing is, advertising on YouTube is very different from running a PPC or paid social campaign. There are specific creative constraints and a ton of options for this platform, and you need a base knowledge before you even scope out your next video project to make the most of the paid possibilities.</p> \n<div> \n <p class=\"p1\"></p> \n</div> \n<h2>What’s New With YouTube Advertising</h2> \n<p>In January 2017, <a href=\"https://adwords.googleblog.com/2017/01/making-youtube-better-in-mobile-cross.html\">Google announced</a>&nbsp;it would make&nbsp;<a href=\"http://adage.com/article/digital/advertisers-target-youtube-ads-based-search-histories/307614/\">changes to AdWords</a> to allow advertisers to reach more viewers on YouTube -- especially across mobile devices, where 50% of YouTube views take place. Among the changes it&nbsp;rolled out, possibly the biggest announcement was that advertisers will soon be able to target viewers based on their Google search history, in addition to their viewing behaviors YouTube was already targeting.</p> \n<p>Marketers can now target ads at people who recently searched for a certain product or service to target the video ads they’ll be served on the platform. If the content of a video ad is closely related to a search the viewer has been researching, they might be more likely to watch the entire ad or click through the ad to the website.</p> \n<p>Keywords are relatively less expensive to target on YouTube than in traditional Google Search: Views cost an average of <a href=\"https://blog.kissmetrics.com/google-adwords-video-ads/\">$0.06 per click</a> on YouTube, compared to the average Google Search cost per click, which is <a href=\"http://www.wordstream.com/blog/ws/2015/05/21/how-much-does-adwords-cost\">estimated</a> to be between $1-2. When YouTube targeting includes search history, it may be a more cost-effective way to target your audience with a more engaging form of content -- video.</p> \n<h2>The 3 Types of YouTube Video Ads</h2> \n<p>There are three key types of video ads in which you can invest on YouTube: TrueView, Preroll, and Bumpers.</p> \n<h3>1. TrueView Ads</h3> \n<p>TrueView ads are the standard video ad type on YouTube.&nbsp;Advertisers only pay for <a href=\"https://support.google.com/adwords/answer/2375464?hl=en\">TrueView ads</a> when viewers watch or interact with their ad (for example, by clicking on a call-to-action), and videos can be easily customized&nbsp;to share a variety of content.</p> \n<p>Advertisers only pay when a user watches the ad for at least 30 seconds or until the end of the video or if the viewer takes an action, such as clicking on a call-to-action.&nbsp;<a href=\"https://support.google.com/displayspecs/answer/6244563\">YouTube requires</a> that skippable TrueView ads&nbsp;be between 12 seconds and 6 minutes in length, and that non-skippable TrueView ads be 15-20 seconds in length.</p> \n<p>There are two types of TrueView ads with which you can optimize your YouTube channel:</p> \n<h4>Video Discovery Ads (Previously Named In-Display Ads)</h4> \n<p><a href=\"https://support.google.com/displayspecs/answer/6227733?hl=en&amp;ref_topic=4588474&amp;vid=1-635792359058243079-3239843357\">Video discovery YouTube ads</a> show up on the YouTube homepage, search results pages, and as related videos on YouTube video watch pages.</p> \n<p>These ads appeared after performing a YouTube search:</p> \n<p><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/youtube_search_results.png?width=669&amp;name=youtube_search_results.png\" alt=\"Two TrueView Video Discovery Ads in a YouTube search result\" width=\"669\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; width: 669px;\" title=\"youtube_search_results.png\"></p> \n<p>This <a href=\"https://support.google.com/youtube/answer/2467968?hl=en\">display ad</a>&nbsp;appears as a related video on the right-hand video sidebar:</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/in-display-ad.png?width=900&amp;name=in-display-ad.png\" width=\"900\" style=\"width: 900px;\" alt=\"YouTube display ad -- or Video Discovery Ad -- on righthand video sidebar\"></p> \n<p>Once a user clicks on the ad, the destination video page features a spot on the right-hand column where a companion banner <a href=\"https://support.google.com/youtube/answer/2467968?hl=en\">display ad</a>&nbsp;will appear.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/video-ad-companion-banner.png?width=900&amp;name=video-ad-companion-banner.png\" alt=\"YouTube video ad companion banner\" width=\"900\" style=\"width: 900px;\"></p> \n<h4>In-Stream Ads</h4> \n<p><a href=\"https://support.google.com/displayspecs/answer/6055025?hl=en&amp;ref_topic=4588474&amp;vid=1-635792359058243079-3239843357\">TrueView in-stream ads</a> play before someone watches the video they’ve selected on YouTube. Viewers sometimes have the option to skip the ad after watching it for five seconds. You can also make them play anywhere in the Google Display Network (GDN) -- or sites that purchased&nbsp;Google video ad space.</p> \n<p>In-stream ads let marketers customize video ads with different CTAs and overlay text, as highlighted in the <a href=\"https://support.google.com/youtube/answer/2467968?hl=en\">skippable in-stream ad</a> example below from Grammarly.</p> \n<p><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/youtube_in_stream_ad_example.png?width=669&amp;name=youtube_in_stream_ad_example.png\" alt=\"TrueView In-Stream video ad by Grammarly\" width=\"669\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; width: 669px;\" title=\"youtube_in_stream_ad_example.png\"></p> \n<p>Here’s what another <a href=\"https://support.google.com/youtube/answer/2467968?hl=en\">skippable</a>&nbsp;in-stream ad from Wix looks like. In this example, there’s another CTA from Wix on top of the right-hand video menu display:</p> \n<p><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/in-stream%20ad%20youtube.png?width=669&amp;name=in-stream%20ad%20youtube.png\" alt=\"in-stream ad youtube.png\" width=\"669\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; width: 669px;\" title=\"in-stream ad youtube.png\"></p> \n<h4>What TrueView Videos Can Include</h4> \n<p>TrueView video campaigns can include people, dialogue, and music that was retrieved with permission -- or is considered royalty-free. However, it's best not to run a standard promotional commercial. Because these videos can be skipped, you need to give your audience a reason to keep watching, and product plugs historically don't get the views you might expect.</p> \n<p>Instead, tell a story with the time you have in this video. People love seeing case studies of those who faced a struggle that they can empathize with. It's a source of entertainment that makes your brand memorable and less tempting to skip.</p> \n<p>With TrueView ads, advertisers can gain a ton of information about the performance of their ads for optimization and testing purposes.</p> \n<p>Using AdWords, YouTube account managers can collect data on an ad's completed views, partial views, if the video drives channel subscriptions, clickthrough rates on CTAs, views sourced from a user sharing the content, and views on the brand's other content that can be attributed to a person initially viewing a video ad.</p> \n<p>These actions help advertisers better understand the full value of their video ad spend and where to allocate budget to increase results.</p> \n<h3>2. Preroll Ads</h3> \n<p>Some in-stream ads are <a href=\"https://support.google.com/youtube/answer/2467968?hl=en\">non-skippable</a> and can play before, <a href=\"https://support.google.com/youtube/answer/6175006?hl=en\">mid-roll</a>, or after the main video. These are called Preroll ads, and they can be 15 to 20 seconds in duration.</p> \n<p>Here's an example of a non-skippable video ad before the main content on YouTube:</p> \n<p><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/videoad_nonskippable.png?width=669&amp;name=videoad_nonskippable.png\" alt=\"Preroll ad on YouTube with &quot;non-skippable&quot; features highlighted in the video\" width=\"669\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; width: 669px;\" title=\"videoad_nonskippable.png\"></p> \n<p>There are also&nbsp;<a href=\"https://support.google.com/youtube/answer/2467968?hl=en\">non-skippable</a>, mid-roll video ads, which appear midway through a YouTube video that's <a href=\"https://support.google.com/youtube/answer/6175006?hl=en\">10 minutes or longer</a> in length.</p> \n<p><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Midroll%20Ad%20YouTube.png?width=644&amp;height=344&amp;name=Midroll%20Ad%20YouTube.png\" alt=\"Midroll preroll ad on YouTube\" width=\"644\" height=\"344\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\"></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><span style=\"font-size: 12px;\"><em>Source:&nbsp;<a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NPe1-ZZerH8\">PC Daily Tips</a></em></span></p> \n<h4>What Preroll Videos Can Include</h4> \n<p>Preroll ads give you just as much freedom as TrueView ads in their allotted content. You can include people, dialogue, audio, and more elements that you find best represent your brand in 15 to 20 seconds.</p> \n<p>Because preroll ads can't be skipped, these videos are best created with a call-to-action (CTA) so you can optimize the attention you do have from the viewer. In other words, encourage viewers to click on your ad and receive something in return. Perhaps you've released a new product or promoting a major event this season and are looking for signups -- use this preroll ad to get those clicks.&nbsp;</p> \n<p>Keep in mind YouTube sells Preroll video space on a pay-per-click (PPC) basis. Make the click worth it.</p> \n<h3>3. Bumpers</h3> \n<p>Bumpers are the third and shortest type of YouTube video ad available to you. At just six seconds per bumper, these ad spots play before a viewer's chosen video.&nbsp;</p> \n<p>Bumper video ads obviously can't tell a good-enough story in just six seconds, but they make terrific complements to larger video campaigns on a new product launch or event. Just be sure to use this six seconds wisely, and include only the components of your brand you want your audience to remember.</p> \n<h2>How to Set Up &amp; Launch a YouTube Video Advertising Campaign</h2> \n<p>Once you’ve created a marketing video you want to advertise on YouTube, it’s time to <a href=\"https://support.google.com/adwords/answer/2375497?hl=en\">create your video ad campaign</a>. (If you haven’t made a video yet, here’s how to get started with <a href=\"https://animoto.com/blog/guides/getting-started-animoto/\">Animoto</a> or <a href=\"https://wistia.com/blog/your-first-video\">Wistia</a>, along with a few <a href=\"https://www.vidyard.com/blog/examples-of-b2b-video-marketing/\">great examples</a>.) Then, upload your video to YouTube.</p> \n<p><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/select_video_to_upload.png?width=669&amp;name=select_video_to_upload.png\" alt=\"YouTube creator's page prompt to select files to upload\" width=\"669\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; width: 669px;\" title=\"select_video_to_upload.png\"></p> \n<p>Now, you're ready to set up your advertising campaign. First, go to your <a href=\"https://adwords.google.com/\">Google AdWords</a> account to set up your campaign.</p> \n<h3>Campaign Type</h3> \n<p>Tap the drop-down menu on the right-hand side of the red \"+ Campaign\" button on your Google AdWords homepage and select \"video.\"</p> \n<p><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/launch_new_video_ad.png?width=329&amp;height=322&amp;name=launch_new_video_ad.png\" alt=\"launch_new_video_ad.png\" width=\"329\" height=\"322\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\"></p> \n<h3>Campaign Name</h3> \n<p>Enter a name for your campaign, and make sure Video has been chosen from the Type drop-down menu.</p> \n<p><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/YouTube_AdWords_Step1.png?width=669&amp;name=YouTube_AdWords_Step1.png\" alt=\"YouTube_AdWords_Step1.png\" title=\"YouTube_AdWords_Step1.png\" style=\"width: 669px; display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\" width=\"669\"></p> \n<h3>Video Ad Format</h3> \n<p>Select \"In-stream or video discovery ads\" to ensure your video ad will be in TrueView format (in the style of the examples outlined above).</p> \n<p><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/video_ad_formats_adwords.png?width=462&amp;height=83&amp;name=video_ad_formats_adwords.png\" alt=\"video_ad_formats_adwords.png\" width=\"462\" height=\"83\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\"></p> \n<h3>Budget</h3> \n<p>Set your budget per day. You can also select a delivery method -- either the standard delivery, which shows ads evenly during the day, or accelerated delivery, which drives&nbsp;views as quickly as possible. The latter would be useful if you want&nbsp;to capitalize on a trend or news item relevant to your brand's video.</p> \n<p><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Agency_Post/Blog_Images/video-ad-budget-delivery.png?width=672&amp;height=194&amp;name=video-ad-budget-delivery.png\" alt=\"video-ad-budget-delivery.png\" title=\"video-ad-budget-delivery.png\" width=\"672\" height=\"194\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\"></p> \n<h3>Networks</h3> \n<p>Decide where you want your ad to appear.</p> \n<ul> \n <li>YouTube Search: Your video ad will appear in results for searches and will appear on the YouTube home page, channel pages, and video pages.</li> \n <li>YouTube Videos: This runs TrueView ads that can appear in-display ads or in-stream ads. With this option, you can choose for your video ad to appear before or around videos shown across the Google Display Network.</li> \n</ul> \n<p>You should create separate campaigns for YouTube Search and YouTube Video as this will help you to better track performance metrics. These ads are served to people performing very different activities and require a different amount of commitment from the viewer, so it's best to monitor performance separately.</p> \n<p><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Agency_Post/Blog_Images/youtube-networks.png?width=526&amp;height=103&amp;name=youtube-networks.png\" alt=\"youtube-networks.png\" title=\"youtube-networks.png\" width=\"526\" height=\"103\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\"></p> \n<h3>Locations</h3> \n<p>Define the location of users whom you want the ad to be shown to. You can also exclude certain locations.</p> \n<p><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Agency_Post/Blog_Images/video-location.png?width=636&amp;height=311&amp;name=video-location.png\" alt=\"video-location.png\" title=\"video-location.png\" width=\"636\" height=\"311\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\"></p> \n<h3>Language, Device &amp; Mobile Bidding</h3> \n<p>AdWords will let you specify the operating system, device, and carrier for more advanced targeting. This is especially useful for mobile app ads, and there's an option to increase or decrease your bid based on if the video ad is shown to someone on a mobile device.</p> \n<p><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/youtube_language_ad_adjustment.png?width=703&amp;name=youtube_language_ad_adjustment.png\" alt=\"youtube_language_ad_adjustment.png\" title=\"youtube_language_ad_adjustment.png\" style=\"width: 703px; display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\" width=\"703\"></p> \n<h3>Advanced Settings</h3> \n<p>With the advanced settings section, you can set begin and end dates for your campaign, create a custom schedule for when your video ad should be shown, and limit the daily impressions and views for users. This all helps you to get the most return for your ad spend.</p> \n<p><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/advanced%20settings%20youtube%20ads.png?width=546&amp;name=advanced%20settings%20youtube%20ads.png\" alt=\"Advanced settings on YouTube ads.png\" title=\"advanced settings youtube ads.png\" style=\"width: 546px; display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\" width=\"546\"></p> \n<h3>Creating the Video Ad Creative</h3> \n<p>Name your ad group, and then insert the YouTube link for the video you would like to run the ad for. You will then choose whether you want this to run as an in-stream ad or an in-display ad.</p> \n<p><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/video_ad_creative_youtube.png?width=772&amp;name=video_ad_creative_youtube.png\" alt=\"video_ad_creative_youtube.png\" title=\"video_ad_creative_youtube.png\" width=\"772\" style=\"width: 772px; display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\"></p> \n<p>For in-display, you'll need to include a title and short description, which is entered on two separate lines. Note: Titles are limited to 25 characters, and the description lines are limited to 35 characters each.</p> \n<p><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Agency_Post/Blog_Images/youtube-in-display.png?width=669&amp;height=302&amp;name=youtube-in-display.png\" alt=\"youtube-in-display.png\" title=\"youtube-in-display.png\" style=\"width: 669px; display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\" width=\"669\" height=\"302\"></p> \n<p>In-stream ads provide you with the option to overlap a display URL on top of the video. You should use a vanity URL that directs to another final URL to make it more memorable. You can include advanced URL tracking options. In addition, a companion banner made from images from your video will appear on the right side of the video ad.</p> \n<p><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/%5BAgency_Post%5D/Blog_Images/youtube-instream.png?width=669&amp;height=394&amp;name=youtube-instream.png\" alt=\"youtube-in-stream.png\" title=\"youtube-instream.png\" width=\"669\" height=\"394\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\"></p> \n<h3>Bidding</h3> \n<p>You'll then determine the max price you will pay for each view, which you can adjust to increase the number of projected views your video may receive.</p> \n<p><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/bidding_video_ad_adwords.png?width=669&amp;name=bidding_video_ad_adwords.png\" alt=\"bidding_video_ad_adwords.png\" title=\"bidding_video_ad_adwords.png\" style=\"width: 669px; display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\" width=\"669\"></p> \n<h3>Targeting</h3> \n<p>Finally, you can further define the audience you would like the video to be shown -- options include gender, age, and parental status. You can also target individuals by their interests, such as beauty mavens, cooking enthusiasts, horror movie fans, etc. Try running multiple campaigns to target different groups of users to discover who is most engaged, rather than including everyone you want to target in one campaign.</p> \n<p><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/%5BAgency_Post%5D/Blog_Images/video-adwords-interests.png?width=669&amp;height=449&amp;name=video-adwords-interests.png\" alt=\"video-adwords-interests.png\" title=\"video-adwords-interests.png\" style=\"width: 669px; display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\" width=\"669\" height=\"449\"></p> \n<h3>Advanced Targeting</h3> \n<p>You can also target individuals by keywords, topics, or websites where you would like your video ad to appear. Keyword targeting with in-display ads can be a powerful tool for finding individuals who are looking for a visual answer to a question. Be sure to do your research, and try testing out different groups of keywords to see which leads to more views, clicks, or conversions.</p> \n<p>Additionally, you can use AdWords video ads to remarket to people who have been in contact with your brand already. This can help you to re-engage those who are already familiar with your brand.</p> \n<p><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/%5BAgency_Post%5D/Blog_Images/narrow-targeting.png?width=292&amp;height=201&amp;name=narrow-targeting.png\" alt=\"narrow-targeting.png\" title=\"narrow-targeting.png\" width=\"292\" height=\"201\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\"></p> \n<h3>Linking Your Account</h3> \n<p>You should link your AdWords account to the YouTube channel where the video is hosted if you haven't already. You can also click \"finish\" to begin running your video ad campaign.</p> \n<p><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/%5BAgency_Post%5D/Blog_Images/adwords-linking-account.png?width=669&amp;height=416&amp;name=adwords-linking-account.png\" alt=\"adwords-linking-account.png\" title=\"adwords-linking-account.png\" style=\"width: 669px; display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\" width=\"669\" height=\"416\"></p> \n<h2>10 Tips for Optimizing Your AdWords for Video Ads</h2> \n<p>Launching a video ad campaign is a great step, but there are some things you should set up prior to starting to pay for views to make the most of your budget and to see the highest return for your client.</p> \n<h3>1. Define your metrics and goals.</h3> \n<p>When analyzing the results, there are four main categories of metrics you can track for each video. These are located under the \"column\" drop-down in your campaigns interface.</p> \n<h4>Views</h4> \n<p>Under the \"views\" category, you can better understand what percentage of the ad people viewed and understand how the ad drove earned views or views on your brand's other videos.</p> \n<p><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/%5BAgency_Post%5D/Blog_Images/views-metrics.png?width=669&amp;height=133&amp;name=views-metrics.png\" alt=\"views-metrics.png\" title=\"views-metrics.png\" style=\"width: 669px; display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\" width=\"669\" height=\"133\"></p> \n<h4>Audience</h4> \n<p>This category can be used to track likes and shares for each video ad.</p> \n<p><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/%5BAgency_Post%5D/Blog_Images/audience-metrics.png?width=669&amp;height=115&amp;name=audience-metrics.png\" alt=\"audience-metrics.png\" title=\"audience-metrics.png\" style=\"width: 669px; display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\" width=\"669\" height=\"115\"></p> \n<h4>Branding</h4> \n<p>The view rate should signal if the creative and message are&nbsp;interesting or entertaining enough for people to watch the ad. By increasing your view-through rate (VTR), you will lower your cost per view.</p> \n<p><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/%5BAgency_Post%5D/Blog_Images/video-branding-metrics.png?width=669&amp;height=115&amp;name=video-branding-metrics.png\" alt=\"video-branding-metrics.png\" title=\"video-branding-metrics.png\" style=\"width: 669px; display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\" width=\"669\" height=\"115\"></p> \n<h4>Conversions</h4> \n<p>Conversions will help you better understand if your ad is driving leads and returning a high ROI for your brand.</p> \n<p><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/%5BAgency_Post%5D/Blog_Images/conversions-metrics.png?width=669&amp;height=128&amp;name=conversions-metrics.png\" alt=\"conversions-metrics.png\" title=\"conversions-metrics.png\" style=\"width: 669px; display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\" width=\"669\" height=\"128\"></p> \n<p>Depending on the goals for the brand, you should determine a few goals based on these metrics and formalize a plan for optimizing creative and trying different targeting criteria to improve results. Your goals should also determine the type of content you will feature in the ad -- some metrics are better for branding goals and others will drive leads and conversions.</p> \n<h3>2. Track low performing placements.</h3> \n<p>If you're running in-display ads that will appear&nbsp;across the Google Display Network, you can review where the ad has appeared in by navigating to Video Targeting &gt; Placements &gt; Where ads were shown &gt; Display network from your Google AdWords Campaigns dashboard. Review this list to see if any particular sites are contributing to poor performance for your desired metrics. Exclude these sites from your ad campaign moving forward to increase your average CPV.</p> \n<h3>3. Use a custom thumbnail image.</h3> \n<p>Design or use a high-quality still image from the video to entice&nbsp;a viewer to click on your video. Remember, this image needs to be legible by users on different devices, including mobile. If your image contains a person, make sure he or she is looking into the camera. If you are featuring a product, make sure the background isn't distracting.&nbsp;</p> \n<h3>4. Drive people to buy with cards.</h3> \n<p>A <a href=\"https://support.google.com/youtube/answer/6140541?vid=1-635792409460577185-3239843357\">YouTube card</a> is teased with a small \"i\" symbol, which the viewer can click to expand. You can time this appearance so only users engaged with the video and content will see the notification.</p> \n<p>With cards, you can feature a product related to or featured in the video to drive product purchases. You can also use cards to drive fundraising donations, traffic to a URL, or traffic to other videos as shown in the <a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ewU7e11y6y8\">example below from <em>Refinery29</em></a>. Each format will allow you to customize the card with text, images, and other options.</p> \n<p><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/refinery29example.png?width=693&amp;name=refinery29example.png\" alt=\"refinery29example.png\" title=\"refinery29example.png\" width=\"693\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; width: 693px;\"></p> \n<h3>5. Create calls-to-actions.</h3> \n<p>When promoting a video on YouTube, you can include call-to-action overlays that link to a URL. You could link to a landing page, product page, information page, career page ... whatever you'd like. You could also send people to a favorable report or interview featuring the brand.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=HgYhTlNtmLE\">Adobe highlights one of its live&nbsp;videos</a> using a call-to-action overlay:</p> \n<p><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/adobe_youtube_ad_CTA.png?width=695&amp;name=adobe_youtube_ad_CTA.png\" alt=\"adobe_youtube_ad_CTA.png\" title=\"adobe_youtube_ad_CTA.png\" style=\"width: 695px; display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\" width=\"695\"></p> \n<h3>6. Create a YouTube end slate.</h3> \n<p><a href=\"http://www.reelseo.com/outro-end-slate-youtube/\">Create an end screen</a> to drive subscribers to your channel, promote your social networks, or increase interest in your brand. If someone has watched a video until the end, it's a good sign they enjoy your content and might be interested in subscribing to your channel for future updates. <a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=pG5ceUvmqS4\"><em>The Tonight Show Starring Jimmy Fallon</em>'s end slate </a>uses this screen to drive subscribers and social media fans while also highlighting other interesting topics its host has featured. Once you build the image, you will be able to annotate the end screen in YouTube's video editor.</p> \n<p><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/yeahboy_endslate.png?width=689&amp;name=yeahboy_endslate.png\" alt=\"yeahboy_endslate.png\" title=\"yeahboy_endslate.png\" style=\"width: 689px; display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\" width=\"689\"></p> \n<h3>7. Use negative remarketing.</h3> \n<p>If you are running a campaign for a longer period of time and want to only attract new users to a brand, consider creating a list of people who your ad will not be shown to. When viewing your AdWords Campaign screen, select \"Shared library\" on the lower left sidebar. Then select \"Video remarketing\" and \"+ Remarketing List\". You can stretch your campaign budget and target only unique users by selecting to not show your video ad to someone who has previously viewed the specific video, who has visited your YouTube channel, or shared, liked, or commented on any of your videos on your channel.</p> \n<p><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/%5BAgency_Post%5D/Blog_Images/remarketing-adwords.png?width=669&amp;height=230&amp;name=remarketing-adwords.png\" alt=\"remarketing-adwords.png\" title=\"remarketing-adwords.png\" style=\"width: 669px; display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\" width=\"669\" height=\"230\"></p> \n<h3>8. Use close captioning to cater to viewer's needs and wants.</h3> \n<p>This tip applies to all YouTube videos -- but it's a general best practice that's not followed by many brands. Include a quality video transcription you've generated and approved. Only user-uploaded transcriptions are indexed by Google because YouTube's automatic captioning can be <a href=\"http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2010/03/29/funny-youtube-caption-fai_n_516866.html\">less than reliable</a>. Depending on your target audience, you may also want to include transcriptions in various other languages. You can also offer users the option to download or visit a site page with the full transcription in your video description.</p> \n<h3>9. Qualify viewers.</h3> \n<p>Sometimes, your ad will be seen by people who have no interest in your product. Encourage them to skip the ad if the content isn't relevant so you don't have to pay for the view and they don't waste their time watching irrelevant advertising.</p> \n<h3>10. Consider making your ad longer.</h3> \n<p>When it comes to <a href=\"https://support.google.com/adwords/answer/2375464?hl=en\">TrueView ads</a>, if the ad is under 30 seconds, you pay only if a viewer watches until the end. If the ad is longer than 30 seconds, you pay if the viewer watches it for at least 30 seconds. In both cases, you pay if the viewer interacts with your ad before it's over. Consider this when you are coming up with ideas for content for the ad. You may want to put messaging at a certain point so uninterested viewers can skip the ad, or you might provide special offers towards the end of the video.</p> \n<h2>The Future of Video is Bright</h2> \n<p>We’ve told you before: Video content is a must-have part of your content strategy. This is even truer&nbsp;now that YouTube lets marketers target users based on their search histories. YouTube advertising is more targeted than ever, and it’s less competitive real estate than the world of Google Search because video content is newer to the content scene and less popular than blog posts.</p> \n<p>Stay tuned for more from us about how to make great video ads for YouTube and social media, and where we think <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/youtube-marketing\">YouTube marketing</a> is headed next.</p> \n<p></p> \n<p></p>  \n<img hubfs/%5BAgency_Post%5D/Blog_Images/youtube-instream.png?width=669&height=394&name=youtube-instream.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn71@2020_4/2020/10/27/16-53-49-094_821278b6eb3c9dc2.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/bidding_video_ad_adwords.png?width=669&name=bidding_video_ad_adwords.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn17@2020_6/2020/10/27/16-54-06-731_d0c288d86bcc2a83.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/%5BAgency_Post%5D/Blog_Images/video-adwords-interests.png?width=669&height=449&name=video-adwords-interests.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn41@2020_6/2020/10/27/16-53-57-970_a46de685d1ec4747.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/%5BAgency_Post%5D/Blog_Images/narrow-targeting.png?width=292&height=201&name=narrow-targeting.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn28@2020_2/2020/10/27/16-53-48-008_ac9326d18f54c469.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/%5BAgency_Post%5D/Blog_Images/adwords-linking-account.png?width=669&height=416&name=adwords-linking-account.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn79@2020_1/2020/10/27/16-53-51-147_e374371e41cb282e.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/%5BAgency_Post%5D/Blog_Images/views-metrics.png?width=669&height=133&name=views-metrics.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn4@2020_4/2020/10/27/16-53-50-406_8ee7cd2f9f7b5ff2.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/%5BAgency_Post%5D/Blog_Images/audience-metrics.png?width=669&height=115&name=audience-metrics.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn22@2020_1/2020/10/27/16-53-54-559_73e9352fb3c9bd62.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/%5BAgency_Post%5D/Blog_Images/video-branding-metrics.png?width=669&height=115&name=video-branding-metrics.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn58@2020_6/2020/10/27/16-54-12-839_c9f7782b09ee82e4.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/%5BAgency_Post%5D/Blog_Images/conversions-metrics.png?width=669&height=128&name=conversions-metrics.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn10@2020_3/2020/10/27/16-53-52-931_8f893c0c41677d55.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/refinery29example.png?width=693&name=refinery29example.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn15@2020_6/2020/10/27/16-54-10-825_0555a41b4ecb5af3.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/adobe_youtube_ad_CTA.png?width=695&name=adobe_youtube_ad_CTA.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn90@2020_1/2020/10/27/16-53-57-008_9bf6fb5d9c48823e.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/yeahboy_endslate.png?width=689&name=yeahboy_endslate.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn95@2020_4/2020/10/27/16-54-03-091_185d6e1c7691df28.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/%5BAgency_Post%5D/Blog_Images/remarketing-adwords.png?width=669&height=230&name=remarketing-adwords.png":null,"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fyoutube-video-advertising-guide&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn93@2020_3/2020/10/27/16-53-59-123_c4d239e68be84e6e.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1603817624900},{"createdTime":"2020-10-28 00:53:44","updatedTime":"2020-10-28 00:53:44","title":"How to Create a Pivot Table in Excel: A Step-by-Step Tutorial (With Video)","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/how-to-create-pivot-table-tutorial-ht","description":"<p>The pivot table is one of Microsoft Excel's most powerful -- and intimidating -- functions. Powerful because it can help you summarize and make sense of large data sets. Intimidating because you're not exactly an Excel expert, and pivot tables have always had a reputation for being complicated.</p> \n<p>The good news: Learning how to create a pivot table in Excel is much easier than you might've been led to believe.</p> \n<p>But before we walk you through process of creating one, let's take a step back and make sure you understand exactly what a pivot table is, and why you might need to use one.</p> \n<p class=\"p1\"></p> \n<div class=\"hsg-featured-snippet\"> \n <h2>What Is a Pivot Table?</h2> \n <p>A pivot table is a summary of your data, packaged in a chart that lets you report on and explore trends based on your information. Pivot tables are particularly useful if you have long rows or columns that hold values you need to track the sums of and easily compare to one another.</p> \n</div> \n<p>In other words, pivot tables extract meaning from that seemingly endless jumble of numbers on your screen. And more specifically, it lets you group your data together in different ways so you can draw helpful conclusions more easily.</p> \n<p>The \"pivot\" part of a pivot table stems from the fact that you can rotate (or pivot) the data in the table in order to view it from a different perspective. To be clear, you're not adding to, subtracting from, or otherwise changing your data when you make a pivot. Instead, you're simply reorganizing the data so you can reveal useful information from it.</p> \n<p><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/pivot_table-1.gif?width=600&amp;name=pivot_table-1.gif\" title=\"An Excel spreadsheet creating pivot tables in action\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; width: 600px;\" alt=\"An Excel spreadsheet creating pivot tables in action\" width=\"600\"></p> \n<h2>How to Use Pivot Tables</h2> \n<p>If you're still feeling a bit confused about what pivot tables actually do, don't worry. This is one of those technologies that's much easier to understand once you've seen it in action. Here are seven hypothetical scenarios where you'd want to use a pivot table.</p> \n<h3>1. Compare sales totals of different products.</h3> \n<p>Say you have a worksheet that contains monthly sales data for three different products -- product 1, product 2, and product 3 -- and you want to figure out which of the three has been bringing in the most bucks. You could, of course, look through the worksheet and manually add the corresponding sales figure to a running total every time product 1 appears. You could then do the same for product 2, and product 3, until you have totals for all of them. Piece of cake, right?</p> \n<p>Now, imagine that monthly sales worksheet of yours has thousands and thousands of rows. Manually sorting through them all could take a lifetime. Using a pivot table, you can automatically aggregate all of the sales figures for product 1, product 2, and product 3 -- and calculate their respective sums -- in less than a minute.</p> \n<h3>2. Show product sales as percentages of total sales.</h3> \n<p>Pivot tables naturally show the totals of each row or column when you create it. But that's not the only figure you can automatically produce.</p> \n<p>Let's say you entered quarterly sales numbers for three separate products into an Excel sheet and turned this data into a pivot table. The table would automatically give you three totals at the bottom of each column -- having added up each product's quarterly sales. But what if you wanted to find the <em>percentage</em> these product sales contributed of all company sales, rather than just those products' sales totals?</p> \n<p>With a pivot table, you can configure each column to give you the column's percentage of all three column totals, instead of just the column total. If three product sales totaled $200,000 in sales, for example, and the first product made $45,000, you can edit a pivot table to instead say this product contributed 22.5% of all company sales.</p> \n<p>To show product sales as percentages of total sales in a pivot table, simply right-click the cell carrying a sales total and select <strong>\"Show Values As\"</strong> &gt; <strong>\"% of Grand Total.\"</strong></p> \n<h3>3. Combine duplicate data.</h3> \n<p>In this scenario, you've just completed a blog redesign and had to update a bunch of URLs. Unfortunately, your blog reporting software didn't handle it very well, and ended up splitting the \"view\" metrics for single posts between two different URLs. So in your spreadsheet, you have two separate instances of each individual blog post. In order to get accurate data, you need to combine the view totals for each of these duplicates.</p> \n<p>That's where the pivot table comes into play. Instead of having to manually search for and combine all the metrics from the duplicates, you can summarize your data (via pivot table) by blog post title, and voilà: the view metrics from those duplicate posts will be aggregated automatically.</p> \n<h3>4. Get an employee head count for separate departments.</h3> \n<p>Pivot tables are helpful for automatically calculating things that you can't easily find in a basic Excel table. One of those things is counting rows that all have something in common.</p> \n<p>If you have a list of employees in an Excel sheet, for instance, and next to the employees' names are the respective departments they belong to, you can create a pivot table from this data that shows you each department name and the number of employees that belong to those departments. The pivot table effectively eliminates your task of sorting the Excel sheet by department name and counting each row manually.</p> \n<h3>5. Add default values to empty cells.</h3> \n<p>Not every dataset you enter into Excel will populate every cell. If you're waiting for new data to come in before entering it into Excel, you might have lots of empty cells that look confusing or need further explaining when showing this data to your manager. That's where pivot tables come in.</p> \n<p>You can easily customize a pivot table to fill empty cells with a default value, such as $0, or TBD (for \"to be determined\"). For large tables of data, being able to tag these cells quickly is a useful feature when many people are reviewing the same sheet.</p> \n<p>To automatically format the empty cells of your pivot table, right-click your table and click <strong>\"PivotTable Options.\"</strong> In the window that appears, check the box labeled <strong>\"Empty Cells As\"</strong> and enter what you'd like displayed when a cell has no other value.</p> \n<div class=\"hsg-featured-snippet\"> \n <h2>How to Create a Pivot Table</h2> \n <ol> \n  <li>Enter your data into a range of rows and columns.</li> \n  <li>Sort your data by a specific attribute.</li> \n  <li>Highlight your cells to create your pivot table.</li> \n  <li>Drag and drop a field into the \"Row Labels\" area.</li> \n  <li>Drag and drop a field into the \"Values\" area.</li> \n  <li>Fine-tune your calculations.</li> \n </ol> \n</div> \n<p>Now that you have a better sense of what pivot tables can be used for, let's get into the nitty-gritty of how to actually create one.</p> \n<div class=\"video-container-responsive\"> \n <div style=\"display: block;\"> \n  <div class=\"wistia_responsive_padding\" style=\"padding: 56.25% 0 0 0; position: relative;\"> \n   <div class=\"wistia_responsive_wrapper\" style=\"height: 100%; left: 0; position: absolute; top: 0; width: 100%;\"> \n    <div class=\"hs-responsive-embed-wrapper hs-responsive-embed\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; width: 100%; height: auto; position: relative; overflow: hidden; padding: 0; max-width: 475px; max-height: 268px; min-width: 256px; margin: 0px auto;\"> \n     <div class=\"hs-responsive-embed-inner-wrapper\" style=\"position: relative; overflow: hidden; max-width: 100%; padding-bottom: 56.42%; margin: 0;\">\n      <iframe class=\"wistia_embed hs-responsive-embed-iframe\" style=\"position: absolute; top: 0; left: 0; width: 100%; height: 100%; border: none;\" src=\"http://fast.wistia.net/embed/iframe/cufjkvmw35?videoFoam=true\" name=\"wistia_embed\" width=\"NaN\" height=\"NaN\" frameborder=\"0\" allowfullscreen></iframe>\n     </div> \n    </div> \n   </div> \n  </div> \n </div>  \n</div> \n<h3>&nbsp;</h3> \n<h3>1. Enter your data into a range of rows and columns.</h3> \n<p>Every pivot table in Excel starts with a basic Excel table, where all your data is housed. To create this table, simply enter your values into a specific set of rows and columns. Use the topmost row or the topmost column to categorize your values by what they represent.</p> \n<p>For example, to create an Excel table of blog post performance data, you might have a column listing each \"URL,\" a column listing each URL's \"Post Title,\" a column listing each post's \"Views to Date,\" and so on. (We'll be using that example in the steps that follow.)</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/excel-data-in-table.jpg?width=793&amp;name=excel-data-in-table.jpg\" alt=\"Excel data entered in three columns in preparation for creating a pivot table\" width=\"793\" style=\"width: 793px;\"></p> \n<h3>2. Sort your data by a specific attribute.</h3> \n<p>When you have all the data you want entered into your Excel sheet, you'll want to sort this data in some way so it's easier to manage once you turn it into a pivot table.</p> \n<p>To sort your data, click the <strong>\"Data\"</strong> tab in the top navigation bar and select the <strong>\"Sort\"</strong> icon underneath it. In the window that appears, you can opt to sort your data by any column you want and in any order. To sort your Excel sheet by \"Views to Date,\" for example, select this column title under <strong>\"Column\"</strong> and then select whether you want to order your posts from smallest to largest, or from largest to smallest.</p> \n<p>Select <strong>\"OK\"</strong> on the bottom-right of the Sort window, and you'll successfully reorder each row of your Excel sheet by the number of views each blog post has received.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/sort-data-excel.jpg?width=690&amp;name=sort-data-excel.jpg\" alt=\"Sort window of Excel sheet\" width=\"690\" style=\"width: 690px;\"></p> \n<h3>3. Highlight your cells to create your pivot table.</h3> \n<p>Once you've entered data into your Excel worksheet, and sorted it to your liking, highlight the cells you'd like to summarize in a pivot table. Click <strong>\"Insert\"</strong> along the top navigation, and select the <strong>\"PivotTable\"</strong> icon. You can also click anywhere in your worksheet, select \"PivotTable,\" and manually enter the range of cells you'd like included in the PivotTable.</p> \n<p>This will open an option box where, in addition to setting your cell range, you can select whether or not to launch this pivot table in a new worksheet or keep it in the existing worksheet. If you open a new sheet, you can navigate to and away from it on the bottom of your Excel workbook. Once you've chosen, click <strong>\"OK.\"</strong></p> \n<p>Alternatively, you can highlight your cells, select \"Recommended PivotTables\" to the right of the PivotTable icon, and open a pivot table with pre-set suggestions for how to organize each row and column.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/inserting%20a%20pivot%20table%20in%20excel.png?width=600&amp;name=inserting%20a%20pivot%20table%20in%20excel.png\" alt=\"Creating a pivot table under the &quot;Insert&quot; option in Excel\" width=\"600\" title=\"Creating a pivot table under the &quot;Insert&quot; option in Excel\" style=\"width: 600px;\"></p> \n<p><strong>Note:</strong> <em>If you're using a version of Excel earlier than Excel 2016, \"PivotTables\" may be under <strong>\"Tables\"</strong> or <strong>\"Data\"</strong> along the top navigation, rather than \"Insert.\" In Google Sheets, you can create pivot tables from the <strong>\"Data\"</strong> dropdown along the top navigation.</em></p> \n<h3>4. Drag and drop a field into the \"Row Labels\" area.</h3> \n<p>After you've completed Step 1, Excel will create a blank pivot table for you. Your next step is to drag and drop a field -- labeled according to the names of the columns in your spreadsheet -- into the <strong>\"Row Labels\"</strong> area. This will determine what unique identifier -- blog post title, product name, and so on -- the pivot table will organize your data by.</p> \n<p>For example, let's say you want to organize a bunch of blogging data by post title. To do that, you'd simply click and drag the “Title” field to the \"Row Labels\" area.</p> \n<p><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/pivot-table-step-2.png?width=600&amp;name=pivot-table-step-2.png\" alt=\"Adding row labels to a pivot table in Excel\" title=\"Adding row labels to a pivot table in Excel\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; width: 600px;\" width=\"600\"></p> \n<p><strong>Note:</strong> <em>Your pivot table may look different depending on which version of Excel you're working with. However, the general principles remain the same.</em></p> \n<h3>5. Drag and drop a field into the \"Values\" area.<strong><br></strong></h3> \n<p>Once you've established what you're going to organize your data by, your next step is to add in some values by dragging a field into the <strong>\"Values\"</strong> area.</p> \n<p>Sticking with the blogging data example, let's say you want to summarize blog post views by title. To do this, you'd simply drag the \"Views\" field into the Values area.</p> \n<p><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/pivot-table-step-3.png?width=600&amp;name=pivot-table-step-3.png\" alt=\"Adding values to a pivot table in Excel\" title=\"Adding values to a pivot table in Excel\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; width: 600px;\" width=\"600\"></p> \n<h3>6. Fine-tune your calculations.<strong><br></strong></h3> \n<p>The sum of a particular value will be calculated by default, but you can easily change this to something like average, maximum, or minimum depending on what you want to calculate.</p> \n<p>On a Mac, you can do this by clicking on the small <strong>\"<em>i\"</em></strong> next to a value in the \"Values\" area, selecting the option you want, and clicking \"OK.\" Once you’ve made your selection, your pivot table will be updated accordingly.</p> \n<p><span class=\"content-post__body\">If you're using a PC, you'll need to click on the small upside-down triangle next to your value and select <strong>\"Value Field Settings\"</strong> in order to access the menu.</span></p> \n<p><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/pivot-table-step-4.png?width=600&amp;name=pivot-table-step-4.png\" alt=\"Changing the field options of a pivot table in Excel\" title=\"Changing the field options of a pivot table in Excel\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; width: 600px;\" width=\"600\"></p> \n<h2><span><span>Digging Deeper With Pivot Tables</span></span></h2> \n<p>You've now learned the basics of pivot table creation in Excel. But depending on what you need your pivot table for, you might not be done.</p> \n<p>For example, you may notice that the data in your pivot table isn't sorted the way you'd like. If were the case, Excel's Sort function can help you out. Alternatively, you may need to incorporate data from another source into your reporting, in which case the VLOOKUP function could come in handy.</p> \n<p>To take a deeper dive into the world of Excel and learn about its various functions, download our comprehensive guide, <em><strong><a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/how-to-use-excel\">How to Use Excel</a></strong>.</em></p> \n<p>Want more Excel tips? Check out these <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/excel-graph-tricks-list\">design tips for creating charts and graphs</a>.</p> \n<p><em>Editor's note: This post was originally published in December 2018 and has been updated for comprehensiveness.</em></p> \n<p></p> \n<div>\n <a class=\"close\"> </a>\n</div>  \n<img \">","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Mon, 19 Oct 2020 11:00:00 +0000","feedId":54,"bgimg":"","linkMd5":"4f57a09273647aabda86f5d3ec20f9b2","bgimgJsdelivr":"","metaImg":"","author":"edevaney@hubspot.com (Erik Devaney)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/pivot_table-1.gif?width=600&name=pivot_table-1.gif":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn16@2020_2/2020/10/27/16-55-03-479_4537a76ac95b5872.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/excel-data-in-table.jpg?width=793&name=excel-data-in-table.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn95@2020_5/2020/10/27/16-54-15-479_205eac048b2247d2.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/sort-data-excel.jpg?width=690&name=sort-data-excel.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn54@2020_6/2020/10/27/16-54-09-960_bfa96680991ff775.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/inserting%20a%20pivot%20table%20in%20excel.png?width=600&name=inserting%20a%20pivot%20table%20in%20excel.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn65@2020_2/2020/10/27/16-54-02-562_ff45ea98e2fb56f8.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/pivot-table-step-2.png?width=600&name=pivot-table-step-2.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn73@2020_3/2020/10/27/16-53-53-905_0999d87d90cf94db.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/pivot-table-step-3.png?width=600&name=pivot-table-step-3.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn84@2020_5/2020/10/27/16-53-47-831_339e1bd884c7169e.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/pivot-table-step-4.png?width=600&name=pivot-table-step-4.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn81@2020_5/2020/10/27/16-53-58-798_c85e792cf986e77a.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fhow-to-create-pivot-table-tutorial-ht&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn35@2020_1/2020/10/27/16-53-49-557_fbb29676339ccb1f.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1603817624920},{"createdTime":"2020-10-28 00:53:44","updatedTime":"2020-10-28 00:53:44","title":"The 11 Best Social Media Dashboard Tools & Apps","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/social-media-dashboard-tools","description":"<p>When implementing your social media strategy, it's easy to realize that manually posting on multiple different websites, multiple times a day, isn't optimal for your busy schedule. But it's not easy to tell from a baseline or pricing page which tools are not only the best for efficiency but best for your business.</p> \n<p>Instead of spending hours of extra research combing through all of your options and sitting through countless demos and free trials, we've compiled a list of the best social media dashboards that fit your budget and brand.</p> \n<p></p> \n<p>These social media dashboards are optimized for every type of SMB; whether you're a social media team or a party of one, these apps will help you accomplish your goals in a streamlined, efficient way.</p> \n<h3>1. <a href=\"http://hubspot.com\" style=\"text-decoration: none;\">HubSpot</a></h3> \n<h4>Price: <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/pricing/marketing?term=annual&amp;edition=starter\"><span style=\"font-weight: normal;\">Included in Professional version ($800/mo) or Enterprise version ($3,200/mo)</span></a></h4> \n<h4>Why it's great: <span style=\"font-weight: normal;\">All-in-one social media software</span></h4> \n<p>With HubSpot's social media management tool, you get an all-inclusive package. Connect up to 300 accounts and schedule up to 10,000 posts a month. Plus, for super in-depth planners, you can schedule posts up to 3 years in advance.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Screen%20Shot%202020-10-26%20at%206.13.30%20PM.png?width=1088&amp;name=Screen%20Shot%202020-10-26%20at%206.13.30%20PM.png\" alt=\"Screen Shot 2020-10-26 at 6.13.30 PM\" width=\"1088\" style=\"width: 1088px;\"></p> \n<p>HubSpot's social media management features include monitoring mentions and engagement, and provides full analytic reports. You're able to schedule posts all in one place without leaving the system.</p> \n<h3>2.<a href=\"http://later.com\" style=\"text-decoration: none;\"> Later</a></h3> \n<h4>Price: <a href=\"http://later.com/pricing\" style=\"font-weight: normal;\">$9, $19, $29, $49 per month, and enterprise pricing</a></h4> \n<h4>Why it's great: <span style=\"font-weight: normal;\">Instagram scheduling</span></h4> \n<p>While you can connect Facebook, Twitter, and Pinterest profiles, Later is best for Instagram scheduling. This is because of its image-based content calendar scheduling, so you can see a bird's eye view of your brand in a monthly, visual format.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/later%20scheduling%20example.png?width=780&amp;name=later%20scheduling%20example.png\" alt=\"later scheduling example\" width=\"780\" style=\"width: 780px; display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\"></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center; font-size: 12px;\"><u><a href=\"http://later.com/\"><span style=\"font-style: italic; font-family: 'times new roman', times;\">Image Source</span></a></u></p> \n<p>Later is also an Instagram partner, which means it integrates with Instagram's API. This partnership means your account information will stay completely safe, which is important for Instagram Business accounts that have Shopping set up.</p> \n<h3>3. <a href=\"http://sendible.com\" style=\"text-decoration: none;\">Sendible</a></h3> \n<h4>Price: <a href=\"http://sendible.com/pricing\" style=\"font-weight: normal;\">$29 up to $299 per month </a></h4> \n<h4>Why it's great: <span style=\"font-weight: normal;\">Agency-based management</span></h4> \n<p>Are you a social media or marketing agency? Sendible may be the answer to unkempt management: it's a tool fit for an agency with clients. It helps you streamline how you manage brands and offers a couple unique features that help you succeed.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/sendible%20report%20example.png?width=1030&amp;name=sendible%20report%20example.png\" alt=\"sendible report example\" width=\"1030\" style=\"width: 1030px; display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\"></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center; font-size: 12px;\"><span style=\"font-family: 'times new roman', times; font-style: italic;\"><u><a href=\"https://assets.sendible.com/cheat-sheets/reporting-guide.pdf\">Image Source</a></u></span></p> \n<p>Sendible has a royalty-free image search tool and a Canva integration. Sendible also has social listening tools, a Reports function, scheduling, and post previews. To put it simply: this is a full dashboard and suite of tools to put your client accounts all in one place.</p> \n<h3>4.<a href=\"http://tailwind.com\" style=\"text-decoration: none;\"> Tailwind</a></h3> \n<h4>Price:<a href=\"http://tailwind.com/pricing\" style=\"font-weight: normal;\"> $9.99 up to $799.99 per month, or enterprise pricing </a></h4> \n<h4>Why it's great: <span style=\"font-weight: normal;\">Pinterest and Instagram management</span></h4> \n<p>Tailwind is a very unique program, providing services for two apps normally not paired with each other: Pinterest and Instagram. It makes sense, however, considering both apps focus on visual multimedia. Offering a full media dashboard with scheduling, social listening, and analytics tools, Tailwind also has a few interesting program-specific services.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/tailwind%20report%20example.png?width=697&amp;name=tailwind%20report%20example.png\" alt=\"tailwind report example\" width=\"697\" style=\"width: 697px; display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\"></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center; font-size: 12px;\"><span style=\"font-style: italic; font-family: 'times new roman', times;\"><u><a href=\"https://blog.tailwindapp.com/case-studies/franc/\">Image Source</a></u></span></p> \n<p>First, it gives suggestions about how to improve Instagram and Pinterest performance. It also comes with a way to promote Pinterest content and manage Instagram user-generated content. If your brand is heavily focused on visuals, Tailwind may be right for you.</p> \n<h3>5. <a href=\"http://sproutsocial.com\" style=\"text-decoration: none;\">Sprout Social</a></h3> \n<h4>Price: <a href=\"http://sproutsocial.com/pricing\" style=\"font-weight: normal; text-decoration: none;\">$99 up to $249 per user per month</a></h4> \n<h4>Why it's great: <span style=\"font-weight: normal;\">Team-based management</span></h4> \n<p>Sprout Social is a dashboard platform that's focused entirely on social media teams. What you get for your money is a full suite of tools, including options that allow you to create and schedule posts, social listening tools, and most of all: analytic data.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/sprout%20social%20report%20example.png?width=782&amp;name=sprout%20social%20report%20example.png\" alt=\"sprout social report example\" width=\"782\" style=\"width: 782px; display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\"></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center; font-size: 12px;\"><span style=\"font-style: italic; font-family: 'times new roman', times;\"><u><a href=\"https://sproutsocial.com/insights/report-builder/\">Image Source</a></u></span></p> \n<p>The analytic tools are the shining star of Sprout Social. Expansive, in-depth reporting is available. If that's a focus for your brand, consider Sprout. They make the reports so professional and easy to read, there's no editing required.</p> \n<h3>6. <a href=\"http://meetedgar.com\" style=\"text-decoration: none;\">MeetEdgar</a></h3> \n<h4>Price: <a href=\"http://meetedgar.com/pricing\" style=\"font-weight: normal; text-decoration: none;\">$49/month</a></h4> \n<h4>Why it's great: <span style=\"font-weight: normal;\">100% automated scheduling</span></h4> \n<p>MeetEdgar is an app with a different approach to social media management, is. All users do is upload categorically-based content into their account and create time slots for when they want their account to post said content.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/meetedgar%20category%20example.png?width=681&amp;name=meetedgar%20category%20example.png\" alt=\"meetedgar category example\" width=\"681\" style=\"width: 681px; display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\"></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center; font-size: 12px;\"><span style=\"font-style: italic; font-family: 'times new roman', times;\"><u><a href=\"https://meetedgar.com/blog/five-big-brands-strategies-for-recycling-social-media-updates/\">Image Source</a></u></span></p> \n<p>Then, according to the time slots and categories, the app will schedule and upload content. If you want your Twitter account to post a meme at 11 AM on a Thursday, MeetEdgar would search through the \"Meme\" category of content you've already uploaded, schedule, and post it.</p> \n<p>Managers might like this option, if they don't have enough time to constantly schedule and upload content. They can plug in their entire content calendar at the start of the month and remove the heavy lifting for the next few weeks.</p> \n<p>Post-enhancing dashboards such as these three can take care of your social strategy without losing any of quality.</p> \n<h3>1. <a href=\"http://tweetdeck.com\" style=\"text-decoration: none;\">TweetDeck</a></h3> \n<h4>Price: <span style=\"font-weight: normal;\">Free</span><br>Why it's great: <span style=\"font-weight: normal;\">Twitter dash management</span></h4> \n<p>TweetDeck is amazing if you're tired of flipping back and forth through the different tabs on Twitter. It’s a free extension of twitter (no download required) that automatically gives you your account's Home, Notifications, Trending, and Messages in a dashboard view.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/tweetdeck%20dsahboard%20example.png?width=550&amp;name=tweetdeck%20dsahboard%20example.png\" alt=\"tweetdeck dsahboard example\" width=\"550\" style=\"width: 550px; display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\"></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center; font-size: 12px;\"><span style=\"font-family: 'times new roman', times;\"><a href=\"http://blogs.sussex.ac.uk/tel/2014/07/17/managing-your-tweets-with-tweetdeck/\" style=\"font-style: italic;\"><u>Image Source</u></a></span></p> \n<p>This app is especially handy for posting quickly. You can engage with your Twitter in-app, and it feels like a much faster method of running your account than the in-browser functionality . Plus, TweetDeck automatically updates with any new notifications.</p> \n<h3>2.<a href=\"http://tweetstats.com\" style=\"text-decoration: none;\"> TweetStats</a></h3> \n<h4>Price: <span style=\"font-weight: normal;\">Free</span><br>Why it's great: <span style=\"font-weight: normal;\">Free basic Twitter analytics</span></h4> \n<p>This little website is super handy if you don't have the budget to pay for analytic tools. TweetStats can give you the analytics of any Twitter account in about two minutes. The website displays graphs of when you've tweeted, the volume of tweets, time you usually tweet, and your most used words and hashtags.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/tweetstats%20analytics%20example.png?width=370&amp;name=tweetstats%20analytics%20example.png\" alt=\"tweetstats analytics example\" width=\"370\" style=\"width: 370px; display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\"></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center; font-size: 12px;\"><span style=\"font-style: italic; font-family: 'times new roman', times;\"><u><a href=\"http://www.tweetstats.com/\">Image Source</a></u></span></p> \n<p>Using TweetStats is especially helpful if you want to view the ecosystem of your Twitter. Are you staying on-brand? Are you meeting your tweet goals? What hashtags can you elevate the use of?</p> \n<h3>3.<a href=\"http://tubebuddy.com\" style=\"text-decoration: none;\"> TubeBuddy</a></h3> \n<h4>Price:<a href=\"http://tubebuddy.com/pricing\" style=\"font-weight: normal; text-decoration: none;\"> Free plan, or $9 up to $49 per month </a><br>Why it's great: <span style=\"font-weight: normal;\">YouTube management</span></h4> \n<p>If you have a large YouTube presence, consider TubeBuddy. TubeBuddy offers a hefty suite of perks to present a full dashboard. Categories include video dashboard, video SEO, bulk processing, promotion, data &amp; research, and productivity.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/tubebuddy%20card%20template.png?width=769&amp;name=tubebuddy%20card%20template.png\" alt=\"tubebuddy card template\" width=\"769\" style=\"width: 769px; display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\"></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center; font-size: 12px;\"><span style=\"font-style: italic; font-family: 'times new roman', times;\"><u><a href=\"https://www.tubebuddy.com/tools#cardtemplates\">Image Source</a></u></span></p> \n<p>The screenshot above features one of TubeBuddy's card template features. Card templates streamline the process of uploading and finalizing YouTube videos, making it easier to sort videos into a playlist on your channel.</p> \n<p>You can install the program for free on Chrome, working sort of like an extension. The free plan gives you access to analytics, productivity, and SEO tools to get started. TubeBuddy is also a YouTube Partner and integrates with Alexa.</p> \n<h3>4. <a href=\"http://mavsocial.com\" style=\"text-decoration: none;\">MavSocial</a></h3> \n<h4>Price: <a href=\"http://mavsocial.com/pricing\" style=\"font-weight: normal; text-decoration: none;\">Free plan, or $19 up to $499 per month </a><br>Why it's great: <span style=\"font-weight: normal;\">Visual-based streamlined management</span></h4> \n<p>This is a great post-enhancing tool. MavSocial has a focus on visual-based management, and as such, offers unique perks, like editing multimedia content and a stock photo digital library. With the editing tools, you can add filters to your photos, crop, and search for royalty-free images.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/mavsocial%20dashboard%20example.png?width=400&amp;name=mavsocial%20dashboard%20example.png\" alt=\"mavsocial dashboard example\" width=\"400\" style=\"width: 400px; display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\"></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center; font-size: 12px;\"><span style=\"font-style: italic; font-family: 'times new roman', times;\"><u><a href=\"https://blackbirdpublishing.com/social-media-management-with-mavsocial/\">Image Source</a></u></span></p> \n<p>On top of all of this, MavSocial has a full dashboard suite, meaning you can schedule content and engage with followers. MavSocial supports YouTube, Facebook, Twitter, and Instagram. The app is also an Instagram Partner.</p> \n<h3>5. <a href=\"http://hootsuite.com\" style=\"text-decoration: none;\">Hootsuite </a></h3> \n<h4>Price: <a href=\"http://hootsuite.com/plans\" style=\"font-weight: normal; text-decoration: none;\">Free plan, or $29 up to $599 per month</a><br>Why it's great: <span style=\"font-weight: normal;\">All-in-one social media management</span></h4> \n<p>Hootsuite is a popular social media tool and boasts over <a href=\"https://hootsuite.com/en-sg/newsroom/press-releases/hootsuite-surpasses-15-million-users-hosts-worlds-largest-online-social-media-conference-for-free\"><u>15 million users</u></a>. The free plan lets you add three social accounts from different platforms on one screen and has a limit on how many posts are available to make.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/hootsuite%20dashboard%20example.png?width=561&amp;name=hootsuite%20dashboard%20example.png\" alt=\"hootsuite dashboard example\" width=\"561\" style=\"width: 561px; display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\"></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center; font-size: 12px;\"><span style=\"font-style: italic; font-family: 'times new roman', times;\"><u><a href=\"https://blog.hootsuite.com/social-media-sentiment-analysis-tools/\">Image Source</a></u></span></p> \n<p>While user-friendly, Hootsuite is an expansive app. You can create ads, running an ROI report on those ads, and also has options to schedule and create posts. Note that you can only post on your Instagram using the scheduler, if you have an Instagram Business account.</p> \n<p>Every business is unique, and so is every social media dashboard. Because of that, finding the best fit can be daunting. Covering all your bases can be simplified with a social media dashboard, as well as building a community and social presence.</p> \n<p>If you want to take a crack at building your own content calendar that'll help you plan your social media posts, check out our article <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/blog/tabid/6307/bid/33415/the-social-media-publishing-schedule-every-marketer-needs-template.aspx\" style=\"text-decoration: none;\">here</a>.</p> \n<p></p> \n<p></p>
