Insider</a> (Domain Authority = 58)</li> \n <li><a href=\"http://n49.com\">n49.com</a> (Domain Authority = 58)</li> \n <li><a href=\"http://mysheriff.net\">My Sheriff</a> (Domain Authority = 57)</li> \n <li><a href=\"http://opendi.us\">opendi.us</a> (Domain Authority = 56)</li> \n <li><a href=\"http://bizhwy.com\">Bizhwy.com</a> (Domain Authority = 55)</li> \n <li><a href=\"http://smartguy.com\">Smartguy.com</a> (Domain Authority = 55)</li> \n <li><a href=\"http://wherezit.com\">Wherezit.com</a> (Domain Authority = 55)</li> \n <li><a href=\"http://www.discoverourtown.com/\">DiscoverOurTown.com</a> (Domain Authority = 54)</li> \n <li><a href=\"http://nexport.com\">Nexport.com</a> (Domain Authority = 52)</li> \n <li><a href=\"https://usdirectory.com/\">USdirectory.com</a> (Domain Authority = 50)</li> \n <li><a href=\"http://wowcity.com\">Wowcity.com</a> (Domain Authority = 49)</li> \n <li><a href=\"http://us.bizadee.com\">Bizadee</a> (Domain Authority = 48)</li> \n <li><a href=\"http://wand.com\">Wand.com</a> (Domain Authority = 47)</li> \n</ol> \n<p>Making sure that you have a presence everywhere your potential customers might find you is critical to any <a title=\"local marketing plan\" href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/blog/tabid/6307/bid/29432/Everything-You-Need-to-Know-to-Dominate-Local-Search.aspx\">local marketing plan</a>. Don't wait -- add your local business to some of these business listings and directories as soon as you can.</p> \n<p></p> \n<div>\n <a class=\"close\">&nbsp;</a>\n</div>  \n<img src=\"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&amp;k=14&amp;r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fblog%2Ftabid%2F6307%2Fbid%2F10322%2Fthe-ultimate-list-50-local-business-directories.aspx&amp;bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&amp;bvt=rss\" alt=\"\" width=\"1\" height=\"1\" style=\"min-height:1px!important;width:1px!important;border-width:0!important;margin-top:0!important;margin-bottom:0!important;margin-right:0!important;margin-left:0!important;padding-top:0!important;padding-bottom:0!important;padding-right:0!important;padding-left:0!important; \">","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Thu, 22 Oct 2020 11:06:00 +0000","feedId":54,"bgimg":"","linkMd5":"13c8604f8f27dfc3c580178c8fd40812","bgimgJsdelivr":"","metaImg":"","author":"Jamie Pitman","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fblog%2Ftabid%2F6307%2Fbid%2F10322%2Fthe-ultimate-list-50-local-business-directories.aspx&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn15@2020_4/2020/10/27/16-54-03-511_614a6151ea810921.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1603817624893},{"createdTime":"2020-10-28 00:53:44","updatedTime":"2020-10-28 00:53:44","title":"Copywriting 101: 6 Traits of Excellent Copy Readers Will Remember","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/good-copywriting-practices-list","description":"<p><a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mad_Men\"><em>Mad Men</em></a> fans everywhere remember the pivotal first scene where we learn just how talented Don Draper is at his job.</p> \n<p>Faced with an almost-impossible copywriting task, he rose to the occasion to solve a huge problem for his client, Lucky Strike. In spite of research warning customers of the dangers of cigarettes, Draper delivered the iconic slogan -- \"It's toasted\" -- to differentiate the brand from its competitors.</p> \n<iframe style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; margin: 0px auto;\" src=\"http://www.youtube.com/embed/GALMX2BO5ps\" width=\"560\" height=\"315\" frameborder=\"0\" allowfullscreen></iframe> \n<p>Now, we definitely aren't advocating for smoking cigarettes (or many of Draper's <a href=\"https://www.thrillist.com/culture/how-long-would-don-draper-live-don-draper-mad-men-life-expectancy\">health choices</a>). But fictional or not, you can't deny the memorability and catchiness of that tagline.</p> \n<p></p> \n<p>It's easy to recognize good copywriting when you see it, but there are actually several characteristics that really separate outstanding writing from the rest of the pack. Want to know them? Read on below to find out.</p> \n<h2>What is copywriting?</h2> \n<p>Copywriting is one of the most critical elements of any and all forms of marketing and advertising. Copywriting consists of the words, either written or spoken, marketers use to try to get people to take an action after reading or hearing them.&nbsp;</p> \n<p>Copywriting is like a call-to-action, but on a bigger scale: Copywriters are trying to get people to feel, think, or respond -- or, ideally, to Google the slogan or brand to learn more about the campaign. And where a blog post like this one has the luxury of hundreds of words with which to make a case, copywriters only have a few words to make their case.</p> \n<p>But short and sweet isn't the only characteristic of good copywriting. Keep reading to learn more characteristics of truly memorable copy.</p> \n<h2>6 Traits of Good Copywriting</h2> \n<h3>1) It tilts your perspective.</h3> \n<p>Sometimes, all a message needs to break through is a slight shift in angle. We've grown so accustomed to blocking out marketing messages, we don't even see them anymore. One of the most powerful things a copywriter can do is break down a reader's guard with an unexpected approach. Every story has a myriad of angles -- your job as a copywriter is to find the one that resonates.</p> \n<div>\n <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/594ab5f61700002000102212.png?width=600&amp;name=594ab5f61700002000102212.png\" alt=\"594ab5f61700002000102212.png\" title=\"594ab5f61700002000102212.png\" width=\"600\" style=\"width: 600px; display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\">\n</div> \n<div style=\"text-align: center;\">\n <span style=\"font-size: 12px;\">Source: <a href=\"https://ppdsilencesucks.com/\"><em>Silence Sucks</em></a></span>\n</div> \n<p>This ad from Sage Therapeutics pressing the importance of talking about postpartum depression works because instead of asking readers to care about something they don't know, it puts them in the position of experiencing the struggle that mothers suffering do. Did they miss some readers who quickly passed by the ad thinking it was for adult pacifiers? Most definitely. But the ad resonated that much more thoroughly with those who read it.</p> \n<p>The next time you sit down to write, try out this approach. Don't take the topic head on. Instead, ask yourself why it matters. Each time you write down an answer, challenge yourself to push it further. Find the larger story happening behind your message.</p> \n<h3>2) It finds connections.</h3> \n<p>In 1996, Steve Jobs let the cat out of the bag. He was <a href=\"http://www.wired.com/wired/archive//4.02/jobs.html?person=steve_jobs&amp;topic_set=wiredpeople\">speaking with a journalist from <em>Wired</em> on the topic of creativity</a> and explained:</p> \n<blockquote> \n <p style=\"padding-left: 30px;\">\"Creativity is just connecting things. When you ask creative people how they did something they feel a little guilty because they didn't really do it, they just saw something. It seemed obvious to them after awhile.\"</p> \n</blockquote> \n<p>Let's say you have to write an ad for a new pair of sneakers. You could take the assignment head on. You could write about the elasticity of the shoe's sole or the lightweight design. Indeed, many have. Or you could put all of that aside and instead draw the connection between the product and the experience it evokes.</p> \n<p><img class=\"wt-blog__normal-image alignCenter shadow\" style=\"width: 503px; display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hub/53/file-398023691-png/Run_ad.png?width=503&amp;name=Run_ad.png\" alt=\"Run_ad\" width=\"503\"></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><span style=\"font-size: 12px;\">Source: <em><a href=\"https://www.pinterest.com/pin/401242648028519555/\">Pinterest</a></em></span></p> \n<p>Two things are happening in this ad. First, the copy recognizes that for many, running isn't about running at all -- it's about solitude, peace, and restoring sanity to an otherwise hectic life. Second, not only does Nike connect the ad to the experience of running, it actually connects to the sound that those shoes make as they hit the pavement.</p> \n<p>This ad is about the complexity of one's life fading away and being replaced by simplicity and clarity. As the copy progresses, the sentences simplify and the copy's complexity is slowly replaced by the simple and rhythmic pounding of words: run, run, run, run. The same rhythm one hears when all but their footsteps have faded away. <em>That's</em>&nbsp;connection.</p> \n<h3>3) It has a stunning lead.</h3> \n<p>The following are all headlines or leading sentences from <a href=\"http://www.urbandaddy.com/home/bos\">Urban Daddy</a>, an email-based magazine drawing attention to new products, experiences, and eateries.</p> \n<ul> \n <li>\"Six days. That’s how long you have until 65% of your body is turkey.\"</li> \n <li>\"There are 8,760 hours in a year. And just one hour in which a stand will be dispensing gratis latkes with homemade applesauce and sour cream in Harvard Square. Yeah, it’s not fair. But 60 minutes is 60 minutes.\"</li> \n <li>\"Ewoks. Talk about living.\"</li> \n</ul> \n<p>What's common among each of these leads? They make us want to read the next line. I mean, seriously, how much do you want to know <a href=\"http://www.urbandaddy.com/bos/leisure/13450/Tree_Spa_at_Hidden_Pond_Getting_Massaged_in_a_Maine_Treehouse_Boston_BOS_Service\">where that Ewok thing is headed</a>?</p> \n<p>There's an adage in copywriting that's loosely credited to copywriter and business owner Joe Sugarman, which roughly states that the purpose of the headline is to get you to read the first line. The purpose of the first line is to get you to read the second line, and so on. In short, if your first line doesn't enthrall your readers, all is lost.</p> \n<h3>4) It is born out of listening.</h3> \n<p>Seeing its plans to launch yet another gym in the greater Boston region, an outsider might have called the Harrington family a wee bit crazy. The market was already flush with gyms, including a new breed of luxury ones that seemed to be in an arms war for the flashiest perks. Gyms across the region were offering massage services, smoothie bars, and fleets of personal trainers. And GymIt wouldn't have any of that.</p> \n<p>What did <a href=\"http://www.gymit.com/about/\">GymIt</a> have? An understanding of its core audience. Before launching its new gym, the brand did a ton of listening to its primary market of gym-goers. For many in GymIt's target market, the added benefits associated with luxury gyms were nice to have, but came with a lot of baggage -- namely expensive rates and overly complex contracts.</p> \n<p>GymIt decided to simplify the gym-going experience for people who predominately cared about getting in and working out. The copy in its launch campaign and across its marketing materials reflects that understanding.</p> \n<p><img class=\"wt-blog__normal-image alignCenter shadow\" style=\"width: 600px; display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hub/53/file-397765571-png/GymIt__gyms_in_Boston_ma__health_clubs.png?width=600&amp;name=GymIt__gyms_in_Boston_ma__health_clubs.png\" alt=\"GymIt__gyms_in_Boston_ma__health_clubs\" width=\"600\" title=\"GymIt__gyms_in_Boston_ma__health_clubs\"></p> \n<p>In <a href=\"http://www.copyblogger.com/listen-carefully/\">an older blog post</a>, <em>Copyblogger</em>'s Robert Bruce put this nicely. \"Humble yourself and truly serve your audience, listen to their needs and desires, listen to the language they use,\" he said. \"If you listen carefully, your audience can eventually give you everything you need, including much of your copy. Get out of their way.\"</p> \n<h3>5) It avoids jargon and hyperbole.</h3> \n<p>Groundbreaking. Revolutionary. Business Solutions. Targetable Scale. Ideation. Evidence-based approaches. Industry-wide best practices.</p> \n<p>Have I lost you yet?</p> \n<p>When writers struggle to convey what is truly special about their company, product, or service, they sometimes fall back on jargon or hyperbole to underscore their point. The truth is, good copywriting doesn't need dressing up. Good copywriting should speak to the reader in human terms.</p> \n<p>This isn't to say you should never celebrate awards or achievements. Just be direct in the way you <em>explain</em> that achievement. This homepage from <a href=\"https://basecamp.com/\">Basecamp</a> does a nice job of highlighting its popularity in concrete terms.</p> \n<p><img class=\"wt-blog__normal-image alignCenter shadow\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; width: 600px;\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/basecamp-copywriting-example.png?width=600&amp;name=basecamp-copywriting-example.png\" alt=\"basecamp-copywriting-example.png\" title=\"basecamp-copywriting-example.png\" width=\"600\"></p> \n<h3>6) It cuts out excess.</h3> \n<p>Good writing gets to the point -- and that means cutting out excessive phrases, and rewording your sentences to be more direct. In an ad celebrating its \"academic\" readership, <a href=\"https://www.economist.com/\"><em>The Economist</em></a> playfully demonstrates this below.</p> \n<p><img class=\"wt-blog__normal-image alignCenter shadow\" style=\"width: 600px; display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hub/53/file-400349025-jpg/economist-1.jpg?width=600&amp;name=economist-1.jpg\" alt=\"economist-1\" width=\"600\" title=\"economist-1\"></p> \n<p>How do you rid excess words from your writing? It's half practice, half knowing where to cut. This <a href=\"http://www.dailywritingtips.com/10-techniques-for-more-precise-writing/\">article from <em>Daily Writing Tips</em></a> is one of the most effective summaries I've found on precise writing. Included in its tips:</p> \n<ul> \n <li><strong>Reduce verb phrases:</strong> For instance, turn \"The results are suggestive of the fact that\" to \"The results suggest.\"</li> \n <li><strong>Reduce wordy phrases to single words:</strong> You can change \"in order to\" into \"to.\" Another example: Turn \"Due to the fact that\" into \"because.\"</li> \n <li><strong>Avoid vague nouns:</strong> Phrases formed around general nouns like \"in the area of\" or \"on the topic of\" clutter sentences.</li> \n <li><a href=\"http://www.dailywritingtips.com/10-techniques-for-more-precise-writing/\">Read the full list of brevity tips here</a>.</li> \n</ul> \n<p>In general, if you can afford to cut without losing the meaning of a sentence, do so. Push yourself to strip down your word count. Turn 50-word homepage copy into 25, then push yourself again to make that 25-word sentence into 15 words. It's not about brevity so much as it is about making sure every word counts in your writing.</p> \n<p>Since my last point was about getting to the point, I'll keep this brief: <em>Words matter</em>. Every time you sit down to write an ad, web page, video script, or other content for your company, you have the opportunity to break through to people. Find those opportunities in your marketing and make sure that you've made the most of them.</p> \n<p><em>Editor's note: This post was originally published in November 2017 and has been updated for comprehensiveness.</em></p> \n<p></p> \n<p><span></span></p> \n<div>\n <a class=\"close\">&nbsp;</a>\n <span class=\"hs-cta-wrapper\"><span class=\"hs-cta-node hs-cta-544ec352-b131-458a-944d-20a70edea831\"><a href=\"https://cta-redirect.hubspot.com/cta/redirect/53/544ec352-b131-458a-944d-20a70edea831\"><img class=\"hs-cta-img\" style=\"border-width: 0px;\" src=\"https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/544ec352-b131-458a-944d-20a70edea831.png\" alt=\"free guide to writing well\"></a></span>   </span>E\n</div>  \n<img src=\"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&amp;k=14&amp;r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fgood-copywriting-practices-list&amp;bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&amp;bvt=rss\" alt=\"\" width=\"1\" height=\"1\" style=\"min-height:1px!important;width:1px!important;border-width:0!important;margin-top:0!important;margin-bottom:0!important;margin-right:0!important;margin-left:0!important;padding-top:0!important;padding-bottom:0!important;padding-right:0!important;padding-left:0!important; \">","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Tue, 20 Oct 2020 11:00:00 +0000","feedId":54,"bgimg":"","linkMd5":"916662064ded2c7b71e5e0095f6eedae","bgimgJsdelivr":"","metaImg":"","author":"manderson@hubspot.com (Meghan Keaney Anderson)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/594ab5f61700002000102212.png?width=600&name=594ab5f61700002000102212.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn17@2020_2/2020/10/27/16-54-01-489_d12ed0e0ed84be30.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hub/53/file-398023691-png/Run_ad.png?width=503&name=Run_ad.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn69@2020_4/2020/10/27/16-53-55-059_8095887b877b29ca.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hub/53/file-397765571-png/GymIt__gyms_in_Boston_ma__health_clubs.png?width=600&name=GymIt__gyms_in_Boston_ma__health_clubs.png":null,"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/basecamp-copywriting-example.png?width=600&name=basecamp-copywriting-example.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn35@2020_4/2020/10/27/16-53-51-792_c1b0e5aadf16cbfb.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hub/53/file-400349025-jpg/economist-1.jpg?width=600&name=economist-1.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn76@2020_4/2020/10/27/16-53-48-954_867a8bec1d37c27b.webp","https://no-cache.hubspot.com/cta/default/53/544ec352-b131-458a-944d-20a70edea831.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn84@2020_4/2020/10/27/16-54-10-955_7b6bc1a365300aad.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fgood-copywriting-practices-list&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn78@2020_6/2020/10/27/16-54-07-469_7ee22c63aa88ffd0.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1603817624915},{"createdTime":"2020-10-28 00:53:44","updatedTime":"2020-10-28 00:53:44","title":"50 Lucrative Blog Niches & Finding One That Works for You","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/blog-niche-ideas","description":"<p>There's an obscure album by an equally obscure guitarist named <a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Duck_Baker\">Duck Baker</a>&nbsp;called<em> <a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/There's_Something_for_Everyone_in_America\">There's Something for Everyone in America</a></em>. I don't know a ton about it — apart from the fact that it came out in 1975 and that its cover art is absolutely next-level. And while neither of those facts is particularly relevant to this article, the album's title <em>is</em>.&nbsp;</p>  \n<div>\n <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/50%20Lucrative%20Blog%20Niches%20%26%20Finding%20One%20That%20Works%20for%20You.jpeg?width=500&amp;name=50%20Lucrative%20Blog%20Niches%20%26%20Finding%20One%20That%20Works%20for%20You.jpeg\" alt=\"Blog niche ideas for everyone\" width=\"500\" style=\"width: 500px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\">\n</div> \n<p style=\"font-size: 12px; text-align: center;\"><a href=\"https://www.bestbuy.com/site/theres-something-for-everyone-in-america-bonus-track-cd/16937451.p?skuId=16937451\" style=\"font-style: italic;\">Image Source: Best Buy</a></p> \n<p>That idea that<em> \"there's something for everyone\"</em> doesn't just apply to America — nor does it have anything to do with what appears to be Lady Justice stabbing a tiger in the heart while Duck Baker casually looks on and smiles from a nearby window.</p> \n<p>No, that concept is also relevant to niche blog topics. Everyone has something that's meaningful and interesting to them in its own right, and in a lot of cases, those kinds of passions and pursuits can be channeled into a well-crafted, consistently maintained blog property.</p> \n<p>Here, we'll go over what you need to consider when choosing a niche blog topic and look into 50 potential blog niche ideas you can choose from.</p> \n<p></p> \n<h2>How to Choose Your Niche Blog Topic</h2> \n<p>So what should you blog about? How do you land on the topic that will resonate most with readers and keep you fulfilled in the long run? Well, first and foremost, you need to consider your areas of expertise.</p> \n<p>Where are you an authority? What can you talk about comfortably and compellingly? If you write a blog in some niche you only halfway understand, readers won't be receptive to it. They want to hear from an expert — someone who can demonstrate that they're qualified to offer tips or trustworthy opinions. But it doesn't end there.</p> \n<p>Writing a blog is a <em>personal</em> pursuit, so you need to write about something that bears <em>personal</em> significance. What do you <em>like</em> to write about? There has to be some degree of joy and enthusiasm behind your blog.</p> \n<p>It takes a lot of work to maintain a blog. It's tough to keep that effort up if you don't actually enjoy what you're writing about. You have to start your blog under the assumption that it will take a while to get off the ground.</p> \n<p>You're probably not going to be able to monetize your site or sell ad space immediately, so you need to be in it — in large part — for the love of the sport.</p> \n<p>Your niche has to reflect your passion because you'll probably be writing for the sake of writing for a while. Attracting an audience neither easy nor a given. If you don't care about your preferred topic, you'll be less inclined to stick it out.</p> \n<h3>Careers and Education</h3> \n<h4>1. Career Advice</h4> \n<p>There's always a market for professional guidance — particularly in uncertain times.</p> \n<h4>2. Learning Employable Skills</h4> \n<p>Job seekers can always use an edge on their competition. If you can offer the insight or resources to give them that leg up, you can find a solid audience.</p> \n<h4>3. Professional Social Media Tips</h4> \n<p>Business owners often look for advice on how to bolster and enhance their presence on social media. If you have some experience in this arena, you can likely find a solid readership.</p> \n<h4>4. Study Hacks</h4> \n<p>There will always be a base of students looking to improve their study-game. If you're particularly savvy when it comes to tips and tricks to boost your grades, consider this niche.</p> \n<h3>Entertainment</h3> \n<h4>5. Acting Tips</h4> \n<p>If you're an experienced actor who can share stories and insight that'll help newbies refine their craft and prepare for auditions, consider giving this niche a shot.</p> \n<h4>6. Card and Board Games</h4> \n<p>There's a lot of material to draw from card and board games. It's a fun niche with an active base.</p> \n<h4>7. Concert Reviews</h4> \n<p>This niche is particularly fun and active. If you can reliably make it to shows and offer meaningful criticism, look into it.</p> \n<h4>8. Film or TV Reviews</h4> \n<p>There's a sizable audience for an aficionado who can dish out some compelling opinions about new movies or TV shows. If you're an outspoken film connoisseur, try this niche.</p> \n<h4>9. Music Criticism</h4> \n<p>This point is similar to the one above. An articulate music buff can rein in a sizable audience by offering their takes on new albums.</p> \n<h4>10. Stand-Up Comedy Instruction</h4> \n<p>Newer stand-up comics can always use a little (or <em>a lot</em>) of guidance as they're starting out. There's definitely an audience for a comedy veteran to offer some tips, tricks, and anecdotes.</p> \n<h4>11. Video Game Tutorials</h4> \n<p>There's a solid population of gamers looking for walkthroughs and assistance through the trickier parts of certain games. If you're an experienced gamer who can provide that help, look into this niche.</p> \n<h3>Finance</h3> \n<h4>12. Budget Shopping</h4> \n<p>Everyone loves a bargain. If you're a particularly deal-savvy shopper, check this niche out.</p> \n<h4>13. Frugal Living</h4> \n<p>People are always after ways to live a little smarter financially. This niche lets you demonstrate exactly how cost-conscious you are day-to-day.</p> \n<h4>14. Investment</h4> \n<p>Do you have a knack for calling all things Wall Street? If so, consider creating a blog up this alley.</p> \n<h4>15. Personal Finance</h4> \n<p>People will always need to know how to balance a checkbook and do taxes, so there's a good chance you can generate readership by covering those kinds of financial fundamentals.</p> \n<h3>Food and Beverage</h3> \n<h4>16. Coffee</h4> \n<p>Coffee enthusiasts are always looking for information on new blends. There's a market for someone who can offer some astute coffee reviews and bean referrals.</p> \n<h4>17. Craft Beers</h4> \n<p>Similar to coffee, there's an audience that <em>loves</em> craft beer and wants to be pointed towards hot new breweries.</p> \n<h4>18. Exotic Cuisine</h4> \n<p>Big-time foodies are active online. A lot of traffic can come with some interesting culinary exploits and tales of exotic cuisines.</p> \n<h4>19. Kitchen Equipment</h4> \n<p>Consumer electronics and accessories — specifically, those related to cooking — are always a big draw.</p> \n<h4>20. Meal Planning</h4> \n<p>Writing about regimented meal prep can bring in all kinds of readers — from cost-conscious consumers to health nuts.</p> \n<h4>21. Recipes and Cooking Tutorials</h4> \n<p>People are always looking for fresh new ways to prepare meals and snacks. If you have a knack for cooking, you might want to look into this idea.</p> \n<h3>Hobbies</h3> \n<h4>22. Gardening</h4> \n<p>Green thumb readers can always use some tips, tricks, and new plants to incorporate into their gardening repertoire.</p> \n<h4>23. Makeup</h4> \n<p>Makeup tutorials have become a big hit across most social media platforms — a blog that capitalizes on that trend can be lucrative if done right.</p> \n<h4>24. Photography</h4> \n<p>Whether it's a forum to offer tips to aspiring photographers or a place to post your own art, a photography blog can draw a solid crowd.</p> \n<h4>25. Technology</h4> \n<p>Compellingly writing about new and emerging tech can attract a forward-thinking base looking for the next big thing.</p> \n<h4>26. Writing</h4> \n<p>It might be slightly meta, but writing about writing can be a big hit. Many aspiring authors and columnists love a source for new prompts and pointers.</p> \n<h3>Personal Relationships</h3> \n<h4>27. Blending Families</h4> \n<p>It's a touchy, tricky subject to handle, but it's a tough challenge a lot of people face. They stand to gain a lot from some sound advice on the topic.</p> \n<h4>28. Dating</h4> \n<p>Dating can be a minefield, and if you know how to help people navigate it, you can build a sizable, dedicated following.</p> \n<h4>29. Parenting</h4> \n<p>It's arguably the hardest part of life — if you can make it that much easier for people, you'll attract a solid audience.</p> \n<h4>30. Relationship Advice</h4> \n<p>Love ain't always easy. That's why plenty of potential readers are looking for someone who can help them figure it out as they go.</p> \n<h4>31. Weddings</h4> \n<p>Almost everyone looks forward to their big day, but planning a wedding means having a lot of balls in the air. Anyone who can help soon-to-be newlyweds successfully juggle them can find an audience.</p> \n<h3>Politics</h3> \n<h4>32. Current Events</h4> \n<p>In the modern age, people need to stay on top of the news. If you can keep them posted with some eloquence and integrity, you can find readers.</p> \n<h4>33. Ethics</h4> \n<p>We could all use a refresher on basic human decency and morality every now and then. A well-crafted ethics blog can rein in a crowd that wants to do that consistently.</p> \n<h4>34. Political Opinions</h4> \n<p>Do you have some incisive, compelling political takes to offer? There might just be an audience that wants to hear what you have to say.</p> \n<h4>35. Political Satire</h4> \n<p>Sometimes, we need to see the humor in the modern political landscape. If you can tastefully (or not-so-tastefully) find it, there could be some a solid readership for it.</p> \n<h3>Self-Care</h3> \n<h4>36. Meditation</h4> \n<p>There are plenty of readers looking to be a bit more mindful and a lot more centered. A meditation blog can tap into that population.</p> \n<h4>37. Mental Health</h4> \n<p>It's an important topic that is (deservedly) getting a lot more attention nowadays than it has in recent years. If you can offer some meaningful insight on how to improve readers' mental wellbeing, you'll find an audience.</p> \n<h4>38. Self-Care</h4> \n<p>A more general, catch-all self-care blog can register with plenty of potential readers looking to improve every facet of their wellbeing.</p> \n<h4>39. Skincare</h4> \n<p>Skincare is a hot topic. There's a massive crowd looking for the best products and techniques to keep their pores small and skin smooth.</p> \n<h3>Sports and Exercise</h3> \n<h4>40. Extreme Sports</h4> \n<p>Out-there, wilder sports can be <em>extremely</em> entertaining in their own right, and there's always a market for \"extremely entertaining.\"</p> \n<h4>41. Personal Training</h4> \n<p>Hardly anyone can afford a real personal trainer. Posting workouts — no matter how rigorous — can attract an audience composed of everyone from dedicated fitness nuts to out of shape newbies.</p> \n<h4>42. Running</h4> \n<p>Running is one of the most fundamental, popular fitness pursuits. There are plenty of readers who would want to hear about your running exploits and anecdotes.</p> \n<h4>43. Specific Sports</h4> \n<p>Football, baseball, basketball, soccer — sports are a staple of modern life. If you can consistently break news or offer interesting takes on a given sport, you can find a base.</p> \n<h4>44. Weight Loss</h4> \n<p>A lot of people are looking to shed some weight. If you can publish workouts or provide inspiration for weight loss, you can find a fairly dedicated audience.</p> \n<h4>45. Workout Trends</h4> \n<p>People want to stay hip to emerging workout trends, so providing news about and guidance for bold new ways to get can help you wrangle in some readers.</p> \n<h3>Travel</h3> \n<h4>46. Hotel Reviews</h4> \n<p>Whether they're looking to book rooms or just want to live vicariously through your incredible hotel stays, there will always be a base interested in hotel reviews.</p> \n<h4>47. Language Instruction</h4> \n<p>Nesvarbu, ar tai būtų praktiniai, ar asmeniniai tikslai, yra daugybė žmonių, kurie norės išmokti naujų kalbų. That's Lithuanian for, <em>\"Whether it be for practical or personal purposes, there are plenty of people who will want to learn new languages.\"</em></p> \n<h4>48. Travel Stories</h4> \n<p>Travel stories are some of the best ones you can tell. If you have some wild, outlandish exploits to share from your time in Bangkok, Paris, or wherever else, consider maintaining a travel blog.</p> \n<h4>49. Traveling for Work</h4> \n<p>Sometimes, travel is for business — not pleasure. There are plenty of readers interested in learning how to do that right.</p> \n<h4>50. Trip Reviews</h4> \n<p>A lot of people want to know which destinations are worth their time, and they might find a nicely maintained trip review blog entertaining and appealing.</p> \n<p>As you can assume, this list of blog niches isn't exhaustive. There are more than the 50 potential topics I've listed to choose from. If you're looking to start a blog but don't know what to write about, consider your passion and areas of expertise before anything else.</p> \n<p>It comes down to a matter of want. You need to consider both what people will <em>want</em> to hear and what you will <em>want</em> to talk about.</p> \n<p></p> \n<p></p>  \n<img src=\"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&amp;k=14&amp;r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fblog-niche-ideas&amp;bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&amp;bvt=rss\" alt=\"\" width=\"1\" height=\"1\" style=\"min-height:1px!important;width:1px!important;border-width:0!important;margin-top:0!important;margin-bottom:0!important;margin-right:0!important;margin-left:0!important;padding-top:0!important;padding-bottom:0!important;padding-right:0!important;padding-left:0!important; \">","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Wed, 21 Oct 2020 11:00:00 +0000","feedId":54,"bgimg":"","linkMd5":"775e20f39ba30b2c0a33c9e897f9e5d9","bgimgJsdelivr":"","metaImg":"","author":"jfuchs@hubspot.com (Jay Fuchs)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Google%20Drive%20Integration/50%20Lucrative%20Blog%20Niches%20%26%20Finding%20One%20That%20Works%20for%20You.jpeg?width=500&name=50%20Lucrative%20Blog%20Niches%20%26%20Finding%20One%20That%20Works%20for%20You.jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn64@2020_5/2020/10/27/16-53-47-914_9129a6ef4215e41c.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fblog-niche-ideas&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn29@2020_1/2020/10/27/16-54-01-863_207c922cd5c27d97.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1603817624896},{"createdTime":"2020-10-28 00:53:44","updatedTime":"2020-10-28 00:53:44","title":"YouTube Analytics: The 15 Metrics That Actually Matter","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/youtube-analytics","description":"<p>Some marketers might have an unhealthy obsession with metrics -- they track too many of them. Maybe we think we can prove any marketing campaign is producing results if there’s a eye-catching percentage by its name. But, deep down, we all know that some metrics are more revealing than others.</p> \n<p>There are a ton of KPIs that provide minimal insights. Fortunately, though, we created this guide to help you navigate YouTube Analytics and measure the metrics that actually matter. It’ll save you from drowning in the sea of analytics that most marketers only have a lifebuoy in, helping you not only stay afloat, but swim safely to land.</p> \n<p>Read on to learn about the YouTube metrics that actually matter, and how they’ll enhance your video strategy.</p> \n<h2>YouTube Analytics: The 15 Metrics That Actually Matter</h2> \n<h3>1. Watch Time</h3> \n<p>Watch time is the total amount of minutes viewers have spent watching your videos. It’s a key metric because YouTube elevates videos and channels with higher watch times in their search results and recommendations section. YouTube does this because the more watch time a video has, the more engaging their algorithm presumes it is.</p> \n<p>In the watch time report, you can see the amount of watch time your videos have accumulated. You can also rank each of your videos by watch time and group your videos by themes, styles, and lengths to determine your most engaging types of videos.</p> \n<h3>2. Average Percentage Viewed</h3> \n<p>Average percentage viewed is the percent of each video the average viewer watched. It measures your video’s ability to hold viewers’ attention for its entirety. And when YouTube realizes your videos can hold people’s attention, they’ll reward it with higher search and recommendation rankings. You can find this metric in your watch time report.</p> \n<h3>3. Average View Duration</h3> \n<p>Average view duration is the total watch time of your video divided by the total number of video plays, including replays. This metric measures your video’s ability to engage viewers. If your video can’t engage viewers, they’ll bounce from your video quickly, leaving you with an unimpressive average view duration. But if your video can engage viewers, your average view duration and total watch time will increase at the same time, boosting your search and recommendations rankings. You can also find this metric in your watch time report.</p> \n<h3>4. Audience Retention</h3> \n<p>Audience retention shows you the percentage of viewers who watch and leave your video at every single moment of the video. YouTube elevates videos with high audience retention in their search rankings and suggestions because these videos can effectively capture viewers' attention.</p> \n<p>Audience retention can also inform your future video strategy. The most engaging parts of your video could be your next best video topics. And watching your video during steep dips of engagement will tell you what might be boring your viewers, allowing you to scrap those elements from current and future videos.</p> \n<p>In YouTube’s audience retention report, there will be two graphs: the absolute retention curve and relative retention curve. The absolute retention curve shows you how well your videos retain viewers. And the relative retention shows you how well one of your videos retains viewers compared to all other YouTube videos of similar length.</p> \n<img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/pasted%20image%200-15.png\" title=\"YouTube Audience Retention Graph\" width=\"100%\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\"> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\">Image Credit: <a href=\"https://creatoracademy.youtube.com/page/course/analytics-series?hl=en\">YouTube</a></p> \n<h3>5. Re-watches</h3> \n<p>Re-watches are the amount of times viewers re-watch certain parts of your video. If a lot of people are re-watching a specific part of your video, then they’re probably interested in the topic your video is covering during that moment. These topics can be fodder for your future video strategy. You can find this data in the absolute audience retention graph. Re-watches are usually indicated by rising curves in the graph.</p> \n<img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/pasted%20image%200%20(1)-2.png\" title=\"YouTube Re-Watch Graph\" width=\"100%\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\"> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\">Image Credit: <a href=\"https://creatoracademy.youtube.com/page/course/analytics-series?hl=en\">YouTube</a></p> \n<h3>6. Engagement</h3> \n<p>Comments, shares, likes, and dislikes provides marketers with a lot of valuable qualitative data.</p> \n<p>Comments can paint a clear picture of your video’s emotional effect on viewers. Shares can gauge how much viewers value your content and brand -- since <a href=\"https://contently.com/strategist/2018/02/02/brand-needs-conscience/\">people share content that confirms their ideal self-persona</a>, people who share your video are publicly displaying that they trust and support your brand. Likes and dislikes can help you determine what video topics work best with your particular audience. You can find your videos’ engagement metrics in YouTube’s Interactions Report.</p> \n<h3>7. Impressions Click-Through Rate</h3> \n<p>Impressions click-through rate measures your video’s ability to prompt people to watch your video after seeing it on their homepage, recommendation section, or trending section. A high click-through rate means your title was compelling and your video’s topic resonates with a lot of relevant audiences on YouTube.</p> \n<p>A common trend for impression click-through rates is that they usually spike immediately after you release your video -- your subscribers will see the video at the top of their home page and probably click on it. But once your video spreads beyond your core audience, your click-through rate will decline and then stay at a stable rate.</p> \n<p>You can also couple this metric with average percentage viewed and average view duration to see if people actually watch your video after they click on it. A high click-through rate is great, but if people are leaving right at the beginning of your video, your title or thumbnail could be misleading. Preparing viewers for what’s to come is crucial because if your title or thumbnail is inaccurate, they’ll feel deceived and lose trust in your brand.</p> \n<p>A low click-through rate but high engagement could mean that the video has a small yet specific audience that is enamored by the content. Go to the Analytics tab in YouTube Studio to examine this metric.</p> \n<img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/pasted%20image%200%20(2).png\" title=\"YouTube Impressions Click-Through-Rate Table\" width=\"100%\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\"> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\">Image Credit: <a href=\"https://creatoracademy.youtube.com/page/course/analytics-series?hl=en\">YouTube</a></p> \n<h3>8. Card Click-Through-Rate</h3> \n<p>Cards are slide-in panels that encourage people to take a desired action during a video like watch another video, subscribe to a channel, or click through to a different website. Each of your cards’ click-through rate tells you which action your viewers prefer to take while watching your videos. This can help you place the most engaging card in each of your videos, potentially boosting your watch time, subscriber growth, or website traffic.</p> \n<p>Analyzing card click-through rates can also help you uncover the optimal timing, placement, and duration of your cards in future videos. You can find your cards’ click-through rates in the Cards Report.</p> \n<img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/pasted%20image%200%20(3).png\" title=\"YouTube Card Click-Through-Rate Chart\" width=\"100%\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\"> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\">Image Credit: <a href=\"https://creatoracademy.youtube.com/page/course/analytics-series?hl=en\">YouTube</a></p> \n<h3>9. Playlist Engagement</h3> \n<p>Playlists are a great way to organize your videos in a digestible way. It helps your viewers easily consume videos about their favorite topics and prompts them to keep watching, which racks up watch time for your channel.</p> \n<p>You can uncover your playlist engagement by analyzing two metrics in YouTube’s Playlist Report: views per playlist start and average time in playlist. Views per playlist start is the average number of video views your playlists gather, and average time in playlist is the average amount of time that viewers viewed the videos in your playlist. If these two metrics are underperforming, try starting your playlist with videos that have the highest retention rate.</p> \n<h3>10. Unique Viewers</h3> \n<p>Unique viewers is the estimated number of individuals who watch your videos over a certain period of time. This metric really helps you understand the actual size of your audience.</p> \n<p>You can also use this metric to gauge your subscriber’s engagement with your videos. If your unique viewers are lower than your subscriber count, then your subscribers aren’t watching as much of your video as they could be. To get them to be more active, ask them to set up notifications for your new videos. You can find this metric under the Reach Views and Audience tab in YouTube Studio.</p> \n<h3>11. Views Per Unique Viewers</h3> \n<p>Views per unique viewers is the amount of times the average viewer watches your video. This metric tells you if people can’t get enough of your video and keep rewatching it. Video topics with a lot of views per unique viewers could also be your most popular content topics, and if you cover them more, you could generate more views, watch time, and subscribers.</p> \n<img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/pasted%20image%200%20(4).png\" title=\"YouTube Views Per Unique Viewers Graph\" width=\"100%\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\"> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\">Image Credit: <a href=\"https://creatoracademy.youtube.com/page/course/analytics-series?hl=en\">YouTube</a></p> \n<h3>12. Who’s Watching Your Videos</h3> \n<p>In YouTube’s demographics report, you can see the different types of people who watch your videos, segmented by age, gender, and geography. This data tells you who your most engaged audience is and who your target audience should actually be. You can take the opposite approach with this data too. If you’re not reaching the audience you want, try pivoting your video strategy and cover topics that would attract them.</p> \n<img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/pasted%20image%200%20(5).png\" title=\"YouTube Views Per Unique Viewers Graph\" width=\"100%\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\"> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\">Image Credit: <a href=\"https://creatoracademy.youtube.com/page/course/analytics-series?hl=en\">YouTube</a></p> \n<h3>13. Subscriber Growth</h3> \n<p>Subscribers are your most loyal fans. They’ve made a public commitment to your brand, content, and values. And they’re most likely to be your evangelists too. Subscribers are also important to your channel because YouTube will send them notifications about your new videos and feature them on their homepage. This means they’ll see your videos more frequently, which’ll help generate more views. <a href=\"https://creatoracademy.youtube.com/page/lesson/discoverability-analytics?cid=analytics-series&amp;hl=en#strategies-zippy-link-3\">Subscribers also watch twice as much video than non-subscribers</a>, so the more subscribers you have, the more watch time your videos will collect.</p> \n<p>YouTube’s Subscribers Report will show you which videos, locations, and time periods gain and lose subscribers. This data will tell you what video topics resonate with your subscribers and where to target new subscribers. And by prioritizing your subscribers’ needs, you’ll create videos that they crave, increase your watch time, and boost your search rankings.</p> \n<h3>14. Traffic Sources</h3> \n<p>External referrals like social media or sites that embed your videos and YouTube referrals like search, the recommended section, and the homepage are all traffic sources. The Traffic Sources report shows you how viewers found your videos and what sources rack up the most views and watch time. You can use this data to better optimize your video promotion strategy.</p> \n<img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/pasted%20image%200%20(6).png\" title=\"YouTube Views Per Unique Viewers Graph\" width=\"100%\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\"> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\">Image Credit: <a href=\"https://creatoracademy.youtube.com/page/course/analytics-series?hl=en\">YouTube</a></p> \n<h3>15. Keywords</h3> \n<p>In YouTube’s Search Report, which is under the Traffic Sources Report, you can see the most popular queries guiding viewers to your videos. If these queries are slightly different than your video’s topic, consider updating your video to fill these content gaps and add the keywords to your metadata. If there’s a stark difference, consider making a new video about these popular queries.</p> \n<p><em>Editor's note: This post was originally published in July 2018 and has been updated for comprehensiveness.</em></p> \n<p></p> \n<div>\n <a class=\"close\">&nbsp;</a>\n</div>  \n<img Chi)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/pasted%20image%200-15.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn48@2020_4/2020/10/27/16-53-49-721_dcbc6dd8b3184230.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/pasted%20image%200%20(1)-2.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn35@2020_4/2020/10/27/16-53-47-885_b69e69664dfe2dbd.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/pasted%20image%200%20(2).png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn95@2020_5/2020/10/27/16-53-51-434_bebc3b138f3c65df.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/pasted%20image%200%20(3).png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn99@2020_4/2020/10/27/16-54-13-391_a64f5b3da6f304fc.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/pasted%20image%200%20(4).png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn55@2020_2/2020/10/27/16-53-52-212_cab7bf787842e643.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/pasted%20image%200%20(5).png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn98@2020_3/2020/10/27/16-54-04-702_5a62107cb65fa8f0.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/pasted%20image%200%20(6).png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn35@2020_3/2020/10/27/16-54-03-762_d51b014eef3f2f0e.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fyoutube-analytics&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":null},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1603817624923},{"createdTime":"2020-10-28 00:53:44","updatedTime":"2020-10-28 00:53:44","title":"11 of the Best Free Google Sheets Templates for 2020","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/google-sheets-templates","description":"<p>Whether your marketing position requires you to send invoices to clients, track website analytics, or create budget and expense reports, you’ve undoubtedly found yourself working with spreadsheets in some form.</p> \n<p>And if you’re anything like me, those spreadsheets can feel frustratingly tedious when you’re under a time crunch.</p> \n<p>Fortunately, Google Sheets offers 26 pre-built templates, allowing you to create reports and analyze data in spreadsheets faster and more effectively.</p> \n<p>Best of all, Google Sheets templates cater to specific categories -- if you click the Paid Traffic Report template, for instance, your spreadsheet is already organized into Overview, 12-month Trends, and Medium Breakdown categories. It knows what you need, and offers it without any manual input.</p> \n<p>Here, we'll delve into 11 of the best free Google Sheets Templates for any marketing role in 2018, so you can create better spreadsheets while saving valuable time to focus on more important things -- like the data itself.</p> \n<p></p> \n<p><em>To find these templates in your Google Sheets, go to your email and click Sheets in the drop-down menu.</em></p> \n<p><em>Then, click the up and down arrow beside Template Gallery. This will show you all your template options.&nbsp;</em></p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/google-sheets-1.jpg\"></p> \n<h2><strong>Google Sheets Templates for Finances</strong></h2> \n<h3>1. Invoices</h3> \n<p>If you’re a freelancer or work for a small business, you probably use invoices to bill clients for services. This invoice template makes the process simple -- it provides space for all the necessary information, and looks more professional than a plain spreadsheet. Plus, the template is customizable, so you can create a theme that aligns well with your brand image.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Screen%20Shot%202018-06-05%20at%201.12.12%20PM.png?width=910&amp;name=Screen%20Shot%202018-06-05%20at%201.12.12%20PM.png\" alt=\"Screen Shot 2018-06-05 at 1.12.12 PM\" width=\"910\" style=\"width: 910px;\"></p> \n<h3>2. Annual Business Budget</h3> \n<p>This template is more in-depth than it initially appears. There are tabs at the bottom -- setup, income, expenses, summary -- and each one includes a number of subcategories. “Expenses”, for instance, covers everything from taxes and insurance, to travel and customer acquisition. The final tab, \"summary\", takes your income, subtracts your expenses, and automatically updates to display your ending balance each month. This template is a good option if your budget requires a lot of customization and has a lot of moving parts.</p> \n<div>\n <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/11%20of%20the%20Best%20Free%20Google%20Sheets%20Templates%20for%202019-9.png\" alt=\"\">\n</div> \n<h3>3. Financial Statements</h3> \n<p>The financial statements template truly is an all-in-one resource to keep track of business transactions, profits, and losses. The “profit &amp; loss” tab automatically summarizes revenue, costs, and expenses for the year, and can display your growth rate percentage. If you work for a small business and need to manage much of your own finances, this template offers resources and guidance to make the process easier, and less prone to human error.</p> \n<div>\n <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/11%20of%20the%20Best%20Free%20Google%20Sheets%20Templates%20for%202019-1.png\" alt=\"\">\n</div> \n<h2><strong>Google Sheet Templates for Reporting and Analytics</strong></h2> \n<h3>4. Website Traffic Dashboard</h3> \n<p><span>If your role requires you to analyze website traffic using Google Analytics, this template is a fantastic supplemental tool to pull that data into an organized report, saving you tons of time. Better still, you can use the template with Supermetrics Google Sheets add-on to monitor and analyze data from PPC, SEO, social media, and website analytics.</span></p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/11%20of%20the%20Best%20Free%20Google%20Sheets%20Templates%20for%202019-6.png\" alt=\"\"></p> \n<h3>5. Website Paid Traffic Report</h3> \n<p>This template makes the process of analyzing and reporting on paid traffic relatively seamless. It automatically collects data on your paid sources from Google Analytics, and provides a clean chart with important information, including PPC’s percentage of goal conversions, total traffic, and bounce rate. You can also adjust it to compare different time periods, or different channels or segments. If you’re looking for a way to demonstrate paid’s influence on your business, this is the tool to do it.</p> \n<div>\n <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/11%20of%20the%20Best%20Free%20Google%20Sheets%20Templates%20for%202019-2.png\" alt=\"\">\n</div> \n<h2><strong>Google Sheet Templates for Customers</strong></h2> \n<h3>6. CRM</h3> \n<p>To organize your contacts and automate an effective sales and <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/products/marketing\">marketing process</a>, it’s important you have a CRM -- but if you’re a small company just starting out, you might not feel ready to implement a fully-established CRM with all the features. This CRM template is a great place to get your feet wet. It saves automatically so you never lose data, and the share feature allows you to work with coworkers within the CRM, which is helpful for encouraging collaboration between your sales and marketing departments.</p> \n<div>\n <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/11%20of%20the%20Best%20Free%20Google%20Sheets%20Templates%20for%202019-5.png\" alt=\"\">\n</div> \n<h2><strong>Google Sheet Templates for Project Management</strong></h2> \n<h3>7. Project Timeline</h3> \n<p><span>Whether this is your first major project or you’ve been managing projects for years, the project timeline template is a useful tool for organizing and implementing each project step. The template helps you visually break-up a daunting project into smaller pieces, ideally making it easier and less stressful to organize and delegate tasks.</span></p> \n<p><span><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/11%20of%20the%20Best%20Free%20Google%20Sheets%20Templates%20for%202019.png\" alt=\"\"></span></p> \n<h3>8. Project Tracking</h3> \n<p>If you’re juggling a bunch of projects simultaneously, this project tracking template could become your new best friend. It enables you to organize your projects into categories by date, deliverables, status, cost, and hours -- best of all, it lets you prioritize your projects. Hopefully, simply visualizing what needs to get done first will alleviate time-management stress.</p> \n<p><span><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/11%20of%20the%20Best%20Free%20Google%20Sheets%20Templates%20for%202019-3.png\" alt=\"\"></span></p> \n<h3>9. Event Marketing Timeline</h3> \n<p><span>The event marketing template offers organization and structure if you’re implementing an upcoming business event or campaign. It offers categories you might’ve forgotten to consider, including local and national marketing, PR, and web, with subcategories ranging from email newsletter to impact studies. The template is already organized with all necessary categories for planning an event, reducing the time you spend on tedious manual input.</span></p> \n<p><span><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/11%20of%20the%20Best%20Free%20Google%20Sheets%20Templates%20for%202019-7.png\" alt=\"\"></span></p> \n<h3>10. Gantt Chart Template</h3> \n<p>The <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/business-templates/gantt-chart\">Gantt chart template</a> helps you alleviate any concern you might have over timing -- and, when you’ve got a complex project with overlapping components, I’m willing to bet timing is one of your major concerns. Using the Gantt chart template helps you visualize all steps and delegate important tasks more efficiently -- labelling the task with an owner on one chart is certainly easier than individually following up via email, and by sharing the template with coworkers, everyone is on the same page.</p> \n<div>\n <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/11%20of%20the%20Best%20Free%20Google%20Sheets%20Templates%20for%202019-8.png\" alt=\"\">\n</div> \n<h2><strong>Google Sheet Templates for Leading a Team</strong></h2> \n<h3>11. Employee Shift Schedule</h3> \n<p>Keeping track of who works what hours, and how much each employee gets paid, can feel confusing, especially if you lead a team of part-time contractors or seasonal interns. This template includes slots for employee’s names, hours worked, and monthly wages, making your paycheck process straightforward and organized.</p> \n<div>\n <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/11%20of%20the%20Best%20Free%20Google%20Sheets%20Templates%20for%202019-4.png\" alt=\"\">\n</div> \n<div></div> \n<div></div>  \n<img
