%20for%202019-7.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn5@2020_6/2020/10/27/16-53-47-831_9815bb8239d2ac67.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/11%20of%20the%20Best%20Free%20Google%20Sheets%20Templates%20for%202019-8.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn95@2020_4/2020/10/27/16-53-47-930_6a8a159a45f70930.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/11%20of%20the%20Best%20Free%20Google%20Sheets%20Templates%20for%202019-4.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn57@2020_2/2020/10/27/16-53-55-052_46dfb8f7a6a00ca4.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fgoogle-sheets-templates&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn93@2020_2/2020/10/27/16-53-55-500_8f00735ebaa171f3.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1603817624896},{"createdTime":"2020-10-28 00:53:44","updatedTime":"2020-10-28 00:53:44","title":"How to Use Photoshop: The Bookmarkable Photoshop Tutorial for Beginners","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/how-to-use-photoshop","description":"<p><span style=\"letter-spacing: 0px; background-color: transparent;\">When you open Adobe Photoshop for the first time, it's easy to click around in confusion for a minute and then reach for your freelancer's phone number instead. Trust us, you're not alone in this. </span></p> \n<p><span class=\"content-post__body\"><span class=\"content-post__body\"><span> It's an incredibly powerful design software with a lot going on, including a wealth of tools that can seem overwhelming at times. </span></span></span>But Photoshop isn't just for the professionals.</p> \n<p>With a little help, you can easily teach yourself how to use it to create beautiful, compelling graphics. <span style=\"background-color: transparent;\">All it takes is an introduction to core elements -- in plain English.</span></p> \n<p><span class=\"content-post__body\"><span class=\"content-post__body\">To get you started, we've picked 12 of the most useful tools in Photoshop and explained what they do, where to find them, how to use them, and a few tips and tricks for getting the most out of them. We've also included some great resources in there in case you'd like to learn about a tool in more depth.</span></span></p> \n<div class=\"hsg-featured-snippet\"> \n <h2>How to Use Photoshop</h2> \n <ol> \n  <li>The Layer Tool</li> \n  <li>The Color &amp; Swatches Tool</li> \n  <li>Custom Fonts &amp; The Text Tool</li> \n  <li>Custom Brushes &amp; The Brush Tool</li> \n  <li>The Select Tool</li> \n  <li>The Move Tool</li> \n  <li>The Zoom Tool</li> \n  <li>The Eraser</li> \n  <li>The Crop Tool</li> \n  <li>The Fill Tool</li> \n  <li>The Eyedropper Tool</li> \n  <li>Blending Options</li> \n </ol> \n</div> \n<h3>1. The Layer Tool<strong><br></strong></h3> \n<p><strong>What It Does:</strong> A layer can be used for an image, text, brush strokes, background colors, patterns, and filters.</p> \n<p>I like to think of layers as sheets of glass stacked on top of one another that you'll use to create a final product. Each sheet can be modified individually without affecting the project as a whole, which can save you tons of time when making edits to individual elements of your graphic.</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/photoshop-layers.png?width=400&amp;height=250&amp;name=photoshop-layers.png\" alt=\"photoshop-layers.png\" title=\"photoshop-layers.png\" width=\"400\" height=\"250\"></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><span style=\"font-size: 12px;\"><em>Image Credit: <a href=\"http://graphicdesign.stackexchange.com/questions/27507/how-can-i-create-and-batch-this-3d-planes-effect\">StackExchange</a></em></span></p> \n<p>Layers are by far the most important element of Photoshop -- and, in my opinion, they're one of the reasons many people throw their arms up in frustration. But once you understand how they work, I promise they'll make your life much easier.</p> \n<p><strong>Where It's Located:</strong> It has its own module on the bottom right-hand corner of your Photoshop screen, by default. You can also access it by clicking \"Layer\" in the top menu bar.</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/photoshop-layers-1.png?width=563&amp;height=435&amp;name=photoshop-layers-1.png\" alt=\"photoshop-layers-1.png\" title=\"photoshop-layers-1.png\" width=\"563\" height=\"435\"></p> \n<p><span class=\"content-post__body\"><strong>Pro Tip:</strong><span> <em>Always</em> name your layers. Keeping them organized will help keep you sane, especially if you find yourself working on a project with a large number of layers. </span></span></p> \n<h4>To add or delete a layer:</h4> \n<p>From the top menu bar, choose Layer &gt; New &gt; Layer...</p> \n<h4>To select a layer:</h4> \n<p>The selected layer is highlighted in blue. To edit a specific part of your image, you'll need to select that specific layer.</p> \n<p>You'll also notice there's an \"eye\" symbol next to each layer: Click that symbol to turn the eye on and off, thereby toggling the visibility of that layer as you work.</p> \n<h4>To duplicate a layer:</h4> \n<p>First, select a layer or group in the Layers panel. Next, either drag the layer or group to the Create a New Layer button, or right-click the layer to choose \"Duplicate Layer\" or \"Duplicate Group.\" Enter a name for the layer or group, and click OK.</p> \n<div class=\"hs-migrated-cms-post\"> \n <p><span class=\"content-post__body\"><strong>Pro Tip:</strong> You can do all sorts of cool things with layers -- and believe it or not, making animated GIFs is one of them. </span><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/how-to-create-animated-gif-quick-tip-ht\">Check out our step-by-step tutorial here</a>.</p> \n <p>To learn more about adding, deleting, and duplicating layers in Photoshop, <a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=nhxj4goGtj0\">check out this video tutorial</a>.</p> \n <h3>2. The Color &amp; Swatches Tool<strong><br></strong></h3> \n <p><strong>What It Does:</strong> The Color and Swatches tool lets you use, modify, copy, and save custom colors for your content. While this may seem like a pretty self-explanatory element, it actually has powerful features that will keep your visual content vibrant and unify your color schemes.</p> \n <p><strong>Where It's Located:</strong> It has its own module on the top right-hand corner of your Photoshop screen, by default.</p> \n <p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/photoshop-color-tool.png?width=532&amp;height=318&amp;name=photoshop-color-tool.png\" alt=\"photoshop-color-tool.png\" title=\"photoshop-color-tool.png\" width=\"532\" height=\"318\"></p> \n <p style=\"text-align: left;\">Another place to find the Color tool is at the bottom of the toolbar on the left, indicated by two overlapping boxes:</p> \n <p style=\"text-align: center;\"><span class=\"content-post__\"><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/photoshop-color-boxes.png?width=235&amp;height=236&amp;name=photoshop-color-boxes.png\" alt=\"photoshop-color-boxes.png\" title=\"photoshop-color-boxes.png\" width=\"235\" height=\"236\"></span></p> \n <h4>To create your own custom color:</h4> \n <p>Open the Color Picker by double-clicking on the top box either in the Color module, or in that menu on the left.</p> \n <p><span class=\"content-post__\">From there, you'll see a vertical spectrum of color with a slider on it, which you can adjust to create your own custom color. Alternatively, if you already have a specific color of which you know the <span>hex value</span> (i.e. #1fb1ee), then enter it in the appropriate box to find that color automatically. <span>You can also select your color swatch based on RGB or CMYK values.</span></span></p> \n <p style=\"text-align: center;\"><span class=\"content-post__\"><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/photoshop-color-picker.png?width=546&amp;height=394&amp;name=photoshop-color-picker.png\" alt=\"photoshop-color-picker.png\" title=\"photoshop-color-picker.png\" width=\"546\" height=\"394\"></span></p> \n <p>Any colors you create can be added to your \"Swatches\" if you click \"Add To Swatches.\"</p> \n <p><strong>Pro Tip: </strong>Take your company colors and save them as “Swatches” so that you can reference and reuse them whenever you’re designing your visual content.</p> \n <h3>3. Custom Fonts &amp; The Text Tool<strong><br></strong></h3> \n <p><strong>What It Does:</strong> The Text tool lets you add custom fonts to your database, and it gives you access to advanced font settings that give your text some serious style.</p> \n <p><strong>Where It's Located: </strong>The toolbar on your left, near the bottom.</p> \n <p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/photoshop-text-tool.png?width=431&amp;height=284&amp;name=photoshop-text-tool.png\" alt=\"photoshop-text-tool.png\" title=\"photoshop-text-tool.png\" width=\"431\" height=\"284\"></p> \n <p>Once you click the Text tool icon, all of the settings and font options will pop up at the top of your screen. These settings let you change the font, font size, and spacing between characters, height, width, color, and style. Be sure to select the layer of your desired text to edit it.</p> \n <p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/photoshop-text-tool-options.png?width=669&amp;height=267&amp;name=photoshop-text-tool-options.png\" alt=\"photoshop-text-tool-options.png\" title=\"photoshop-text-tool-options.png\" width=\"669\" height=\"267\"></p> \n <h4>To add text to your graphic:</h4> \n <p>The text tool works like any other text tool you’ve used. Click the \"T\" icon on the left side bar, drag the text box over any particular area you want text to appear, and you’re set to go.</p> \n <p><strong>Whenever you create a text box, Photoshop will generate a layer for it.</strong> You can choose the color, size, stroke, font style, and a variety of other options to switch things up.</p> \n <p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/photoshop-editing-text.png?width=669&amp;height=427&amp;name=photoshop-editing-text.png\" alt=\"photoshop-editing-text.png\" title=\"photoshop-editing-text.png\" width=\"669\" height=\"427\"></p> \n <p><strong>Pro Tip: </strong>While Photoshop offers a wide variety of fonts, you can also install your own fonts. <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/28-free-fonts-beautify-content\">Read this blog post for a list of 35 beautiful fonts</a> you can download for free, and then <a href=\"http://www.adobe.com/products/type/install-instructions.html\">read this post</a> to learn how to install your new fonts in Photoshop so you can get to using 'em.</p> \n <p>To learn more about fonts and the Text tool, <a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=018lVE-Afm0\">check out this video tutorial</a>.</p> \n <h3>4. Custom Brushes &amp; The Brush Tool<strong><br></strong></h3> \n <p><strong>What It Does:</strong> Just as with fonts, you can add your own, royalty-free, custom brush tips. With the brush settings, you can change the size, shape, and transparency of your brush strokes to achieve a number of different visual effects.</p> \n <p>Brushes are a great way to add some visual accents to your content. Photoshop starts you off with a nice selection of brush tips that you can use to clean up your graphics and create some basic visual effects.</p> \n <p><strong>Where It's Located:</strong> The toolbar on the left.</p> \n <p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/photoshop-brush-tool.png?width=458&amp;height=322&amp;name=photoshop-brush-tool.png\" alt=\"photoshop-brush-tool.png\" title=\"photoshop-brush-tool.png\" width=\"458\" height=\"322\"></p> \n <p>Once you click the Brush tool icon, all of the settings and brush options will pop up at the top of your screen. These settings let you change the brush size, opacity, flow, and so on. You'll find a variety of pre-installed brush tips, as well as any custom brush tips you install to Photoshop. (You can find royalty-free brushes at <a href=\"http://www.brusheezy.com\">www.brusheezy.com</a> if you want to get really creative.)</p> \n <p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/photoshop-brush-settings.png?width=669&amp;height=298&amp;name=photoshop-brush-settings.png\" alt=\"photoshop-brush-settings.png\" title=\"photoshop-brush-settings.png\" width=\"669\" height=\"298\"></p> \n <h4>To use the brush tool:</h4> \n <p>The brush tool is perfect for adding design accents to your content content. When using the brush tool, I always suggest adding a new layer to work with so you don’t paint over any of your other elements. You can choose colors from your library of swatches, or use a custom color.</p> \n <p>Changing the brush settings can give your brush a drastically different look and style. Don’t be afraid to play around a bit with all of your custom brushes.</p> \n <h3>5. The Select Tool<strong><br></strong></h3> \n <p><strong>What It Is: </strong>When used correctly, this tool will let you select individual elements, entire graphics, and determines what is copied, cut, and pasted into your graphics.</p> \n <p><strong>Where It's Located:</strong> The toolbar on the left.</p> \n <p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/select-tool.png?width=320&amp;height=302&amp;name=select-tool.png\" alt=\"select-tool.png\" title=\"select-tool.png\" width=\"320\" height=\"302\"></p> \n <p>The Select tool is known as one of the most basic, yet frustrating tools to use in Photoshop. The first thing you should know is that it'll only work if a layer is highlighted. So, if I want to cut or copy a piece of Layer 4, Layer 4 must be highlighted in my Layer's tool bar. Highlighted areas are indicated by a flashing dotted line.</p> \n <p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/photoshop-select-dotted-line.png?width=547&amp;height=419&amp;name=photoshop-select-dotted-line.png\" alt=\"photoshop-select-dotted-line.png\" title=\"photoshop-select-dotted-line.png\" width=\"547\" height=\"419\"></p> \n <p>Once you remember to pay attention to which layer you are working with, the Select tool becomes <em>much</em> easier to use.</p> \n <p>First, highlight your area of choice. Then, simply right-click and decide what you'd like to do from the pull-out menu. For example, you can cut out objects from a current layer and create a layer of your own.</p> \n <p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/photoshop-select-menu.png?width=669&amp;height=444&amp;name=photoshop-select-menu.png\" alt=\"photoshop-select-menu.png\" title=\"photoshop-select-menu.png\" width=\"669\" height=\"444\"></p> \n <h4>How to select an image to insert into your graphic:</h4> \n <p>Open the image you'd like to use in Photoshop, and use the Select Tool to determine how much of the image you want to copy. Once you’ve selected the area of the image, simply copy the area.</p> \n <p>Next, open the tab for your current project and paste it in as a new layer. Highlight the layer of the object(s) you'd like to select. You can move multiple objects at once by highlighting multiple layers.</p> \n <p>Then, right-click your selection, and then you have a few options, including:</p> \n <p style=\"padding-left: 30px;\"><strong>A)</strong> Choosing \"Layer via Copy\" to copy the object(s) from this layer and create a layer of its own.</p> \n <p><span class=\"content-post__body\"><span class=\"content-post__body\"><strong>Pro Tip: </strong><span>To select your entire graphic and include all layers, highlight all layers and then use the Select tool. Once you've determined the area to copy, use the menu bar at the top and click \"Edit\" &gt; \"Copy Merged.\" This will copy the entire graphic so you can paste it as its own layer.</span></span></span></p> \n <p style=\"padding-left: 30px;\"><strong><span class=\"content-post__body\"><span class=\"content-post__body\"><span class=\"content-post__body\">B) </span></span></span></strong>Choosing \"Free Transform\" to scale, rotate, move, and flip your selections. (Refer to the Move tool in the next section of this post if you need more help on this.)</p> \n <p><span class=\"content-post__body\"><strong>Pro Tip:</strong> One really nifty trick you can do with \"Free Transform\" is to overlay </span>screenshots of a PDF to make a 3D-looking image, like the one below for our <a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/how-to-use-pinterest-for-business\">introductory Pinterest ebook</a>. You can find a visual overview of the steps below, but <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/get-started-with-photoshop-ht\">read this blog post for the step-by-step tutorial</a>.</p> \n <p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/customize-photoshop-image.png?width=621&amp;height=345&amp;name=customize-photoshop-image.png\" alt=\"customize-photoshop-image.png\" title=\"customize-photoshop-image.png\" width=\"621\" height=\"345\"></p> \n <p>To learn more about all the Selection tools available in Photoshop, <a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=14Jj-nGubf0\">check out this video tutorial</a>.</p> \n <h3>6. The Move Tool<strong><br></strong></h3> \n <p><strong>What It Does:</strong> This is a fairly basic tool that allows you to move individual elements of your graphic.</p> \n <p>The Move tool works on individual layers, and on the graphic as a whole -- if (remember how to do this?) you highlight all of your layers. It comes in handy when you’re trying to reposition images, text, and other design elements.</p> \n <p><strong>Where It's Located:</strong> The toolbar on the left, at the top.</p> \n <p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/photoshop-move-tool.png?width=359&amp;height=292&amp;name=photoshop-move-tool.png\" alt=\"photoshop-move-tool.png\" title=\"photoshop-move-tool.png\" width=\"359\" height=\"292\"></p> \n <h4>To use the Move tool:</h4> \n <p>Click the Move Icon from the left hand menu bar and simply drag the object(s) you would like to move. To move all objects in one layer, simply highlight the layer and use the Move tool. You can also right click the object for additional options.</p> \n <h4>To scale, rotate, move, and flip things:</h4> \n <p>The Free Transform tool lets you scale, rotate, move, and flip any element in your select layer or layers. Use the shortcut <strong>CTRL + T</strong> or <strong>Command + T</strong> (for Macs) to initiate Free Transform, and check out the options that pop up at the top of your screen. Hold the <strong>SHIFT</strong> key while transforming to maintain the proportions of your elements.</p> \n <p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/photoshop-free-transform.png?width=669&amp;height=401&amp;name=photoshop-free-transform.png\" alt=\"photoshop-free-transform.png\" title=\"photoshop-free-transform.png\" width=\"669\" height=\"401\"></p> \n <h3>7. The Zoom Tool<strong><br></strong></h3> \n <p><strong>What It Does:</strong> The Zoom tool lets you zoom in close to certain areas of an image, and zoom out to get more of a bird's eye view of what's happening.</p> \n <p><strong>Where It's Located:</strong> In the top menu bar, choose <strong>View</strong> &gt; <strong>Zoom In</strong> or <strong>View</strong> &gt; <strong>Zoom Out.</strong></p> \n <p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/photoshop-zoom-tool.png?width=669&amp;height=316&amp;name=photoshop-zoom-tool.png\" alt=\"photoshop-zoom-tool.png\" title=\"photoshop-zoom-tool.png\" width=\"669\" height=\"316\"></p> \n <h4>To use the Zoom tool:</h4> \n <p>Either select the zoom options from the \"View\" menu (as shown above). To use the keyboard shortcut, hold <strong>ALT</strong> (PC) or <strong>Command </strong>(Mac) and press + to zoom in, and <strong>ALT</strong> (PC) or<strong> Command </strong>(Mac) and press - to zoom out.</p> \n <h3>8. The Eraser<strong><br></strong></h3> \n <p><strong>What It Does: </strong>The Basic Eraser functions a lot like the brush tool. You can change the size and hardness of the eraser tip to achieve a variety of effects, like blending and fades. The Background Eraser uses differences in color to help you erase unwanted background areas from your images.</p> \n <p>The eraser is one of the most useful tools in Photoshop. Yes, I understand it’s technically just an eraser, but you’ve never used an eraser like this.</p> \n <p><strong>Where It's Located:</strong> The toolbar on the left.</p> \n <p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/photoshop-eraser.png\" alt=\"photoshop-eraser.png\" title=\"photoshop-eraser.png\"></p> \n <h4>To use the Basic Eraser:</h4> \n <p>Once you click the Eraser icon, all of the settings will pop up at the top of your screen. These settings let you change the eraser size, hardness, and other aspects of the tool.</p> \n <p>Like most tools in Photoshop, the eraser works only on a specifically selected layer. Make sure you've got the layer you want selected before you start erasing.</p> \n <p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/photoshop-eraser-options.png?width=621&amp;height=374&amp;name=photoshop-eraser-options.png\" alt=\"photoshop-eraser-options.png\" title=\"photoshop-eraser-options.png\" width=\"621\" height=\"374\"></p> \n <h4>To use the Background Eraser:</h4> \n <p>This tool is a time-saving wonder. You can see how easily it eliminates background colors from images. This is especially helpful if you need an object with a transparent background.</p> \n <p>To use the Background Eraser, click and hold the eraser icon until the slide out menu appears. Choose \"Background Eraser.\"</p> \n <p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/photoshop-background-eraser.png?width=224&amp;height=107&amp;name=photoshop-background-eraser.png\" alt=\"photoshop-background-eraser.png\" title=\"photoshop-background-eraser.png\" width=\"224\" height=\"107\"></p> \n <p>Now you're ready to do some serious erasing. Adjust the size of the Background Eraser, and simply click the color you would like deleted from the selected layer. Remember to select the layer you want to erase on.</p> \n <p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/photoshop-background-eraser-example.png?width=669&amp;height=428&amp;name=photoshop-background-eraser-example.png\" alt=\"photoshop-background-eraser-example.png\" title=\"photoshop-background-eraser-example.png\" width=\"669\" height=\"428\"></p> \n <p><strong>Pro Tip: </strong>Don’t be afraid to use an oversized eraser tip for the Background Eraser. Since it works by removing particular colors from the image, it won’t erase colors that aren’t selected.</p> \n <p>To learn more about how to remove the background of a photo in Photoshop or PowerPoint, <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/how-to-remove-background-image-in-powerpoint-design-ht\">check out this step-by-step tutorial</a>.</p> \n <h3>9. The Crop Tool<strong><br></strong></h3> \n <p><strong>What It Does: </strong>The Crop tool lets you crop an image. It works like any crop tool you’ve ever encountered: Simply choose your area and crop it out.</p> \n <p>I know this is a basic tool, but you’ll find yourself using this just as often as any other tool in Photoshop, especially when you’ve completed your graphic and need to clean up some of the free space around the edges.</p> \n <p><strong>Where It's Located:</strong> The toolbar on the left.</p> \n <p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/photoshop-crop-tool.png?width=240&amp;height=319&amp;name=photoshop-crop-tool.png\" alt=\"photoshop-crop-tool.png\" title=\"photoshop-crop-tool.png\" width=\"240\" height=\"319\"></p> \n <h4>To use the Crop tool:</h4> \n <p>Select the icon indicated in the screenshot from the side menu bar, and drag the box over the area you would like to crop. To adjust the crop box, simply click and drag the small anchor boxes on the sides and corners of the crop box.</p> \n <p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/photoshop-crop-tool-example.png?width=669&amp;height=357&amp;name=photoshop-crop-tool-example.png\" alt=\"photoshop-crop-tool-example.png\" title=\"photoshop-crop-tool-example.png\" width=\"669\" height=\"357\"></p> \n <p><strong>Pro Tip: </strong>You can make your canvas size larger than it needs to be so that you can give yourself more room to move your design elements, and crop it down to the proper size afterwards.</p> \n <p><a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/crop-images-in-photoshop-to-specific-ratios-ht\">Read this blog post</a> to learn how to crop images in Photoshop to a specific ratio. If you want to learn some cropping tricks -- like how to rotate an image using the Crop tool -- then <a href=\"http://digital-photography-school.com/5-secrets-of-the-photoshop-crop-tool/\">check out this article from Digital Photography School</a>.</p> \n <h3>10. The Fill Tool</h3> \n <p><strong>What It Does: </strong>The Fill tool, formerly the Paint Bucket tool, fills any solid area with the color of your choice. It's great for solid backgrounds or coloring large areas. It can also be used to apply patterns to your images. The Gradient tool within the Fill tool lets you create a nice, faded background effect of the color of your choice.</p> \n <p><strong>Where It's Located:</strong> On the top menu bar, choose <strong>Layer</strong> &gt; <strong>New Fill Layer.</strong> From there, you have the option to choose \"Solid Color,\" \"Gradient,\" or \"Pattern.\"</p> \n <p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/photoshop-fill-tool.png?width=620&amp;height=291&amp;name=photoshop-fill-tool.png\" alt=\"photoshop-fill-tool.png\" title=\"photoshop-fill-tool.png\" width=\"620\" height=\"291\"></p> \n <h4>To fill a solid area with a color:</h4> \n <p>First, select the layer you'd like to fill with a solid color. Then, from the top menu bar, choose <strong>Layer</strong> &gt; <strong>New Fill Layer</strong> &gt; <strong>Solid Color... </strong>From there, a \"New Layer\" window will pop up and prompt you to name the new color fill layer. Don't worry about choosing the color you want right then and there -- simply name the layer and press \"OK.\"</p> \n <p style=\"text-align: center;\">&nbsp;</p> \n <p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/photoshop-solid-color-fill.png?width=438&amp;height=150&amp;name=photoshop-solid-color-fill.png\" alt=\"photoshop-solid-color-fill.png\" title=\"photoshop-solid-color-fill.png\" width=\"438\" height=\"150\"></p> \n <p>Next, the Color Picker window will pop up. Here, you can choose which solid color you'd like to fill. Since I'd selected my background layer to fill in (i.e. the color of the sky in my graphic), the color I select in the Color Picker dictates the color of the sky:</p> \n <p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/photoshop-color-picker-fill.png?width=669&amp;height=516&amp;name=photoshop-color-picker-fill.png\" alt=\"photoshop-color-picker-fill.png\" title=\"photoshop-color-picker-fill.png\" width=\"669\" height=\"516\"></p> \n <h4>To apply patterns to your images:</h4> \n <p>These patterns can be manually created if you have the time and patience, or you can find a variety of royalty-free patterns available for download through a basic Google search.</p> \n <p>To apply a pattern, first select the layer you'd like to fill with a pattern. Then, from the top menu bar, choose <strong>Layer</strong> &gt; <strong>New Fill Layer</strong> &gt; <strong>Pattern.</strong><strong>.. </strong>From there, a \"New Layer\" window will pop up and prompt you to name the new color fill layer. Don't worry about choosing the color you want right then and there -- simply name the layer and press \"OK.\"</p> \n <p>Next, you'll see the \"Pattern Fill\" window pop up. From there, you can choose the pattern and its scale. Since I'd selected my background layer to fill in (i.e. the color of the sky in my graphic), the pattern I select in the Pattern Fill changes the sky:</p> \n <p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/photoshop-patterns.png?width=669&amp;height=379&amp;name=photoshop-patterns.png\" alt=\"photoshop-patterns.png\" title=\"photoshop-patterns.png\" width=\"669\" height=\"379\"></p> \n <h4>To use the Gradient tool:</h4> \n <p>To apply a gradient, first select the layer you'd like to fill with a pattern. Then, from the top menu bar, choose <strong>Layer</strong> &gt; <strong>New Fill Layer</strong> &gt; <strong>Gradient.</strong><strong>.. </strong>From there, a \"New Layer\" window will pop up and prompt you to name the new color fill layer. Don't worry about choosing the color you want right then and there -- simply name the layer and press \"OK.\"</p> \n <p>Next, a \"Gradient Fill\" window will pop up. Play around with these options, including the style, angle, and scale. To choose a different gradient than the one offered by default, click the arrow on the right-hand side of the default gradient to open the Gradient Editor, shown below:</p> \n <p><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/photoshop-gradients.png\" alt=\"photoshop-gradients.png\" title=\"photoshop-gradients.png\"></p> \n <h3>11. The Eyedropper<strong><br></strong></h3> \n <p><strong>What It Does:</strong> This handy little tool lets you extract and use any color from any image in Photoshop.</p> \n <p><strong>Where It's Located: </strong>The toolbar on the left.</p> \n <p style=\"text-align: center;\"><span class=\"content-post__\"><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/photoshop-eyedropper.png?width=323&amp;height=318&amp;name=photoshop-eyedropper.png\" alt=\"photoshop-eyedropper.png\" title=\"photoshop-eyedropper.png\" width=\"323\" height=\"318\"></span></p> \n <h4>To use the Eyedropper tool:</h4> \n <p>Select the icon from the sidebar. Next, locate that color you would like to extract, and simply click that area to clone the color.</p> \n <p>Once you've extracted the color, you'll see it indicated both in the Color module at the top right of your screen, as well as the bottom of the left sidebar. You can double-click that color box to bring up the advanced color picker, where you can then adjust and save the color to a swatch for future use.</p> \n <p style=\"text-align: center;\"><span class=\"content-post__\"><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/photoshop-color-picker-eyedrop.png?width=669&amp;height=520&amp;name=photoshop-color-picker-eyedrop.png\" alt=\"photoshop-color-picker-eyedrop.png\" title=\"photoshop-color-picker-eyedrop.png\" width=\"669\" height=\"520\"></span></p> \n <h3>12. Blending Options<strong><br></strong></h3> \n <p><strong>What It Does: </strong>Blending options include quite a number of features to enhance the look or your graphic. For example, you can use the \"Outer Glow\" effect to make letters appear like they're glowing. Or you can use the \"Drop Shadow\" effect to add a shadow to your letters. Take some time to play around with all the layer effects and find out which ones tickle your fancy.</p> \n <p><strong>Where It's Located:</strong> From the top menu bar, choose <strong>Layer</strong> &gt; <strong>Layer Style</strong> &gt; <strong>Blending Options... </strong>You can also double-click any layer to bring up the options for that particular layer.</p> \n <p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/photoshop-blending-options.png?width=669&amp;height=405&amp;name=photoshop-blending-options.png\" alt=\"photoshop-blending-options.png\" title=\"photoshop-blending-options.png\" width=\"669\" height=\"405\"></p> \n <h4><span class=\"content-post__\"><span class=\"content-post__\">To use Blending Options:</span></span></h4> \n <p><span class=\"content-post__\">First, select the layer you want to apply your blending options and effects to. Then, open up your blending options and choose the one you'd like to apply. With the variety of options available, you can achieve a number of great effects to finalize your graphics. Have fun with these and experiment on different layers, images, and texts. Here's a look at what's offered:</span></p> \n <p style=\"text-align: center;\"><span class=\"content-post__\"><span class=\"content-post__\"><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/blending-options-menu.png?width=669&amp;height=418&amp;name=blending-options-menu.png\" alt=\"blending-options-menu.png\" title=\"blending-options-menu.png\" width=\"669\" height=\"418\"></span></span></p> \n <p style=\"text-align: left;\">For example, in the image below, I selected my text layer and chose \"Bevel &amp; Emboss.\" Looks pretty cool, eh?</p> \n <p style=\"text-align: center;\"><span class=\"content-post__\"><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/photoshop-bevel-example.png?width=472&amp;height=247&amp;name=photoshop-bevel-example.png\" alt=\"photoshop-bevel-example.png\" title=\"photoshop-bevel-example.png\" width=\"472\" height=\"247\"></span></p> \n <p>Before we send you on your way, <span>it's worth noting that if you're working with a limited budget and a tight schedule, you can save yourself tons of time and money by using </span><strong>free, royalty-free stock photos.</strong> <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/free-stock-photos\">Here's a list of 17 of the best free stock photo sites you can look through</a><span>.</span></p> \n <p>Also, Photoshop offers a number of <strong>really helpful keyboard shortcuts</strong> for things like zooming in and out, changing canvas size, creating a new layer, and so on. <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/photoshop-keyboard-shortcuts-list\">Check out this blog post for a full list</a>, including shortcuts for some of the tools mentioned above.</p> \n <p><span class=\"content-post__body\"><span>Now, it wouldn't be realistic to guarantee that you'd be a Photoshop wiz at this point -- but that isn’t what this guide designed to do. We hope we've provided you with the understanding you’ll need to use the powerful tools in Photoshop in a timely, efficient, non-hair-pulling manner, so that you can elevate your visual content game, like, today.</span></span></p> \n <p><span class=\"content-post__body\"><span>Happy Photoshopping!</span></span></p> \n <div>\n  <a class=\"close\"> </a>\n </div> \n</div>  \n<img ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn44@2020_6/2020/10/27/16-53-52-157_82897311a02f6bfd.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/photoshop-background-eraser.png?width=224&height=107&name=photoshop-background-eraser.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn45@2020_3/2020/10/27/16-54-05-597_66b2e3be19012f10.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/photoshop-background-eraser-example.png?width=669&height=428&name=photoshop-background-eraser-example.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn43@2020_1/2020/10/27/16-53-50-762_db936ccc82b7a007.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/photoshop-crop-tool.png?width=240&height=319&name=photoshop-crop-tool.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx33/cdn49@2020_5/2020/10/27/16-54-12-526_b0d8e77a49ee81a4.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/photoshop-crop-tool-example.png?width=669&height=357&name=photoshop-crop-tool-example.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn83@2020_2/2020/10/27/16-54-08-912_c6e141cef160f472.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/photoshop-fill-tool.png?width=620&height=291&name=photoshop-fill-tool.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn39@2020_4/2020/10/27/16-53-49-615_90311aaef52c5de9.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/photoshop-solid-color-fill.png?width=438&height=150&name=photoshop-solid-color-fill.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx14/cdn9@2020_2/2020/10/27/16-54-06-702_6c18f7a6706f0e18.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/photoshop-color-picker-fill.png?width=669&height=516&name=photoshop-color-picker-fill.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn37@2020_1/2020/10/27/16-53-59-788_1ed1ced3cc47cafe.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/photoshop-patterns.png?width=669&height=379&name=photoshop-patterns.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn97@2020_1/2020/10/27/16-53-55-462_2c335947164705f5.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/photoshop-gradients.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn61@2020_2/2020/10/27/16-54-11-550_de94cb7f26c1d049.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/photoshop-eyedropper.png?width=323&height=318&name=photoshop-eyedropper.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn27@2020_1/2020/10/27/16-53-49-391_bfadc393dd668f33.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/photoshop-color-picker-eyedrop.png?width=669&height=520&name=photoshop-color-picker-eyedrop.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn33@2020_5/2020/10/27/16-53-57-766_3d24fdac9085b971.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/photoshop-blending-options.png?width=669&height=405&name=photoshop-blending-options.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx23/cdn22@2020_2/2020/10/27/16-54-03-610_ef0d4ab4d3072263.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/blending-options-menu.png?width=669&height=418&name=blending-options-menu.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn31@2020_2/2020/10/27/16-54-14-843_18db13d1aeb9f36f.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/photoshop-bevel-example.png?width=472&height=247&name=photoshop-bevel-example.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn4@2020_3/2020/10/27/16-53-51-416_92c838dba883219a.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fhow-to-use-photoshop&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn30@2020_6/2020/10/27/16-53-54-628_eaaafed607ac8423.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1603817624925},{"createdTime":"2020-10-28 00:53:44","updatedTime":"2020-10-28 00:53:44","title":"35 Office Costume Ideas for Marketing Nerds & Tech Geeks","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/halloween-costume-ideas-marketers-list","description":"<p>Halloween is a fun holiday, and it doesn't get the attention it deserves. It doesn't have recognizable songs or vacation days associated with it, and it falls on a busy time of year for most people in the workforce.</p> \n<p>But that doesn't mean you should skip the festivities at your office Halloween celebration.</p> \n<p></p> \n<p>How many days of the year are you encouraged to dress up and goof around at work? Probably just one -- Halloween -- and even then, it can be hard to know what's office-appropriate.</p> \n<p>We want you to have fun this Halloween, so we're taking the work out if it for you. We've compiled a list of DIY Halloween costume ideas that are easy to put together, inexpensive, and perfect for the digital marketer or tech professional.</p> \n<p>If your family and friends don't get your costume, your colleagues definitely will.</p> \n<p></p> \n<h2>35 Office Costume Ideas for Marketing Nerds &amp; Tech Geeks</h2> \n<h3>Computer or App-Related Costumes</h3> \n<h4>1. Alt Text</h4> \n<p>Alt text isn't just the metadata of an image published on the web -- you could also say it's an \"alternative\" fashion statement with the text to describe the era. This was HubSpot Director of Content Corey Wainwright's office Halloween costume a few years ago. It's great because you don't even look dressed up if you have a casual office dress code, so you can just blend in.</p> \n<p>To dress as alt text this halloween, break out your best 90s alternative garb -- our coworker Corey went with black jeans, combat boots, and a flannel. Then, tape hyphenated text that best describes what you're wearing, much like an <em>image</em> of your outfit would do online to help search engines read the file.</p> \n<p>We edited a sash of alt text on to the alternatively dressed girl below, just to help you picture your awesome costume.</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/computer-costume-alt-text.jpg?width=400&amp;name=computer-costume-alt-text.jpg\" alt=\"Computer costume of girl in 90s alternative outfit with alt text written across her shirt\" width=\"400\" style=\"width: 400px; display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\"><em><span style=\"font-size: 12px; text-align: center;\">Source: </span><a href=\"http://thats2263.rssing.com/chan-42292448/all_p2.html\" style=\"font-size: 12px; text-align: center;\">That's Life</a></em></p> \n<h4>2. SEO Ninja</h4> \n<p>Speaking of dorking out on SEO, you could be everyone's favorite LinkedIn title -- the SEO ninja. Dress in all black, buy a black ski mask, and tape keywords all over yourself. Voila ... you're an actual ninja -- just one much more concerned with search engine optimization than lurking in the darkness.</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/seo-ninja-costume.jpg?width=400&amp;name=seo-ninja-costume.jpg\" alt=\"seo-ninja-costume\" width=\"400\" style=\"width: 400px; display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\"><em><span style=\"font-size: 12px; text-align: center;\">Source: </span><a href=\"https://www.pinterest.co.uk/pin/386957792957848886\" style=\"font-size: 12px; text-align: center;\">Pinterest</a></em></p> \n<h4>3. Mobile App</h4> \n<p>Wander around holding an appetizer -- candy, cheese and crackers, chips and dip ... whatever you have on hand. Boom. You're a mobile \"app.\"</p> \n<p>This costume also doubles as a great way to introduce yourself and make friends at a party.</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><span style=\"font-size: 12px;\"><img class=\"wt-blog__normal-image alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/mobile-app-costume.png?width=669&amp;name=mobile-app-costume.png\" alt=\"mobile-app-costume.png\" width=\"669\" style=\"width: 669px;\" title=\"mobile-app-costume.png\"><em style=\"color: inherit; font-size: 11px;\">Source: <a href=\"https://oppmax.com/blog/7-savvy-halloween-costume-ideas-for-digital-marketers/\">Opportunity Max</a></em></span></p> \n<h4>4. Instagrammer</h4> \n<p>Want another way to turn handing out food into a costume? Dress up like a hipster and hand out graham crackers. You're an \"instant\" \"gram\" cracker server -- or, for short, an Instagrammer. Pun absolutely intended.</p> \n<h4>5. Ghostwriter</h4> \n<p>Have you ever written something for somebody else's byline? Such is the life of a \"ghostwriter.\" Turn your author-less accomplishment into this year's office Halloween costume.</p> \n<p>To dress up as a ghostwriter, grab a white sheet and cut a hole for your head and arms. Dob some black ink spots on the sheet, get a book and one of those feather quills (or just get a feather, I suppose), and <em>boo</em> -- you're a ghostwriter.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/ghostwriter-costume.jpg?width=474&amp;name=ghostwriter-costume.jpg\" alt=\"ghostwriter-costume\" width=\"474\" style=\"width: 474px; display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\"></p> \n<h4>6. Whitespace</h4> \n<p>Whitespace on the internet might just denote all the blank space you use to help your design stand out, but on Halloween, \"whitespace\" isn't just the absence of space.</p> \n<p>Dress in all white -- add white face paint and a white wig if you're ultra-committed. Then add a hint of color somewhere on the outfit, like a colored tie or scarf, or even a paint splotch. That color splotch will make the white space more prominent, transforming you into \"<a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/whitespace-web-design?_ga=2.207328723.195528841.1539902488-814765080.1538488659\">whitespace</a>.\"</p> \n<h4>7. Error 404 Code</h4> \n<p>You've most likely encountered a funny error 404 page before, and you can make it a funny costume, too. Grab a sheet of paper, write \"Error 404: Costume Not Found,\" and tape it to your outfit.</p>  \n<blockquote class=\"instagram-media\" style=\"background: #FFF; border: 0; border-radius: 3px; box-shadow: 0 0 1px 0 rgba(0,0,0,0.5),0 1px 10px 0 rgba(0,0,0,0.15); margin: 1px; max-width: 658px; padding: 0; width: calc(100% - 2px);\"> \n <div style=\"padding: 8px;\"> \n  <div style=\"background: #f8f8f8; line-height: 0; margin-top: 40px; padding: 50% 0px; width: 100%;\">\n   &nbsp;\n  </div> \n  <p style=\"color: #c9c8cd; font-family: Arial,sans-serif; font-size: 14px; line-height: 17px; margin-bottom: 0; margin-top: 8px; overflow: hidden; padding: 8px 0 7px; text-align: center; text-overflow: ellipsis; white-space: nowrap;\"><a href=\"https://www.instagram.com/p/7QsQ9Vhj9_/\" style=\"color: #c9c8cd; font-family: Arial,sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; line-height: 17px; text-decoration: none;\">A photo posted by RachAel Klopfenstein (@theklopf)</a> on Sep 5, 2015 at 12:33pm PDT</p> \n </div> \n</blockquote>  \n<p>  </p> \n<h4 style=\"text-align: left;\">8. (Monty) Python</h4> \n<p>If you're into programming code, British comedy, and low-effort costumes, being (Monty) Python is perfect. Dress up in anything remotely snakelike in your closet: olive green clothing, snakeskin accessories, and fake vampire teeth that can serve as your fangs.</p> \n<p>Then, to amp up the dork factor on this costume, add two coconuts or a gold chalice to embody <a href=\"http://www.imdb.com/title/tt0071853/\">Monty Python</a> on his quest for the Holy Grail.</p> \n<h4>9. Facebook</h4> \n<p>Grab face paint or eyeliner and write \"book\" across your cheeks. Just like that, you're the world's biggest social network for Halloween.</p> \n<p>And for your sake, we hope your colleagues actually get it:</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img class=\"wt-blog__normal-image alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/Halloween-Jim_Bookface-Jim.jpg\" alt=\"Halloween-Jim_Bookface-Jim.jpg\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\"><span style=\"font-size: 12px; text-align: center;\"><em>Source:</em> </span><em style=\"color: inherit; font-size: 12px; text-align: center;\"><a href=\"http://www.andpop.com/2013/10/11/laziest-halloween-costume-according-offices-jim-halpert/\">AndPop</a></em></p> \n<h4>10. Unicorn</h4> \n<p>Here's another tech-friendly, double-entendre costume: Be your own version of a <a href=\"http://fortune.com/unicorns/\">tech unicorn</a>. Here at HubSpot, we love this tech icon, and you can easily make your own version of a unicorn horn with help from <a href=\"http://www.wikihow.com/Make-a-Unicorn-Horn\">this article</a>.</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img class=\"wt-blog__normal-image alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/aid2617087-v4-900px-Make-a-Unicorn-Horn-Step-10-Version-3.jpg?width=600&amp;name=aid2617087-v4-900px-Make-a-Unicorn-Horn-Step-10-Version-3.jpg\" alt=\"aid2617087-v4-900px-Make-a-Unicorn-Horn-Step-10-Version-3.jpg\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; width: 600px;\" title=\"aid2617087-v4-900px-Make-a-Unicorn-Horn-Step-10-Version-3.jpg\" width=\"600\"><em style=\"color: inherit; font-size: 1.1rem; text-align: center;\"><span style=\"font-size: 12px;\">Source<a href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-a-Unicorn-Horn\">: WikiHow</a></span></em></p> \n<h4>11. Phishing Emails</h4> \n<p>Phishing emails are nothing to joke about -- they can seriously threaten your technology and data security. But on Halloween, you can dress up as a play on phishing emails for an easy DIY costume. All you need are a stick, a piece of string, and an envelope. Bonus points if you own a bucket hat and vest to complete the ensemble. Check out an amusing version of this costume below.</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/phishing-email-costume.jpg?width=248&amp;name=phishing-email-costume.jpg\" alt=\"Email phishing Halloween costume with fishing rod with Passwords label as bait\" width=\"248\" style=\"width: 248px; display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\"><em style=\"color: inherit; font-size: 1.1rem; text-align: center;\"><span style=\"font-size: 12px;\">Source: <a href=\"https://www.caranddriver.com/news/the-team-costumes-of-the-2011-24-hours-of-lemons-season\">Car and Driver</a></span></em></p> \n<h4>12. Copycat</h4> \n<p>\"CNTRL + C\" is the popular keyboard macro allowing you to copy items from one place to another on your computer. Well, here's a technology spin on a classic Halloween costume. All you'll need are cat ears, eyeliner-drawn whiskers, and a sheet of paper. Write \"CNTRL + C\" on the paper, tape it to your outfit, and you're a \"copycat.\"</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img class=\"wt-blog__normal-image alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/sub-buzz-22134-1476718504-4.jpg?width=625&amp;height=833&amp;name=sub-buzz-22134-1476718504-4.jpg\" alt=\"Girl in copycat Halloween costume with black cat makeup and CNTRL + C labeled necklace\" width=\"625\" height=\"833\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\"><em style=\"color: inherit; font-size: 1.1rem; text-align: center;\"><span style=\"font-size: 12px;\"><span style=\"font-size: 12px;\">Source: <a href=\"https://www.buzzfeed.com/brettvergara/simple-costumes-you-can-make-the-day-before-hallo?utm_term=.saJORY2yb#.ia4O87jAJ\">BuzzFeed</a></span></span></em></p> \n<h4>13. The Blue Screen of Death</h4> \n<p>You know the screen, even if you don't know the morbid nickname the tech world has given it. This classic error screen is known for signaling the end of a computer's useful life, and you know it when you see it. It causes so much stress on site, in fact, that the color alone is scary enough for October 31.</p> \n<p>Believe it or not, there are <a href=\"http://errorwear.com/\">official T-shirts</a> you can get with the blue screen of death copy printed on them. Want to make your own? All you need is a royal blue t-shirt and a printed version of this horrifying error message to pin to it.</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/blue-screen-of-death-costume.jpg?width=378&amp;name=blue-screen-of-death-costume.jpg\" width=\"378\" style=\"width: 378px; display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\" alt=\"T-shirt with Blue Screen of Death error message printed on it\"><em style=\"color: inherit; font-size: 12px; text-align: center;\">Source:<span style=\"font-size: 12px;\"> <a href=\"https://www.spreadshirt.com/blue+screen+of+death+t-shirts\">Spreadshirt</a></span></em></p> \n<h4>14. GPS Costume</h4> \n<p>This will work best with two people. You can cut a Point A and Point B pin shape out of cardboard, paint both red, and simply write A and B on it. From there, you can personalize the costume whichever way you'd like. You can even get more intricate by finding a T-Shirt with a map on it.&nbsp;</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Screen%20Shot%202019-10-15%20at%203.39.39%20PM.png?width=600&amp;name=Screen%20Shot%202019-10-15%20at%203.39.39%20PM.png\" alt=\"GPS office costume\" width=\"600\" style=\"width: 600px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\"></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center; font-size: 12px;\"><em>Source: <a href=\"https://www.pinterest.com/pin/137359857365658289/?nic=1\">Pinterest</a></em></p> \n<h4>15. Dead Battery and Low Wi-Fi&nbsp;</h4> \n<p>Nothing is more terrifying than a dead battery or no Wi-Fi. This costume brings all of techy's fears to life. It's also pretty simple to create. Just tape or glue images of dead Wi-Fi and low battery signals on to a black shirt. To emphasize the low-connectivity fears, put on some zombie or skeleton makeup.&nbsp;</p> \n<p>Although this can work as a couples costume, this could also be a fun option for office colleagues. Since both costumes within the set don't rely on each other to be understandable, an individual could also wear either the Dead Battery outfir or the No-Wi-Fi suit and still be easily recognized.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://i.pinimg.com/originals/ad/57/91/ad5791e2e93e090fbb432574e53ce4f5.jpg\" width=\"528\" style=\"width: 528px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\" alt=\"Dead Battery and Low Wi-Fi Halloween Costume\"></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center; font-size: 12px;\"><em>Source: <a href=\"https://www.pinterest.com/pin/474496510732540902/?lp=true\">Pinterest</a></em></p> \n<h3>Emoji Costumes</h3> \n<h4>16. Information Desk Girl</h4> \n<p>This genius professional found a golden (or, rather, purple) opportunity to be the \"information desk emoji, the many gestures of whom we've all come to know, love, and use at some point in a text conversation.</p> \n<p>The best part about this awesome tech reference is that you don't need to alter your regular attire to make it work. As Naomi shows us below, it's all in the hand gestures.</p> \n<blockquote class=\"instagram-media\" style=\"background: #FFF; border: 0; border-radius: 3px; box-shadow: 0 0 1px 0 rgba(0,0,0,0.5),0 1px 10px 0 rgba(0,0,0,0.15); margin: 1px; max-width: 540px; min-width: 326px; padding: 0; width: calc(100% - 2px);\"> \n <div style=\"padding: 16px;\">\n  <a href=\"https://www.instagram.com/p/9ensvxiS4i/?utm_source=ig_embed&amp;utm_medium=loading\" style=\"background: #FFFFFF; height: 50px; margin: 0 auto 12px; width: 50px;\">\n    &nbsp;\n   </div> \n   <div style=\"padding-top: 8px;\"> \n    <div style=\"color: #3897f0; font-family: Arial,sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-weight: 550; line-height: 18px;\">\n     View this post on Instagram\n    </div> \n   </div> \n   <div style=\"padding: 12.5% 0;\">\n    &nbsp;\n   </div> \n   <div style=\"display: flex; flex-direction: row; margin-bottom: 14px; align-items: center;\">\n    &nbsp;\n   </div> </a> \n  <p style=\"margin: 8px 0 0 0; padding: 0 4px;\"><a href=\"https://www.instagram.com/p/9ensvxiS4i/?utm_source=ig_embed&amp;utm_medium=loading\" style=\"color: #000; font-family: Arial,sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; line-height: 17px; text-decoration: none; word-wrap: break-word;\">No one recognized my Halloween costume for work until I started texting and striking poses #emojicostume #lazycostume</a></p> \n  <p style=\"color: #c9c8cd; font-family: Arial,sans-serif; font-size: 14px; line-height: 17px; margin-bottom: 0; margin-top: 8px; overflow: hidden; padding: 8px 0 7px; text-align: center; text-overflow: ellipsis; white-space: nowrap;\">A post shared by <a href=\"https://www.instagram.com/naomi_yyz/?utm_source=ig_embed&amp;utm_medium=loading\" style=\"color: #c9c8cd; font-family: Arial,sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; line-height: 17px;\"> Naomi</a> (@naomi_yyz) on Oct 30, 2015 at 3:26pm PDT</p> \n </div> \n</blockquote> \n<h4>17. Dancing Girls Emoji</h4> \n<p>If you're the owner of one of the nearly <a href=\"https://www.lifewire.com/how-many-iphones-have-been-sold-1999500\">more than 1 billion</a> Apple iPhones sold worldwide, you're probably familiar with the dancing girls emoji, shown below.</p> \n<p>The <a href=\"http://www.brit.co/diy-emoji-costumes/?utm_campaign=pinbutton_hover\">easiest version of this costume</a> is to find a buddy and dress all in black together. If you're committed to emoji authenticity, buy black bunny ears to complete the look.</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img class=\"wt-blog__normal-image alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Screen%20Shot%202016-10-25%20at%202.13.14%20PM.png?width=669&amp;name=Screen%20Shot%202016-10-25%20at%202.13.14%20PM.png\" alt=\"Screen Shot 2016-10-25 at 2.13.14 PM.png\" width=\"669\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; width: 669px;\" title=\"Screen Shot 2016-10-25 at 2.13.14 PM.png\"><em><span style=\"font-size: 12px; text-align: center;\">Source: </span><span style=\"font-size: 12px;\"><a href=\"http://www.brit.co/diy-emoji-costumes/?utm_campaign=pinbutton_hover\">Brit + Co</a></span></em></p> \n<h4>18. Heart Eyes</h4> \n<p>Are you just <em>in love</em> with Halloween? Prove it with this passionate emoji face. You don't have to paint your entire face, chin to hairline, to get the Heart Eyes Emoji just right, but it certainly helps. It'll also disguise your stress when you're at your most focused during the day.</p> \n<p>\"This employee just seems to love her job, I can't put my finger on why,\" your manager will think ... See how to paint this emoji onto your face below (you'll need some help for this one).</p> \n<p>&nbsp;</p> \n<div class=\"hs-responsive-embed-wrapper hs-responsive-embed\" style=\"margin: 0px auto; display: block; width: 100%; height: auto; position: relative; overflow: hidden; padding: 0; max-width: 640px; max-height: 380px; min-width: 256px;\"> \n <div class=\"hs-responsive-embed-inner-wrapper\" style=\"position: relative; overflow: hidden; max-width: 100%; padding-bottom: 59.38%; margin: 0;\">\n  <iframe class=\"hs-responsive-embed-iframe\" style=\"position: absolute; top: 0; left: 0; width: 100%; height: 100%; border: none;\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/21otnaBvQ44?ecver=1\" width=\"640\" height=\"380\" frameborder=\"0\" allowfullscreen></iframe>\n </div> \n</div> \n<p>&nbsp;</p> \n<h3>Topical Office Costumes</h3> \n<h4>19. Fully Vested</h4> \n<p>At work, \"fully vested\" usually refers to one's ability to earn all matching funds of a 401(k) retirement plan. But for some, you just can't help but picture someone wearing lots of sleeveless jackets at the same time. Now's the time to personify that image.</p> \n<p>If you work in a company where people would get the joke, put on a bunch of vests (at least three, but even more is encouraged), and that's about it. You're fully vested.</p> \n<h4>20. Nerd</h4> \n<p>What I love about the nerd costume is that it's effortless and always unique -- there are many ways to be a nerd in this day and age. Are you a tech nerd, a video game nerd, or a book nerd? The sky is the limit with this costume. Show up wearing glasses with your favorite accessories, such as a magic wand, book, or lightsaber, to complete the effect.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://i.pinimg.com/564x/92/7c/a5/927ca538726e49296fcc9724ac1e03f9.jpg\" alt=\"Worlds cutest nerd costumes. Erin Harrison and Chandler Abney everyone!! ;) Follow me for my next Halloween costume!\"></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center; font-size: 13px;\"><em>Source: <a href=\"https://www.pinterest.com/pin/335377503481122205/?nic=1\">Pinterest</a></em></p> \n<h4>21. A Solar Eclipse</h4> \n<p>Last year, the solar eclipse took over the internet -- and the country. As millions of people flocked to the path of totality to (hopefully) catch a glimpse of this rare event without burning their corneas, millions more made <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/funniest-social-media-tweets\">jokes about it on social media</a>.</p> \n<p>To dress up as a solar eclipse for Halloween, you'll need a work pal to dress up as the sun and the moon with you. One of you wears black, the other wears yellow, and you both wear dark sunglasses. Then, at the Halloween party, the one dressed in black spends the whole time standing in front of the one in yellow.</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/solar-eclipse-costume.jpg?width=690&amp;name=solar-eclipse-costume.jpg\" width=\"690\" style=\"width: 690px;\" alt=\"Two girls dressed in solar eclipse costume at an office\"><em style=\"color: inherit; font-size: 12px;\">Source: <a href=\"https://www.pinterest.com/pin/267823509074335221\">Pinterest</a></em></p> \n<h4>22. The 'Evil Kermit' Meme</h4> \n<p>If you haven't heard of this mega-popular meme this year, you've probably seen it somewhere: It features Kermit the Frog, face-to-face with his evil twin, Evil Kermit. Evil Kermit looks identical, except for the black cloak.</p> \n<p>For this costume, you and a coworker can keep it simple: You both wear green shirts, and one of you wears a black hoodie or jacket on top. If you really want to commit to the costume, you'll spring for some <a href=\"https://www.amazon.com/Snazaroo-Classic-Face-Paint-Green/dp/B000LWCPRI?th=1\">green face paint</a> to complete the ensemble. Walk around the party together, facing one another, for maximum effect.</p> \n<img class=\"wt-blog__normal-image alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/evil%20kermit%20halloween.png\" alt=\"evil kermit halloween.png\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\"> \n<h4>23. <a href=\"https://fox4kc.com/2018/10/30/5-easy-pun-halloween-costumes-you-can-make-at-the-last-minute/\">Fifty Shades of Grey: PG Paint Swatch Costume</a></h4> \n<p>Want to do something cheeky, but still office friendly? This is PG pun costume shares the name of a popular <a href=\"https://www.amazon.com/Fifty-Shades-Grey-Book-Trilogy/dp/0345803485\">romantic novel and film</a>, \"50 Shades of Grey.\"</p> \n<p>Go to your local paint or hardware store and buy 50 grey paint swatches. Then, tape them to a black shirt and tell your colleagues you're, \"50 Shades of Grey.\"&nbsp;</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://localtvwdaf.files.wordpress.com/2018/10/50-shades.jpg?quality=85&amp;strip=all&amp;w=770&amp;h=770\" width=\"600\" style=\"width: 600px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\" alt=\"50 Shades of Grey Pun Halloween Costume\"></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center; font-size: 12px;\">Source:<a href=\"https://fox4kc.com/2018/10/30/5-easy-pun-halloween-costumes-you-can-make-at-the-last-minute/\"> Fox 24 of Kansas City</a></p> \n<h4>24. The \"But That's None of My Business\" Meme</h4> \n<p>If you love Kermit the Frog, but don't have a colleague to team up with for the \"Evil Kermit\" costume, consider going solo with a costume based off of the <a href=\"https://knowyourmeme.com/memes/but-thats-none-of-my-business\">\"But That's None of My Business\" meme</a>, where Kermit <a href=\"https://knowyourmeme.com/memes/but-thats-none-of-my-business\">is seen judgmentally drinking coffee</a>.</p> \n<p>All you have to do is stick a pair of eyes on a green hoodie and start sipping your tea or coffee. For an added effect, you can cut a white photo frame to hold in front of you so you can look like an image posted on social media.&nbsp;</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Screen%20Shot%202019-10-15%20at%204.08.59%20PM.png?width=600&amp;name=Screen%20Shot%202019-10-15%20at%204.08.59%20PM.png\" alt=\"But That's None of My Business Meme Halloween Costume\" width=\"600\" style=\"width: 600px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\"><span style=\"font-size: 12px;\"><em>Source: <a href=\"https://www.pinterest.com/pin/355925176779595570/?lp=true\">Pinterest</a></em></span></p> \n<h4>25. Eleven from <em>Stranger Things</em></h4> \n<p>Eleven from Netflix's hit series <em>Stranger Things </em>is universally beloved, and it's a bonus that her signature look is a comfortable and easy-to-assemble costume. Rock your best Eleven with a dress, a denim jacket, and a box of Eggo Waffles.</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img class=\"wt-blog__normal-image alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/the-stranger-things-actress-behind-eleven-doesnt-love-eating-tons-of-eggo-waffles.png?width=600&amp;name=the-stranger-things-actress-behind-eleven-doesnt-love-eating-tons-of-eggo-waffles.png\" alt=\"the-stranger-things-actress-behind-eleven-doesnt-love-eating-tons-of-eggo-waffles.png\" width=\"600\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; width: 600px;\" title=\"the-stranger-things-actress-behind-eleven-doesnt-love-eating-tons-of-eggo-waffles.png\"><em style=\"color: inherit; font-size: 11px; text-align: center;\">Source:<span style=\"font-size: 12px;\"> <a href=\"http://www.businessinsider.com/stranger-things-eleven-doesnt-love-waffles-2016-10\">Business Insider</a></span></em></p> \n<h4>26. Scoops Ahoy Employee from Stranger Things</h4> \n<p>While Eleven, noted above, is an absolute classic Stranger Things character, 2019's season inspired another great costume opportunity. During the newest installment of episodes, Stave, a main character played by Joe Keery, worked at an icecream shop called Scoops Ahoy. As a server, he had to wear a goofy sailor uniform alongside <a href=\"https://www.refinery29.com/en-us/2019/07/236976/stranger-things-3-steve-scoops-ahoy-friend-robin\">his coworker Robin</a>.&nbsp;</p> \n<p>Since the season aired, the uniform has been regularly worn by cosplayers and at Comic Con as people mimic Steve and Robin.</p> \n<p>Since it's a pretty generic sailor uniform, you might be able to easily find one that's similar in a variety of Halloween shops. This costume could work for both individuals or two colleagues.&nbsp;</p>  \n<blockquote class=\"instagram-media\" style=\"background: #FFF; border: 0; border-radius: 3px; box-shadow: 0 0 1px 0 rgba(0,0,0,0.5),0 1px 10px 0 rgba(0,0,0,0.15); margin: 1px; max-width: 540px; min-width: 326px; padding: 0; width: calc(100% - 2px);\"> \n <div style=\"padding: 16px;\">\n  <a href=\"https://www.instagram.com/p/B3pSdZsoA_W/?utm_source=ig_embed&amp;utm_campaign=loading\" style=\"background: #FFFFFF; line-height: 0; padding: 0 0; text-align: center; text-decoration: none; width: 100%;\"> \n   <div style=\"display: flex; flex-direction: row; align-items: center;\"> \n    <div style=\"background-color: #f4f4f4; border-radius: 50%; flex-grow: 0; height: 40px; margin-right: 14px; width: 40px;\">\n     &nbsp;\n    </div> \n    <div style=\"display: flex; flex-direction: column; flex-grow: 1; justify-content: center;\"> \n     <div style=\"background-color: #f4f4f4; border-radius: 4px; flex-grow: 0; height: 14px; margin-bottom: 6px; width: 100px;\">\n      &nbsp;\n     </div> \n     <div style=\"background-color: #f4f4f4; border-radius: 4px; flex-grow: 0; height: 14px; Pokémon GO Trainer</h4> \n<p>Pokémon GO had roughly <a href=\"http://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2016-08-22/these-charts-show-that-pokemon-go-is-already-in-decline\">45 million people</a> walking around in cities glued to their phones last summer (I, among them). To pay homage to the explosion of this tech trend, you'll need a t-shirt that's red, yellow, or blue. Using fabric paint or permanent marker, write Valor (for red), Instinct (for yellow), or Mystic (for blue) on your shirt.</p> \n<p>Spend Halloween walking around pointing your phone at objects, and you're the spitting image of a Pokémon GO trainer. Gotta catch 'em all, right?</p>  \n<blockquote class=\"instagram-media\" style=\"background: #FFF; border: 0; border-radius: 3px; box-shadow: 0 0 1px 0 rgba(0,0,0,0.5),0 1px 10px 0 rgba(0,0,0,0.15); margin: 1px; max-width: 658px; padding: 0; width: calc(100% - 2px);\"> \n <div style=\"padding: 8px;\"> \n  <div style=\"background: #F8F8F8; line-height: 0; margin-top: 40px; padding: 62.4537037037% 0; text-align: center; width: 100%;\">\n   &nbsp;\n  </div> \n  <p style=\"color: #c9c8cd; font-family: Arial,sans-serif; font-size: 14px; line-height: 17px; margin-bottom: 0; margin-top: 8px; overflow: hidden; padding: 8px 0 7px; text-align: center; text-overflow: ellipsis; white-space: nowrap;\"><a href=\"https://www.instagram.com/p/BI6CX_aBN4F/\" style=\"color: #c9c8cd; font-family: Arial,sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; line-height: 17px; text-decoration: none;\">A photo posted by Odinia (@marshmallowsie)</a> on Aug 9, 2016 at 4:44pm PDT</p> \n </div> \n</blockquote>  \n<h3>&nbsp;</h3> \n<h3>&nbsp;</h3> \n<h3>Group Office Costumes</h3> \n<h4>28. The Sales Lifecycle</h4> \n<p>At HubSpot, we love embracing team costumes. In 2018, a handful of HubSpot employees grabbed some T-Shirts and wrote the stages of the sales lifecycle on them. Then they lined up accordingly and passed a fake prospect listing around to symbolize the process of making a sale. This was such an easy costume to coordinate that the team could even include an out-of-office employee over a video call.&nbsp;</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/20181031_165016.gif?width=600&amp;name=20181031_165016.gif\" alt=\"HubSpot Employee sales cycle halloween costume\" width=\"600\" style=\"width: 600px; margin: 0px auto;\"><span style=\"font-size: 12px;\"><em>Source: Maggie Bomze, Principal Customer Success Manager of Strategic Accounts at HubSpot</em></span></p> \n<h4>29. Social Media Channels</h4> \n<p>While this Pinterest image shows classmates posting as the major social media networks, this could easily be modified to fit the office setting.&nbsp;</p> \n<p>Simply pick out a solid list of the hottest social networks, then by blank T-Shirts that match the colors of each platform. From there, you can either draw, tape or glue the logos on to each shirt. If you're not interested in the tutus worn below, you could also find matching pants, or just wear jeans and keep things simple.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://i.pinimg.com/originals/4f/7a/b6/4f7ab6fe86bcb3e3c903ba35dfd5d189.jpg\" alt=\"Social Media Network team costumes\" width=\"600\" style=\"width: 600px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\"></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center; font-size: 12px;\"><em>Source: <a href=\"https://www.pinterest.com/pin/535506211925012614/?lp=true\">Pinterest</a></em></p> \n<h4>30. Google Algorithm Update</h4> \n<p>Find a couple of office buddies for this one -- one panda, one penguin, and one pigeon. You might be thinking, \"what the heck is the pigeon algorithm update?\" 1) <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/google-algorithm-visual-history-infographic?_ga=2.34709217.195528841.1539902488-814765080.1538488659\">It's a thing</a>, and 2) we checked Amazon for hummingbird costumes and there aren't any cheap ones available.</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img class=\"wt-blog__normal-image alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/google-algorithm-update-halloween-costumes.jpg?width=1024&amp;name=google-algorithm-update-halloween-costumes.jpg\" alt=\"google-algorithm-update-halloween-costumes.jpg\" width=\"1024\" style=\"width: 1024px;\"><em style=\"color: inherit; font-size: 1.1rem; text-align: center;\"><span style=\"font-size: 12px;\">Source: <a href=\"https://oppmax.com/blog/7-savvy-halloween-costume-ideas-for-digital-marketers/\">Opportunity Max</a></span></em></p> \n<h4>31. Black Hat and White Hat SEO</h4> \n<p>This is another SEO-related costume, and I think you can figure this one out on your own. I recommend wearing a black hat for one, and a white hat for the other, and having \"SEO\" embroidered on each one -- which you can <a href=\"https://www.google.com/search?q=custom+order+embroidered+hat\">easily custom order</a>.</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Black-Hat-SEO.jpg?width=513&amp;name=Black-Hat-SEO.jpg\" alt=\"Black hat with SEO label on top\" width=\"513\" style=\"width: 513px; display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\"><em><span style=\"font-size: 12px; text-align: center;\">Source: <a href=\"https://seo-hacker.com/google-blackhat-1999/\" style=\"font-size: 12px; text-align: center;\"><em>SE</em>O-Hacker</a></span></em></p> \n<h4>32. Snapchat Filters</h4> \n<p>Here's another group costume idea that pays tribute to Snapchat's filters feature.</p> \n<p>There are numerous options that you and your team can choose from to embody this costume. You could dress up as <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/snapchat-best-brands\">vomiting rainbows</a>, cat and dog ears, a flower crown, or a face swap, and this could be as DIY or store-bought as you're interested in pursuing. For example, here's some inspiration for a couple of the dog filters:</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img class=\"wt-blog__normal-image alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/snapchatfilter.jpg?width=669&amp;name=snapchatfilter.jpg\" alt=\"snapchat filter team costume\" width=\"669\" title=\"snapchatfilter.jpg\" style=\"width: 669px; display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\"><em><span style=\"font-size: 12px;\">Source: <a href=\"http://www.popsugar.com/smart-living/DIY-Snapchat-Filter-Halloween-Costume-42390391\">PopSugar</a></span></em></p> \n<h4>33. Snapchat Ghosts</h4> \n<p>Put a marketing spin on a classic Halloween costume by arriving as a Snapchat ghost. You'll all need a white sheet and to pick which ghost you like the most.</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img class=\"wt-blog__normal-image alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/maxresdefault-24.jpg?width=669&amp;name=maxresdefault-24.jpg\" alt=\"Snapchat Ghost team halloween costume\" width=\"669\" style=\"width: 669px; display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\" title=\"maxresdefault-24.jpg\"><em><span style=\"font-size: 12px; text-align: center;\">Source: <a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RLx0waKuwRE\">YouTube</a></span></em></p> \n<h4>34. PAC-MAN and Company</h4> \n<p>Here's yet another awesome ghostly costume idea your whole team at work can get in on. Have your team lead wear the yellow pie-shaped garb of PAC-MAN, with each team member dressed as the multi-colored ghosts that roam the screen in this vintage arcade game.</p> \n<p>Just make sure the team lead doesn't <em>actually</em> try to eat the ghosts -- you're in an office, and you're all technically on the same team.</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/pac-man-group-costume.jpg?width=612&amp;name=pac-man-group-costume.jpg\" alt=\"Group costume with PAC-MAN, four ghosts and fruit from the vintage arcade game\" width=\"612\" style=\"width: 612px;\"><em style=\"color: inherit; font-size: 12px; text-align: center;\">Source: <a href=\"https://meningrey.net/galery/pacman-group-costume.html\">Meningrey</a></em></p> \n<h4>35. Instagram Filters</h4> \n<p>For this group costume, you'll need white t-shirts and fabric markers. Draw an Instagram photo frame on the front of your shirts, and each team member can write a different <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/edit-instagram-photos\">Instagram filter</a>'s name inside the photo frame. Or, create frame props with different filters on them like the group did below:</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img class=\"wt-blog__normal-image alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/M-nahalloween-1.jpg?width=600&amp;name=M-nahalloween-1.jpg\" alt=\"Instagram Filter Halloween costumes\" width=\"600\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; width: 600px;\" title=\"M-nahalloween-1.jpg\"><em><span style=\"font-size: 12px;\">Source: <a href=\"http://www.nailsmag.com/blogpost/109187/nails-flashback-friday-halloween\">Nails Magazine</a></span></em></p> \n<p>The clothes don't make the marketer, but the costume can certainly make the culture at your company. Find out what it takes to hire and train the best fits for your open roles in the free ebook, available below.</p> \n<p><em>Editor's Note: This post was originally published October 21, 2018 but was updated in October of 2019 for comprehensiveness.</em></p> \n<p></p> \n<p></p>  \n<img
