readerx10/cdn75@2020_5/2020/10/27/16-53-54-049_590ea6ce1d58e6a6.webp","https://i.pinimg.com/originals/4f/7a/b6/4f7ab6fe86bcb3e3c903ba35dfd5d189.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn92@2020_3/2020/10/27/16-53-51-489_ae56ec67da1ff354.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/google-algorithm-update-halloween-costumes.jpg?width=1024&name=google-algorithm-update-halloween-costumes.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn39@2020_1/2020/10/27/16-53-53-470_dfd4641ea31b7739.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Black-Hat-SEO.jpg?width=513&name=Black-Hat-SEO.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn23@2020_3/2020/10/27/16-53-50-469_50fed6d0e1942709.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/snapchatfilter.jpg?width=669&name=snapchatfilter.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn86@2020_5/2020/10/27/16-54-02-875_2f59f422701c4edb.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/maxresdefault-24.jpg?width=669&name=maxresdefault-24.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn80@2020_6/2020/10/27/16-53-50-053_dfa818761761e5e0.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/pac-man-group-costume.jpg?width=612&name=pac-man-group-costume.jpg":null,"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/M-nahalloween-1.jpg?width=600&name=M-nahalloween-1.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn87@2020_2/2020/10/27/16-54-08-938_795dc6bbcaf21c5b.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fhalloween-costume-ideas-marketers-list&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn52@2020_3/2020/10/27/16-54-03-992_c5d452967021cb00.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1603817624903},{"createdTime":"2020-10-28 00:53:44","updatedTime":"2020-10-28 00:53:44","title":"What Are YouTube Tags & Why Are They Important?","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/youtube-tags","description":"<p>YouTube is the <a href=\"https://www.searchenginejournal.com/seo-101/meet-search-engines/\">second largest search engine in the world</a>, so keyword-optimizing your videos on the platform is just as important as keyword-optimizing your blog posts for Google.</p> \n<p>Even if you’ve just created the next “<a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_OBlgSz8sSM\">Charlie bit my finger</a>” video, you must remember that an algorithm dictates which videos YouTube will serve to its audience -- and which ones it won’t.</p> \n<p>One of the best ways to <a href=\"https://academy.hubspot.com/courses/youtube-marketing\">keyword-optimize your videos for YouTube</a> is leveraging tags. Below, we’ve put together a guide that will explain exactly what YouTube tags are, why they’re important, and some best practices to follow. We’ll also show you three YouTube tag generators that can help you discover the keywords that could rocket your videos to the top of the platform’s search results.</p> \n<div class=\"hsg-featured-snippet\"> \n <h2>What are tags for YouTube?</h2> \n <p>YouTube Tags are words and phrases you can include in your YouTube videos’ description. They let your viewers, and YouTube, know what your videos are about and can help them rank higher in the platform’s search results.</p> \n</div> \n<h2><strong>Why are YouTube tags important?</strong></h2> \n<p>YouTube tags are important because they help YouTube grasp your video’s content and context. This way, YouTube can understand your video’s topic and category, and associate it with similar content, which can amplify your video’s reach.</p> \n<h2><strong>YouTube Tags Best Practices</strong></h2> \n<p>To leverage YouTube tags to their fullest potential, check out these tips and tricks.</p> \n<h3>1. Make your first tag your target keyword and order the rest by importance.</h3> \n<p>YouTube heavily accounts for your video’s first few tags when ranking content in their search results, especially the first tag. So make sure your first tag is the exact keyword you want to target.</p> \n<h3>2. Use some broad keywords that describe the overarching topic your video falls under as other tags.</h3> \n<p>Using broad keywords as other tags helps YouTube understand your video’s context. For example, if you’re creating a video called “How to Hit a Baseball”, you’d want to add “Baseball” as a broad tag to indicate to YouTube that your video’s overarching topic is about baseball.</p> \n<h3>3. Use some specific keywords that describe the topics you covered in your video as other tags.</h3> \n<p>Using specific keywords that describe the topics you cover in your video as other tags helps YouTube understand your video’s content. For instance, in the same “How to Hit a Baseball” video, adding “hitting off a tee” or “hitting batting practice” as specific tags would indicate to YouTube the exact topics your video covers.</p> \n<h2><strong>Best YouTube Tag Generators</strong></h2> \n<p>To discover the keywords you can tag in your videos and help them rank higher in YouTube’s search results, here are three of the best YouTube Tag Generators to try.</p> \n<h3>1. <a href=\"https://keywordkeg.com/\">Keyword Keg</a></h3> \n<img src=\"https://lh5.googleusercontent.com/1BKxGryQKTdmUrL_vNs3aU-TozY80Wn6MQrfx1-VJl491uleI-O4c-2oAMT7JXqJxtHU3N5bR3p13gwP8hrjhSeLVdfEBZ94Sr5WxwDgu83ovZjZjPAmGI_LjjdkgXkKf7FUmrTv\" title=\"\" width=\"100%\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\"> \n<p>Using Keyword Keg, you can enter your target keyword into the tool and it’ll serve up its search volume, cost-per-click, competition, on-page difficulty, off-page difficulty, SEO difficulty, CTR scope, keyword power, trends, and suggested keywords. You can also filter your results by country and language.</p> \n<h3>2. <a href=\"https://keywordtool.io/youtube\">Keywordtool.io</a></h3> \n<img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/unnamed%20(1)-3.png\" title=\"\" width=\"100%\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\"> \n<p>After plugging your target keyword into its YouTube search bar, Keywordtool.io will provide you with suggested keywords, their search volume, how they’ve trended over the past 12 months, and questions, prepositions, and hashtags that also include your target keyword.</p> \n<h3>3. <a href=\"https://vidiq.com/\">VidIQ</a></h3> \n<span style=\"font-size: 1.125rem; font-weight: 400;\">VidIQ will display your target keyword’s related keywords, related score, search volume, search score, competition score, and overall score, which is a combination of a keyword’s related score, search score, and competition score.</span> \n<p><em>Editor's note: This post was originally published in July 2019 and has been updated for comprehensiveness.</em></p>  \n<img src=\"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&amp;k=14&amp;r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fyoutube-tags&amp;bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&amp;bvt=rss\" alt=\"\" width=\"1\" height=\"1\" style=\"min-height:1px!important;width:1px!important;border-width:0!important;margin-top:0!important;margin-bottom:0!important;margin-right:0!important;margin-left:0!important;padding-top:0!important;padding-bottom:0!important;padding-right:0!important;padding-left:0!important; \">","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Mon, 19 Oct 2020 11:00:00 +0000","feedId":54,"bgimg":"","linkMd5":"4f7a8cd440da82f80ab1f8e1ff62f300","bgimgJsdelivr":"","metaImg":"","author":"cchi@hubspot.com (Clifford Chi)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://lh5.googleusercontent.com/1BKxGryQKTdmUrL_vNs3aU-TozY80Wn6MQrfx1-VJl491uleI-O4c-2oAMT7JXqJxtHU3N5bR3p13gwP8hrjhSeLVdfEBZ94Sr5WxwDgu83ovZjZjPAmGI_LjjdkgXkKf7FUmrTv":null,"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/unnamed%20(1)-3.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn99@2020_1/2020/10/27/16-53-49-142_16e2e172af89ede1.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fyoutube-tags&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn100@2020_3/2020/10/27/16-54-08-970_e93f0c226e88be1a.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1603817624925},{"createdTime":"2020-10-28 00:53:44","updatedTime":"2020-10-28 00:53:44","title":"The Ultimate Guide to Content Creation","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/content-creation","description":"<p>Where is the first place you go for expert advice or an answer to a burning question? My guess is Google (or your preferred search engine). You’re not alone — Google alone answers over four billion search queries everyday.</p> \n<p>When you enter a question into the search bar, those links that appear in your search results are content. Whether you know it or not, you consume content on a daily basis.<span style=\"font-size: 1.1rem;\">&nbsp;</span></p> \n<p>That <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/content-marketing-strategy-guide\">marketing strategy guide</a> ... content.</p> \n<p>Those articles that diagnose your symptoms ... content.</p> \n<p>The video tutorial on how to create Victoria Secret-level hair volume ... content.</p> \n<p>News stories, Instagram feeds, blog posts, cat videos, GIFs, memes ... all content.</p> \n<p>Content is a large part of your everyday life. It’s hard to avoid, but why would you want to? Content keeps us informed, answers our questions, entertains us, makes us smile, guides our decisions, and more.</p> \n<p>Content helps you attract, engage, and delight prospects and customers, bring new visitors to your site, and ultimately, generate revenue for your company.</p> \n<p>In other words, if you’re not creating content, then you’re <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/marketing-statistics\">behind the curve</a>.</p> \n<h3>Why Is Content Important?</h3> \n<p>Content creation is the ultimate inbound marketing practice. When you create content, you’re providing free and useful information to your audience, attracting potential customers to your website, and retaining existing customers through quality engagement.</p> \n<p>You’re also generating some major ROI for your company, as these content marketing stats demonstrate:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>Content marketing brings in <a href=\"https://www.demandmetric.com/content/content-marketing-infographic\">3X</a> as many leads as traditional marketing and costs 62% less.</li> \n <li>SMBs that use content marketing get <a href=\"https://www.impactbnd.com/blogging-statistics-55-reasons-blogging-creates-55-more-traffic\">126%</a> more leads than those that don’t.</li> \n <li><a href=\"https://contentmarketinginstitute.com/2017/10/know-like-trust-content/\">61% of online purchases</a> are the direct result of a customer reading a blog.</li> \n <li>Companies that publish 16+ blog posts per month get <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/blogging-frequency-benchmarks\">3.5X</a> more traffic than those that post four or fewer posts per month.&nbsp;</li> \n</ul> \n<p>Content equals business growth. So, let’s get started with your content strategy.</p> \n<a></a> \n<h2><strong>Content Planning and Strategy</strong></h2> \n<p>You wouldn’t start building a house without a blueprint, a sculpture without a sketch, or a company without a mission statement. So, there should be no content creation without a plan. Otherwise you risk getting derailed from your objective.</p> \n<p>A <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/content-marketing-plan\">content strategy</a> includes everything from brand and tone to how you will promote your content and eventually repurpose it. Let’s go over how to create your content plan, step-by-step.</p> \n<p><strong>Featured Resource</strong></p> \n<ul> \n <li><a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/content-marketing-training-workbook?hubs_post-cta=inline-text\">Interactive Content Marketing Workbook</a></li> \n</ul> \n<h3>Set Your Content Goals</h3> \n<p>Similar to a traditional marketing campaign, your content strategy should be centered on your marketing goals (which should, in turn, be derived from your company goals).</p> \n<p>Your goals could range from attracting more visitors to your site to generating more leads to anything in between — as long as they’re <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/blog/tabid/6307/bid/33898/how-to-set-smart-marketing-goals-for-2013-template.aspx\">SMART</a> goals. An example of this kind of goal would be to increase organic traffic to the blog by 25% in the next quarter.<span style=\"font-size: 1.1rem;\">&nbsp;</span></p> \n<p>Once you determine that, each piece of content you create should be aligned with your goal and contribute to your desired outcome.</p> \n<p>In sum, start with your goals, then create your content.</p> \n<h3>Create a Buyer Persona</h3> \n<p>Building a content strategy is more than considering what type of content you want to create. You first need to know who you’re speaking to, how you want to speak to them, and where to find them.<span style=\"font-size: 1.1rem;\">&nbsp;</span></p> \n<p>The key to creating successful inbound content is to make each reader feel like you’re speaking directly to them.</p> \n<p>The only way to do this is to get intimate with your visitors, leads, and customers — you need to know them like you know an old friend. You should be aware of their obstacles, their pain points, their challenges, and fears. Similarly, you should understand their best possible outcome, their dream solution, and their biggest fantasies.<span style=\"font-size: 1.1rem;\">&nbsp;</span></p> \n<p>Always remember that you are marketing to <strong>humans</strong> that want to feel connected.</p> \n<p>Ideally you’d know and be able to speak directly to every individual that visits your website, but you can’t. The solution? Create a buyer persona.<span style=\"font-size: 1.1rem;\">&nbsp;</span></p> \n<p>Your buyer persona is the person that you want to reach with your content. This semi-fictional character serves as a representation of your target audience, i.e., the people who are most likely to benefit from your message and become customers.<span style=\"font-size: 1.1rem;\">&nbsp;</span></p> \n<p>Creating a buyer persona takes a bit of research, some guesswork, and tweaking. But the end result is a clear picture of the person you want to market to and someone who will happily consume your content.<span style=\"font-size: 1.1rem;\">&nbsp;</span></p> \n<p><strong>Not sure where to start? Use </strong><a href=\"https://www.makemypersona.com/\">MakeMyPersona</a><strong> to build out your buyer persona.</strong></p> \n<h3>Rely on the Buyer’s Journey</h3> \n<p>If you’ve ever had a headache, the first thing you likely did was try to figure out the cause. Perhaps you were dehydrated, or caffeine-depleted, or maybe you were sick. After you diagnosed the problem, you moved on to solutions — drink some water, grab an espresso, or take some medicine. Finally, you decide between solutions: Evian or tap water? Starbucks or Peet’s Coffee? Aleve or Tylenol? Hopefully, your headache then subsided and you were able to go about your day.<span style=\"font-size: 1.1rem;\">&nbsp;</span></p> \n<p>This is a representation of the buyer’s journey. Each of your prospects follows a path to a solution — that path involves awareness, consideration, and decision stages. But each of your prospects is in a different part of that journey, so it’s important to use your content to appeal to each stage.<span style=\"font-size: 1.1rem;\">&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-size: 1.1rem;\">&nbsp;</span></p> \n<div>\n <img src=\"https://lh5.googleusercontent.com/IGJVUQefJ4EBBW2vSYn2EoRA_b20ZkRLB6FngQc7Df8L9kiAnv1xpjxyb3n-P-YY9EB5bBUq-acrqbZoJZwuDPBKzQsRCHYiMrTcry4JCX1qcGVTstjJVsmum7LmTMo3iGo6XIPc\" alt=\"\">\n</div> \n<div style=\"text-align: center;\">\n <span style=\"font-size: 1.1rem;\"><span style=\"font-size: 13px;\">Source: <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/customers/apply-the-buyers-journey-to-your-inbound-strategy\">HubSpot</a></span></span>\n</div> \n<p>By creating content for each stage of the buyer’s journey, you’re ensuring that no visitors fall through the cracks and that every individual that comes to your site feels like they are receiving relevant, useful information.</p> \n<p>You also want to select a format for your content so that it’s tailored to each stage of the buyer’s journey. A new visitor in the awareness stage won’t want a live demo of your product, but they <em>would</em> read a quick checklist or blog post that helps them better understand their problem. A prospect in the decision stage doesn’t need to know about all the possible solutions, they need a consultation or demo that shows them that your product is the <em>right</em> solution. Always meet your audience where they are.</p> \n<p><span style=\"font-size: 1.1rem;\">Here’s a guide to the best content formats for each stage of the buyer’s journey:</span></p> \n<p><strong>Awareness: </strong>Whitepaper, Blog Post, Checklist, Tip Sheet, Infographic, Ebook, Game, Quiz</p> \n<p><strong>Consideration: </strong>Podcast, Webinar, Worksheet, Comparison Matrix, Template<span style=\"font-size: 1.1rem;\">&nbsp;</span></p> \n<p><strong>Decision: </strong>Demo, Free Trial, Product Guide, Consultation, Coupon</p> \n<h3>Perform a Content Audit</h3> \n<p>Whether you’ve been creating content for a while without any clear direction or you’ve been following a strategy all along, every marketing department can benefit from a content audit. Just because you didn’t start out with a clearly defined strategy doesn’t mean that the content you already have won’t fit into one.</p> \n<p>A content audit is simply taking inventory of the work you’ve already done, then organizing it to fit under a your new content plan.<span style=\"font-size: 1.1rem;\">&nbsp;</span></p> \n<p>The process might involve some re-writing, or it could reveal gaps that need to be filled with content that appeals to your persona and their journey stage.<span style=\"font-size: 1.1rem;\">&nbsp;</span></p> \n<p>Here’s how you’d perform your content audit:<span style=\"font-size: 1.1rem;\">&nbsp;</span></p> \n<ol> \n <li>Gather all of your content in a spreadsheet.</li> \n <li>Create columns for target keywords, buyer persona, buyer’s journey stage, format, and main topic, then fill these in for each content piece.</li> \n <li>Add columns for your key metrics, like page views, shares, engagement, etc.</li> \n <li>Finally, categorize each post (using highlights or another column) by those that are doing well, need improvement, should be rewritten, or can be merged with another post.</li> \n</ol> \n<p>While a content audit may seem tedious, all the manual labor will be worth the <a href=\"https://contentmarketinginstitute.com/2017/03/content-strategy-editorial-planning/\">increased traffic and leads</a>. Plus, you’ll have a verified plan moving forward.</p> \n<p>If this process seems a bit overwhelming, check out <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/customers/creating-a-content-inventory\">this post</a> for some more guidance.</p> \n<h3>Choose the Right Format</h3> \n<p>Remember that buyer person you created? You’re creating content <em>for</em> them. That means you should be crafting content in a format that is most easily and enjoyably consumed by your prospects.</p> \n<p>The format you choose might be a blog post, video, slideshare, graphic, ebook, whitepaper, podcast, or whatever your creative mind can conceive. As long as it serves your persona, you’ll be in good shape.<span style=\"font-size: 1.1rem;\">&nbsp;</span></p> \n<p>Also, you don’t need to stick to one format for every piece of content that you create. But you should be able to create content — in whatever format — on a consistent cadence. What I mean is, a podcast series might be a great marketing tactic, but if you lack the resources (and patience) to stick to it, then a blog might be a better route.</p> \n<p>Use these questions as a guide when choosing your content format:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>What stage of buyer’s journey is this for?</li> \n <li>How easy is it for your audience to consume this content?</li> \n <li>Where does your persona spend their time online?</li> \n <li>What format can you create on a consistent basis?</li> \n <li>Are you able to produce this content at aquality level that’s competitive?</li> \n</ul> \n<h3>Content Promotion</h3> \n<p>What good is it to create all this great content if no one sees it? In a perfect world, herds of people would flock to your site every time you published a new post. In reality — especially when you’re just starting out — you’ll need to entice people to consume your content and even shepherd them into your online space.</p> \n<p>Hence why content promotion is just as important to your strategy as whatever content you create.</p> \n<p>Your promotion plan should be guided by your persona. Where do they spend their time online? What time of day do they use a particular platform? How often do they want to see content from you? How do they like to consume content? What email subject lines get them to click?<span style=\"font-size: 1.1rem;\">&nbsp;</span></p> \n<p>Content promotion varies by medium, and there are <a href=\"https://academy.hubspot.com/lessons/how-to-effectively-promote-content\">specific rules to follow</a> for each.</p> \n<h4>Social Media</h4> \n<p>While social media is a relationship building tool, it can be <a href=\"https://academy.hubspot.com/lessons/understanding-social-media-promotion\">used to promote content</a>. It’s all about finding the right balance between self-promotion, sharing useful information, and entertainment. Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, YouTube, and Snapchat are all great mediums to both create and share relevant content. The key is modifying that content to fit the platform.</p> \n<p><strong>Featured Resources</strong></p> \n<ul> \n <li><a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/how-to-use-twitter-for-business?hubs_post-cta=inline-text\">How to Use Twitter for Business (+ Follower Growth Tracking Template)</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/30-days-of-instagram?hubs_post-cta=inline-text\">30 Days of Instagram: A Guide for Businesses</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/how-to-attract-customers-with-facebook?hubs_post-cta=inline-text\">How to Attract Customers With Facebook</a></li> \n</ul> \n<h4>Email Marketing</h4> \n<p>Email is one of the best ways to reach your audience for any reason, especially to <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/content-promotion-ideas\">promote content</a>. The reason is anyone on your email list has opted in to hear from you <em>and</em> you can guarantee that they’ll get your messages. Better yet, you can improve your open rates by sending relevant content to segmented lists, meaning they’ll be eager to read everything you send their way.</p> \n<p><strong>Featured Resource</strong></p> \n<ul> \n <li><a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/an-introduction-to-email-marketing?hubs_post-cta=inline-text\">The Beginner's Guide to Email Marketing</a></li> \n</ul> \n<h4>Paid Promotion</h4> \n<p>Pay-per-click (PPC) helps you get your content in front of new audiences through targeted, paid advertisements. These ads can run on social media, search engines, or other websites. Once you define your buyer persona, you’ll want to go the paid route so not to waste money targeting uninterested parties. Once you have your audience down, <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/insiders/media-tactics-to-promote-content\">paid promotion</a> can yield a great ROI.</p> \n<p><strong>Featured Resources</strong></p> \n<ul> \n <li><a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/template-managing-and-organizing-google-adwords-campaigns?hubs_post-cta=inline-text\">The Ultimate Google AdWords and PPC Kit</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/digital-ads-myths?hubs_post-cta=inline-text\">34 Digital Advertising Myths</a></li> \n</ul> \n<h4>Syndication</h4> \n<p>Getting your content promoted through authoritative, third-party channels is a great way to build your audience. Syndication gets your brand in front of fresh eyes (and wallets) that you wouldn’t otherwise reach with your own efforts.</p> \n<h3>Repurposing Content</h3> \n<p>When you repurpose content, you’re reusing something you spent a lot of time to create and transforming it in various formats so that it can be more widely consumed.</p> \n<p>Think of it as recycling. You want to spend less time creating and more time getting your content in front of your audience. For example, that blog post that you wrote on marketing stats can also serve as a great infographic or even a video.</p> \n<p>If you created something in one format, try to think of all the other ways that you could reuse that information that might be just as effective.</p> \n<a></a> \n<h2><strong>The Content Creation Process</strong></h2> \n<p>We marketers are busy. We don’t have time to waste on inefficient systems. That’s why we create processes for everything we do. We devise a system, roll it out, tweak it until it works, then repeat that system over and over to generate the results we want. Think about every marketing campaign you’ve ever done — webinars, autoresponders, surveys. Each of them had a process. Content creation is no different.<span style=\"font-size: 1.1rem;\">&nbsp;</span></p> \n<p>Follow these steps to create content, remove the guesswork, and allow for more creative mental space.</p> \n<h3>1. SEO Research</h3> \n<p>Creating your buyer persona likely gave you some ideas about what topics to write about and what questions your audience might have, which is a great start. Now, you need to confirm if those ideas can apply on a bigger scale to a larger audience. Sure, it would be great to write a blog post directed toward a single person, but, <em>boy</em>, would it be a waste of energy.</p> \n<p>SEO research — a.k.a. keyword research — will show you the search volume of a specific keyword phrase and whether it’s worth the investment of creating a piece of content around it.</p> \n<p>A good way to go about keyword research is to write down some questions that your persona might have based on their obstacles and goals. Then, perform some keyword research around those queries to see if enough people are searching for them. A rule of thumb is to target keywords that are attainable, meaning that have a monthly search volume (MSV) and keyword difficulty that corresponds to your domain authority. Trying to target high volume (read: highly competitive) keywords when you’ve just started blogging won’t pan out too well for you.</p> \n<p><em>Before we go any further, let’s detour into a quick-and-dirty SEO explanation:</em></p> \n<p>One important factor that helps you to rank in search engines is domain authority. You gain domain authority by how many external sites link back to your content. In order for this to happen, you need to have a pretty large library of content that is valuable enough to cite. That means, the longer you write high quality content, the higher your domain authority and the easier it is to rank for highly competitive keywords that will put you on the first page of Google.</p> \n<p>If you’re not quite there yet, the best thing to do is to target <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/definition-long-tail-keyword-100-words-sr\">long-tail</a>, low-volume keywords with minimal keyword difficulty (&lt;50) — we’re talking 200-1000 MSV. This will give you the best chance at ranking for keywords and getting your content in front of more people.<span style=\"font-size: 1.1rem;\">&nbsp;</span></p> \n<p><em>SEO lesson concluded. Back to our scheduled programming.</em></p> \n<p>There are a few ways you could perform your keyword research:<span style=\"font-size: 1.1rem;\">&nbsp;</span></p> \n<ul> \n <li>Use keyword research tools, like <a href=\"https://www.semrush.com/\">SEMRush</a> or <a href=\"https://moz.com/explorer\">Moz Keyword Explorer</a>.</li> \n <li>Type your keyword into a search engine and take note of the auto-filled queries.</li> \n <li>Check out the related searches section on search engine results pages (SERPs).</li> \n</ul> \n<p><strong>Featured Resources</strong></p> \n<ul> \n <li><a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/how-to-conduct-technical-seo-audit?hubs_post-cta=inline-text\">How to Conduct a Technical SEO Audit</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/seo-myths?hubs_post-cta=inline-text\">22 SEO Myths to Leave Behind in 2019</a></li> \n</ul> \n<h3>2. Ideation</h3> \n<p>Now that you’ve determined which keywords to target, it’s time to brainstorm some content ideas. HubSpot research shows that the best way to organize content is through <a href=\"https://research.hubspot.com/topic-clusters-seo\">topic clusters</a>, meaning you create a long-form, comprehensive pillar page based on a keyword that then links to content you’ve created on related subtopics (think blog posts).</p> \n<p>To illustrate the point, it looks something like <a href=\"https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v%3DxOGxyw9DSa8&amp;sa=D&amp;ust=1531793246976000&amp;usg=AFQjCNE4n7Q0NmI5OO6vE8xnnmM_RWkUmQ\">this</a>.</p> \n<p>The topic cluster model makes brainstorming so much easier because now you have structure to follow (... told you we like processes). You can use your main keyword to create a pillar piece that covers that topic in depth, like … say a guide to content creation. Then, you can create shorter pieces of content — infographics, blog posts, templates — that help your audience dive deeper into the topic and target long-tail keywords.<span style=\"font-size: 1.1rem;\">&nbsp;</span></p> \n<p>If you’re stumped for ideas, you might want to consider looking for inspiration from books you’ve read, industry studies, your competitor’s sites, or related searches on SERPs.</p> \n<p>Once you have all of your ideas down, you can develop your <a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/editorial-calendar-templates\">editorial calendar</a> and start creating.</p> \n<h3>3. Writing</h3> \n<p>I’m going to talk about the writing process because … well, that’s what I do. <em>Your</em> specific content creation strength might be videos or graphics or podcasts. Whatever it is, the creation process follows some pretty similar guidelines:<span style=\"font-size: 1.1rem;\">&nbsp;</span></p> \n<ul> \n <li>Write to your persona. Use their voice, their euphemisms, even their humor to construct a piece that resonates.</li> \n <li>Use titles, meta descriptions, and other teasers to compel your audience to read your content. Put the benefit of your content <em>right</em> in the title to let them know why they should read it.</li> \n <li>Create something unique. Don’t simply regurgitate the information that’s already out there. Infuse a unique style or cite new research to emphasize your points.</li> \n <li>Stick to one idea and use your content to reinforce it. Don’t confuse your reader by going on tangents or trying to explain multiple semi-related topics in a single piece.</li> \n <li>Stay true to your voice. Don’t try to impress your audience with eloquent prose or an expansive vocabulary if <em>they</em> don’t speak that way.</li> \n <li>Be concise and clear. You want your audience to relate to you and derive value from your content … and not have to sift through jargon or confusing metaphors.</li> \n</ul> \n<p><strong>Featured Resource</strong></p> \n<ul> \n <li><a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/marketers-guide-to-writing-well?hubs_post-cta=inline-text\">HubSpot's Guide to Writing Well in Marketing</a></li> \n</ul> \n<h3>4. Editing</h3> \n<p>The way you edit your (or others’) work is a very subjective process. You may want to edit as you go, or you might wait a few days and review the work with fresh eyes. You might care a great deal about grammar, or you might aim for a more colloquial piece.<span style=\"font-size: 1.1rem;\">&nbsp;</span></p> \n<p>Either way, there are a few things that should definitely look out for as you refine your content, like active voice, clear language, short sentences, and plenty of whitespace. Consider having a colleague or manager review your work, too.<span style=\"font-size: 1.1rem;\">&nbsp;</span></p> \n<p>Some tools that will help you cut down on your editing time are <a href=\"https://app.grammarly.com/?network=g&amp;utm_source=google&amp;matchtype=b&amp;gclid=EAIaIQobChMIyZrNjNiX3AIVg8VkCh0EsgpcEAAYASAAEgL0oPD_BwE&amp;placement=&amp;q=grammar&amp;utm_content=244431933073&amp;utm_campaign=Search1&amp;utm_medium=cpc&amp;utm_term=%2Bhemingway+%2Bapp\">Grammarly</a> and <a href=\"http://www.hemingwayapp.com/\">Hemingway Editor</a>.</p> \n<h3>5. Uploading</h3> \n<p>Now that your content is ready, you’ll need to put it somewhere that people can access it. A content management system (CMS) is software that hosts digital content and allows you to display it on your website (or anywhere else on the web).<span style=\"font-size: 1.1rem;\">&nbsp;</span></p> \n<p>The benefit to a CMS is that it connects all of your content and stores it in one place. So, you can easily link to a landing page in your blog article or insert a content offer in an email. Not only that, but you can analyze the results of all the content you created for a specific campaign (which can help with content audits). A CMS saves you from having a disjointed content marketing system.</p> \n<p>For example, <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/products/marketing/content-optimization-system\">CMS Hub</a> is home to our blog, where you get access to all of our great content and useful free offers.</p> \n<h3>6. Publishing</h3> \n<p>Publishing content is as simple as clicking a button. So, why include a section on it? Well, because it’s not always that simple. Yes, you can publish your content immediately after uploading, or you can maximize its impact by waiting for an optimal time.</p> \n<p>If you’re just starting out, then clicking publish right away probably won’t impact your audience too much. But if you have committed to a regular publishing schedule, like delivering a new post every Wednesday, your audience will expect to see posts published on Wednesdays.</p> \n<p>Something else to keep in mind is to publish according to trends or time-sensitive events. For example, if you create content about national holidays or current events, then you’ll want to publish those at specific times.<span style=\"font-size: 1.1rem;\">&nbsp;</span></p> \n<p>A CMS will allow you schedule posts for a future date and specific time, so you can click, schedule, and forget.</p> \n<a></a> \n<h2><strong>Content Creation Tools</strong></h2> \n<p>While a CMS will help you manage your content, it won’t help you create it. That’s where content creation tools come in handy. These are especially useful if you’re artistically impaired, like me, or if you don’t have the capacity to hire help. From GIFs to infographics, these content creation tools will help you look like a professional, regardless of what kind of content you’re making.<span style=\"font-size: 1.1rem;\">&nbsp;</span></p> \n<p><a href=\"https://www.canva.com/\">Canva</a> will help you create beautiful designs for any platform, from social ads to Facebook cover photos to infographics. The software features aesthetically pleasing templates that you can customize with colors, images, and text ... for free.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://giphy.com/\">Giphy</a> The GIF has replaced emojis as a completely normal form of communication, and, therefore, an acceptable way to present content. Giphy allows you to search millions of pre-created GIFs in their database or even create your own.<span style=\"font-size: 1.1rem;\">&nbsp;</span></p> \n<p><a href=\"https://www.vidyard.com/\">Vidyard</a> is a video hosting platform that was made for marketers. The software allows you to customize your video by adding overlays, text, or CTA buttons, split test, transcribe, and has SEO features.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://www.surveymonkey.com/\">SurveyMonkey</a> is a leading survey creation platform. Why might you need such a thing? Because a good marketer knows that customer feedback is critical to an effective marketing campaign.<span style=\"font-size: 1.1rem;\">&nbsp;</span></p> \n<p><a href=\"https://www.makemypersona.com/\">MakeMyPersona</a> is HubSpot’s own nifty tool that will walk you through the process of creating your buyer persona. You can generate a document to reference throughout your content creation process.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://anchor.fm/\">Anchor</a> is the podcasting tool for beginners. It’s free, allows you to record and store unlimited episodes, and you can easily upload to any third-party platform.</p> \n<p>This is far from an exhaustive list of all the great content creation tools out there — <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/free-content-marketing-tools-list\">this list</a> is much better!</p> \n<a></a> \n<h2><strong>Creating a Content Plan</strong></h2> \n<p>Content exists everywhere, but its success relies on <em>your</em> ability to adapt it to the medium on which it lives. One size does not fit all when it comes to posting on different mediums — or the platforms within those mediums, for that matter.</p> \n<p>Social media content varies from blog content, which is different than website content. So, you need to know how to tailor your creation to reach your audience where they are.<span style=\"font-size: 1.1rem;\">&nbsp;</span></p> \n<p>Let’s dive into some guidelines for sharing content on various platforms.</p> \n<h3>Social Media Content</h3> \n<p>There is an art to <a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/social-media-content-creation\">creating content for social media</a>. But it’s well worth your time since there are <a href=\"https://www.statista.com/statistics/278414/number-of-worldwide-social-network-users/\">2.6 billion</a> users across social media platforms worldwide. Plus, someone who follows you on social media is like a warm lead — they already like you and are interested in what you have to say. So, you have an eager audience that’s ready to engage with your content.<span style=\"font-size: 1.1rem;\">&nbsp;</span></p> \n<p>Here are a few quick tips for creating content on some popular social channels.<span style=\"font-size: 1.1rem;\">&nbsp;</span></p> \n<p><strong>Facebook</strong> can be used to build micro communities via Facebook Groups or to share to a mass audience on Facebook Pages. When it comes to sharing content, questions and videos reap the most engagement.</p> \n<p><strong>Instagram</strong> is best for sharing high-quality imagery and short videos with brief captions. Hashtags work well on this platform as long as they’re relevant to your account and business. Instagram Stories has introduced a new way to engage with your followers, from quick polls to questions to real-time videos.<span style=\"font-size: 1.1rem;\">&nbsp;</span></p> \n<p><strong>YouTube</strong> has <a href=\"https://influencermarketinghub.com/12-best-types-of-youtube-content/\">1.3 billion users</a> and counting. Users frequent this platform to watch content ranging from DIY videos to parodies. Some of the most successful content on this platform are how-to guides, vlogs, product reviews, and educational videos.<span style=\"font-size: 1.1rem;\">&nbsp;</span></p> \n<p><strong>Featured Resources</strong></p> \n<ul> \n <li><a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/beginners-guide-to-video-marketing?hubs_post-cta=inline-text\">The Ultimate Video Marketing Starter Pack</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/youtube-for-business?hubs_post-cta=inline-text\">YouTube for Business: A 30-Day Roadmap for Channel Growth</a></li> \n</ul> \n<p><strong>Twitter</strong> best practices include short messages, supporting images, relevant hashtags, and retweets. And, of course, replies go a long way to win over your audience.</p> \n<h3>Website Content</h3> \n<p>Website content should focus on three things: your persona, your target keywords, and your solution. Not unlike your blog content, the copy on your website needs to guide visitors to your solution in a cohesive and natural way. Think of web content like a map to your product.</p> \n<p>Be careful not to turn visitors away through social media feeds and other distracting elements. Once you you’ve attracted a potential customer, you must do everything you can to keep them there, and that’s the key function of your website content.</p> \n<h3>Blog Content</h3> \n<p>The purpose of blog content is to support your business by attracting strangers and bringing in qualified leads. Blog content is a free resource that’s not often directly tied to sales, but don’t underestimate the power of a well-crafted blog to ultimately generate <a href=\"https://contentmarketinginstitute.com/2017/10/know-like-trust-content/\">revenue</a> for your business. Research shows that companies that blog more get more traffic and more leads than those that don’t.</p> \n<p><strong>Featured Resources</strong></p> \n<ul> \n <li><a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/how-to-start-a-successful-blog?hubs_post-cta=inline-text\">How to Start a Successful Blog</a></li> \n <li><a href=\"https://offers.hubspot.com/blog-post-templates?hubs_post-cta=inline-text\">5 Free Blog Post Templates</a></li> \n</ul> \n<a></a> \n<h2><strong>Analyzing Your Content</strong></h2> \n<p>The final, and arguably most important step in content creation is analyzing your content. Without data, you can’t know what’s working or how to improve it.</p> \n<p>There are several data points you could track when analyzing your content, so use your goals as a guide to set some parameters. Whatever you want to accomplish with your content will help you choose your metrics. (Remember that initial goal we talked about?)<span style=\"font-size: 1.1rem;\">&nbsp;</span></p> \n<p>What you analyze is completely up to you, but here are some ideas for metrics to track:</p> \n<ul> \n <li><strong>Page Views: </strong>the number of users that visit your content.</li> \n <li><strong>Organic Traffic:</strong>&nbsp;the amount of traffic that comes from search engines.</li> \n <li><strong>Bounce Rate:</strong>&nbsp;the percentage of visitors who leave your site after visiting only one page.</li> \n <li><strong>Conversion Rates:</strong>&nbsp;the percent of visitors that engage with a CTA.</li> \n <li><strong>Engagement Rates:</strong>&nbsp;the number of people that interact with your content through likes, shares, comments, or in other ways.</li> \n <li><strong>Audience Growth:</strong>&nbsp;the new subscribers or leads that are generated from a piece of content.&nbsp;</li> \n</ul> \n<p>If you need more tips on analyzing your content, check out this free <a href=\"https://academy.hubspot.com/lessons/measuring-and-analyzing-your-content\">HubSpot Academy course</a>.</p> \n<h2>Start Creating</h2> \n<p>Content creation is an iterative process that pays off tremendously with your audience. Once you have the content creation process down, you’ll be able to generate creative work that not only delights your audience but also grows your business.</p> \n<p><em>Editor's note: This post was originally published in August 2018 and has been updated for comprehensiveness.</em></p> \n<p></p> \n<p></p>  \n<img src=\"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&amp;k=14&amp;r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fcontent-creation&amp;bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&amp;bvt=rss\" alt=\"\" width=\"1\" height=\"1\" style=\"min-height:1px!important;width:1px!important;border-width:0!important;margin-top:0!important;margin-bottom:0!important;margin-right:0!important;margin-left:0!important;padding-top:0!important;padding-bottom:0!important;padding-right:0!important;padding-left:0!important; \">","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Mon, 19 Oct 2020 11:00:00 +0000","feedId":54,"bgimg":"https://lh5.googleusercontent.com/IGJVUQefJ4EBBW2vSYn2EoRA_b20ZkRLB6FngQc7Df8L9kiAnv1xpjxyb3n-P-YY9EB5bBUq-acrqbZoJZwuDPBKzQsRCHYiMrTcry4JCX1qcGVTstjJVsmum7LmTMo3iGo6XIPc","linkMd5":"d5db035b7aac610bff8bdf18ee89d26b","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn60@2020_6/2020/10/27/16-53-45-256_9b4b5a261169de61.webp","destWidth":1600,"destHeight":1010,"sourceBytes":189968,"destBytes":144842,"author":"cperricone@hubspot.com (Christina Perricone)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://lh5.googleusercontent.com/IGJVUQefJ4EBBW2vSYn2EoRA_b20ZkRLB6FngQc7Df8L9kiAnv1xpjxyb3n-P-YY9EB5bBUq-acrqbZoJZwuDPBKzQsRCHYiMrTcry4JCX1qcGVTstjJVsmum7LmTMo3iGo6XIPc":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn60@2020_6/2020/10/27/16-53-45-256_9b4b5a261169de61.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fcontent-creation&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx23/cdn6@2020_6/2020/10/27/16-54-01-023_8e04dfcf0598f038.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1603817624926},{"createdTime":"2020-10-28 00:53:44","updatedTime":"2020-10-28 00:53:44","title":"Phone Photography 101: How to Take Good Pictures With Your Mobile Device","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/good-pictures-phone-tips","description":"<p>Before the days of smartphones — if you can remember such a time — taking a great photo was a labor-intensive process. You'd have to buy a fancy camera and editing software for your desktop computer, and invest some serious time and energy into learning how to use them.</p> \n<p>But, thanks to our mobile devices and the editing apps that come with them, we can now take high-quality photos and edit them without too many bells and whistles — all from the same device that we use to make calls.</p> \n<p>Brands are catching on, too — these kinds of <a href=\"https://cdn2.hubspot.net/hubfs/53/HubSpot-State-of-Inbound-Report-2016.pdf?__hstc=20629287.857e77756cee829a859f9012da7eee4e.1469131805634.1474043741200.1474046603726.36&amp;hsCtaTracking=7b8dec0c-af54-4700-899c-3d4907a5cdc4%7C323c7216-def8-4f80-bb32-0ec9964b65f3\">visuals remain important to marketing</a>. But make no mistake: Taking a great photo on your smartphone is not as simple as pointing and shooting. There are plenty of bad smartphone photos out there — I'm sure you've seen at least a few.</p> \n<p>What's the secret to taking great pictures with your smartphone, then? As it turns out, there are a few of them. Check out these tips below to improve your smartphone photography game. (And once you have the photo-taking part down, <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/photo-video-editing-apps-mobile\">check out some of the best photo editing apps for mobile</a>.)</p> \n<p class=\"p1\"></p> \n<h2><strong>How to Take Good Photos With Your Phone: 25 Tips &amp; Tricks</strong></h2> \n<h3>1. Use gridlines to balance your shot.</h3> \n<p>One of the easiest and best ways to improve your mobile photos is to turn on the camera's gridlines. That superimposes a series of lines on the screen of your smartphone's camera that are based on the \"<a href=\"http://digital-photography-school.com/rule-of-thirds/\">rule of thirds</a>\" — a photographic composition principle that says an image should be broken down into thirds, both horizontally and vertically, so you have nine parts in total.</p> \n<p>According to this theory, if you place points of interest in these intersections or along the lines, your photo will be more balanced, level, and allow viewers to interact with it more naturally.</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/rule-of-thirds.jpg?width=560&amp;name=rule-of-thirds.jpg\" alt=\"rule-of-thirds.jpg\" title=\"rule-of-thirds.jpg\" width=\"560\" style=\"width: 560px; margin: 0px auto;\"></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><em style=\"color: inherit; font-size: 12px;\">Source: <a href=\"http://digital-photography-school.com/rule-of-thirds/\">Digital Photography School</a></em></p> \n<p>To switch the grid on ...</p> \n<ul> \n <li><strong>iPhone:</strong> Go to \"Settings,\" choose \"Photos &amp; Camera,\" and switch \"Grid\" on.</li> \n <li><strong>Samsung Galaxy:</strong> Launch the camera app, go to \"Settings,\" scroll down and switch the \"grid lines\" option to \"on.\"</li> \n</ul> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/gridlines.jpg?width=600&amp;name=gridlines.jpg\" alt=\"gridlines.jpg\" title=\"gridlines.jpg\" width=\"600\" style=\"width: 600px; margin: 0px auto;\"></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><span style=\"font-size: 12px;\"><em>Source: <a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zEpKOHqELAM\">Lynda.com</a></em></span></p> \n<h3>2. Set your camera's focus.</h3> \n<p>Today's phone cameras automatically focus on the foreground of your frame, but not every picture you take on your phone has an obvious subject. To adjust where you want your camera lens to focus, open your camera app and tap the screen where you want to sharpen the view.</p> \n<p>If you're taking a photo of something in motion, for example, it can be difficult for your camera to follow this subject and refocus as needed. Tap the screen to correct your phone camera's focus just before snapping the picture to ensure the moving subject has as much focus as possible. A square or circular icon should then appear on your camera screen, shifting the focus of your shot to all of the content inside that icon.</p> \n<h3>3. Focus on one subject.</h3> \n<p>Many of the best photos include just one, interesting subject. So when taking a picture of one, spend some extra time setting up the shot. Some professional photographers say that the subject <a href=\"http://www.photokonnexion.com/the-simple-secrets-of-the-single-subject-shot/\">shouldn't fill the entire frame, and that two-thirds of the photo should be negative space</a> — that helps the subject stand out even more.</p> \n<p>But be sure you tap the screen of your smartphone to focus the camera on your subject — that'll help to ensure that it's focused and the lighting is optimized.</p> \n<p><strong>Pro Tip: </strong>Once you've taken your photo, you can use filters and apps to make the subject even more vivid, or to crop it to frame the subject correctly. The brightness, contrast, and saturation of the photo can also be adjusted accordingly — all from your phone.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/patrick-2.png?width=1612&amp;name=patrick-2.png\" alt=\"@aguynamedpatrick instagram picture of himself in mirror holding a phone taking a picture of himself\" width=\"1612\" style=\"width: 1612px;\"></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><span style=\"font-size: 12px;\"><em>Source: <a href=\"https://www.instagram.com/aguynamedpatrick/\">Patrick Janelle</a></em></span></p> \n<h3>4. Embrace negative space.</h3> \n<p>\"Negative space\" simply refers to the areas around and between the subjects of an image — and it can take a photo from \"good\" to \"great.\"</p> \n<p>When you include a lot of empty space in a photo, your subject will stand out more and evoke a stronger reaction from your viewer. And what does negative space looks like? It's often a large expanse of open sky, an empty field, a large wall, or water, as in the example below.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/eric%20christian.png?width=1618&amp;name=eric%20christian.png\" alt=\"eric christian in front of an ocean on instagram\" width=\"1618\" style=\"width: 1618px;\"></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><span style=\"font-size: 12px;\"><em>Source: <a href=\"https://www.instagram.com/ericchristian/\">Eric Christian</a></em></span></p> \n<h3>5. Find different perspectives.</h3> \n<p>Taking photos from a unique, unexpected angle can make them more memorable — it tends to create an illusion of depth or height with the subjects. It also makes the image stand out, since most mobile photos are taken either straight -on or from a bird's eye view.</p> \n<p>Try taking a photo directly upward and playing with the sky as negative space, like in the first photo below. Or, you can try taking it at a slight downward angle.</p> \n<p><strong>Pro Tip:</strong> If you take a photo and find the perspective is a little askew or tilted, use the <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/photo-video-editing-apps-mobile\">SKRWT photo editing app</a> to make the lines look clean and square.</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/bookshelf-perspective.png?width=599&amp;name=bookshelf-perspective.png\" alt=\"bookshelf-perspective.png\" title=\"bookshelf-perspective.png\" width=\"599\" style=\"width: 599px; margin: 0px auto;\"></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><span style=\"font-size: 12px;\"><em>Source: <a href=\"http://iphonephotographyschool.com/architecture/\">iPhone Photography School</a>; <a href=\"https://www.instagram.com/p/y70fRQoAqa/?taken-by=pauloctavious\">Paul Octavious</a></em></span></p> \n<h3>6. Play with reflections.</h3> \n<p>There's something so idyllic about seeing the sky reflected in a body of water. There's a reason why we love seeing that — our eyes are drawn to reflections. So look for opportunities to play with them in photos.</p> \n<p>There are plenty of out-of-the-box places to find reflections — puddles, larger bodies of water, mirrors, sunglasses, drinking glasses, and metallic surfaces are just a few.</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/capture-reflections.png?width=599&amp;name=capture-reflections.png\" alt=\"capture-reflections.png\" title=\"capture-reflections.png\" width=\"599\" style=\"width: 599px; margin: 0px auto;\"></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><span style=\"font-size: 12px;\"><em>Source: <a href=\"https://www.instagram.com/p/yAonfphKvR/\">Joshua Lott</a></em></span></p> \n<h3>7. Use leading lines.</h3> \n<p>In some photos, there's a line that draws the viewer's eye toward a certain part of the frame. Those are called leading lines. They can be straight or circulinear — think staircases, building facades, train tracks, roads, or even a path through the woods.</p> \n<p>Leading lines are great for creating a sense of depth in an image, and can make your photo look purposefully designed — even if you just happened to come upon a really cool shape by accident.</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/leading-lines-path.png?width=599&amp;name=leading-lines-path.png\" alt=\"leading-lines-path.png\" title=\"leading-lines-path.png\" width=\"599\" style=\"width: 599px; margin: 0px auto;\"></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><span style=\"font-size: 12px;\"><em>Source: <a href=\"https://www.instagram.com/p/srHhAzpMLj/?taken-by=carloscopertone\">Carlos Copertone</a></em></span></p> \n<h3>8. Look for symmetry.</h3> \n<p>Symmetry can be <a href=\"https://books.google.com/books?id=DxmcCgAAQBAJ&amp;pg=PA24&amp;lpg=PA24&amp;dq=%E2%80%9CSymmetry+is+a+vague+sense+of+harmonious+and+beautiful+proportion+and+balance%E2%80%9D.&amp;source=bl&amp;ots=Ms5K2cCG4a&amp;sig=m6qY0wE_lVbWxPdvHkp3-9GDB3E&amp;hl=en&amp;sa=X&amp;ved=0ahUKEwjV___Ms6fJAhVHGT4KHdJoAvkQ6AEIKjAC\">defined</a> as \"a vague sense of harmonious and beautiful proportion and balance.\" And pictures that contain symmetry can be incredibly pleasing to the eye — it's also one of the simplest and most compelling ways to compose a photo.</p> \n<p>In photography, <a href=\"http://www.school-of-digital-photography.com/2014/01/using-symmetry-to-improve-your-photography-composition.html\">symmetry usually means</a> creating an image that can be divided into two equal parts that are mirror images of each other. That's a bit different than reflections — symmetry can be found \"in the wild,\" as per the staircase picture, or you can set up your photo accordingly, like photographer Eric Christian did in the first photo below.</p> \n<p>And remember — use those gridlines from tip #1 to line everything up perfectly.</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/symmetry.png?width=600&amp;name=symmetry.png\" alt=\"symmetry.png\" title=\"symmetry.png\" width=\"600\" style=\"width: 600px; margin: 0px auto;\"></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><span style=\"font-size: 12px;\"><em>Source: <a href=\"https://www.instagram.com/p/6plxSXvOFr/?taken-by=ericchristian\">Eric Christian</a></em></span></p> \n<h3>9. Keep an eye out for repetitive patterns.</h3> \n<p>Repetitive patterns are very pleasing to the eye — they appear whenever strong graphic elements are repeated over and over again, like lines, geometric shapes, forms, and colors. These patterns can make a strong visual impact, and photographing something like a beautiful, tiled floor can be enough to create a striking image. Other times, it's more fun to keep an eye out for where they appear naturally or unintentionally, like with the congruent fire escapes on the left.</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/soup-pattern.png?width=598&amp;name=soup-pattern.png\" alt=\"soup-pattern.png\" title=\"soup-pattern.png\" width=\"598\" style=\"width: 598px; margin: 0px auto;\"></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><span style=\"font-size: 12px;\"><em>Source: <a href=\"https://www.instagram.com/aguynamedpatrick/\">Patrick Janelle</a></em></span></p> \n<h3>10. Play around with color blocking.</h3> \n<p>Isn't it cool when an entire photo is black and white, except for a single object? It turns out that yes, indeed, there are apps for that. One of our favorites is <a href=\"https://itunes.apple.com/us/app/touch-color-black-white-partial/id560810455?mt=8\">Touch Color</a> — an app that automatically converts a picture to grayscale and lets you fill in the parts you want to colorize.</p> \n<p>Color blocking can help to highlight the elements of a photo that you want to stand out, like a plant or something else with a bold hue. It achieves a similar goal as negative space, in that it can help a single subject stand out — but with color blocking, the photo's other elements remain intact for a cohesive image.</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><em><span style=\"font-size: 12px;\"><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/img_3845-copy.jpg?width=600&amp;name=img_3845-copy.jpg\" width=\"600\" title=\"img_3845-copy.jpg\" style=\"width: 600px; margin: 0px auto;\" alt=\"Grayscaled photo taken on mobile camera with color blocking to reveal purple flower in woman's hand\"></span></em></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><em><span style=\"font-size: 12px;\">Source: <a href=\"http://coloring.mibanquero.com/how-to-make-color-photos-black-and-white/\">Coloring Pages</a></span></em></p> \n<h3>11. Avoid zooming in.</h3> \n<p>When you take a photo from a distance, it's tempting to zoom in on something specific you're trying to capture. But it's actually better <em>not</em> to zoom in — doing so can make the photo appear grainy, blurry, or pixelated.</p> \n<p>Instead, try to get closer to your subject — unless it's a wild animal, in which case we would advise keeping your distance — or take the photo from a default distance, and crop it later on. That way, you won't compromise quality, and it's easier to play around or optimize a larger image.</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/crop-photo-1.jpg?width=600&amp;name=crop-photo-1.jpg\" alt=\"crop-photo-1.jpg\" title=\"crop-photo-1.jpg\" width=\"600\" style=\"width: 600px; margin: 0px auto;\"></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><span style=\"font-size: 12px;\"><em>Source: <a href=\"http://obamapacman.com/2011/10/apple-iphone-4s-icloud-camera-siri-tv-ads/\">Obama Pacman</a></em></span></p> \n<h3>12. Capture small details.</h3> \n<p>You may have heard the phrase, \"It's the little things.\" Sometimes, that also applies to photos. Close-up images that capture small, intricate, and delicate details can make for really compelling visual content. Keep an eye out for textures and patterns like peeling paint, a gravel road, or a tile tabletop.</p> \n<p><strong>Pro Tip: </strong>Use the \"sharpen\" tool <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/photo-video-editing-apps-mobile\">in your favorite photo editing app</a> to (conservatively) sharpen the details of your photo. You might also download the Camera+ app and use its Clarity filter, which is what <em><a href=\"http://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052702303816504577305702578426084\">The Wall Street Journal</a></em><a href=\"http://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052702303816504577305702578426084\">'s Kevin Sintumuang calls</a> the app's \"secret sauce — it adds pro-camera crispness to almost any shot.\"</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/tile-patterns.png?width=599&amp;name=tile-patterns.png\" alt=\"tile-patterns.png\" title=\"tile-patterns.png\" width=\"599\" style=\"width: 599px; margin: 0px auto;\"></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><span style=\"font-size: 12px;\"><em><em>Source: </em><a href=\"https://www.instagram.com/p/204_lWPOI2/?taken-by=ericchristian\">Eric Christian</a></em></span></p> \n<h3>13. Use natural light.</h3> \n<p>It's hard to find a great smartphone photo that was taken with a flash. Most of the time, they make a photo look overexposed, negatively altering colors and making human subjects look washed out. In fact, even the iPhone 7's flash is <a href=\"http://www.pcmag.com/article/347907/iphone-7-plus-vs-iphone-6s-vs-galaxy-s7-cameras-compared\">rumored to have some flaws</a>.</p> \n<p>Take advantage of the sources of natural light you can find, even after dark. This gives you a chance to play with shadows, like in the second image below, or create a silhouette with other ambient sources of light, like traffic and surrounding buildings.</p> \n<p>Once you've taken the photo, play with the \"Exposure\" tool <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/photo-video-editing-apps-mobile\">in your favorite photo editing app</a> to see if you can make the image slightly brighter, without making it too grainy.</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/no-flash-flower.png?width=596&amp;name=no-flash-flower.png\" alt=\"no-flash-flower.png\" title=\"no-flash-flower.png\" width=\"596\" style=\"width: 596px; margin: 0px auto;\"></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><span style=\"font-size: 12px;\"><em>Source: <a href=\"https://www.instagram.com/p/tDM9R1oAte/?taken-by=pauloctavious\">Paul Octavious</a></em></span></p> \n<h3>14. If you use flash, only do so during the day.</h3> \n<p>Sometimes, using your camera's flash can improve a photo — but rarely does it do so at night. Because dark shots reveal a much sharper contrast against your phone's flash, it can make any flash look look invasive and uneven</p> \n<p>In already well-lit spaces, however, a flash can help to soften some dark shadows behind or beneath your main subject.</p> \n<p>When framing your next shot, look on the ground or against vertical surfaces for any dark shadows you might want to remove. If you see any, flip on the flash manually in your camera app. Setting your phone's camera flash to \"auto\" won't guarantee that your phone will notice the shadows you want to get rid of. Just remember to turn the flash off again when you're done.</p> \n<p>Consider the importance of flash for enhancing or hiding certain lines and features the next time you're shooting <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/product-photography-tips\">product photography</a>.</p> \n<h3>15. Consider buying a mobile tripod.</h3> \n<p>Although mobile devices make it easy to snap any photo on the go, there's never been an easy way to ensure the shot stays level and balanced when you shoot — especially if you want to be in the picture and not just take a typical selfie with your extended arm.</p> \n<p>Mobile tripods give you the freedom to mount your smartphone for quick hands-free shots without lugging any heavy equipment with you. Most mobile tripods are barely bigger than your mobile device, and can bend to any angle. Check out one of them from Joby, above, and learn how these miniature tripods can help enhance your mobile <em>video</em> experience below.</p> \n<div class=\"hs-responsive-embed-wrapper hs-responsive-embed\" style=\"width: 100%; height: auto; position: relative; overflow: hidden; padding: 0; max-width: 640px; max-height: 380px; min-width: 256px; margin: 0px auto; display: block;\"> \n <div class=\"hs-responsive-embed-inner-wrapper\" style=\"position: relative; overflow: hidden; max-width: 100%; padding-bottom: 59.38%; margin: 0;\">\n  <iframe class=\"hs-responsive-embed-iframe\" style=\"position: absolute; top: 0; left: 0; width: 100%; height: 100%; border: none;\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/anWNGQNr8DM?ecver=1\" width=\"640\" height=\"380\" frameborder=\"0\" allowfullscreen></iframe>\n </div> \n</div> \n<h3>16. Set your camera app's exposure manually.</h3> \n<p>Another mobile camera feature you'll want to set manually is your exposure. Tapping your screen when your phone's camera is on doesn't just refocus the lens on a new subject — it also automatically adjusts how much light the camera lets in. This, too, won't always look just right. It's best to adjust it by hand.</p> \n<p>To change your mobile camera's exposure by hand, open your camera app and tap the screen. When you see the lens refocus, you'll see a very small sun icon and a vertical scale. Slowly swipe your finger up and down this scale to adjust the light level.</p> \n<h3>17. Create abstracts.</h3> \n<p>Abstract photos are meant to capture the essence of an object, or a series of them, without revealing the entire landscape as a whole. In other words, they serve the purpose of creating unique, surprising images from ordinary subjects.</p> \n<p>This look can be accomplished by cropping an abstract portion of an otherwise normal photo, or by taking close-up shots of objects that leave the viewer wondering — in admiration, of course — what the subject might be. And subjects with patterns or repetition are great candidates for abstract photography, like in the photo of sliced figs below.</p> \n<p><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/abstract-architecture.jpg?width=560&amp;name=abstract-architecture.jpg\" alt=\"abstract-architecture.jpg\" title=\"abstract-architecture.jpg\" width=\"560\" style=\"width: 560px; margin: 0px auto; display: block;\"></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><span style=\"font-size: 12px;\"><em>Source: <a href=\"http://iphonephotographyschool.com/architecture/\">iPhone Photography School</a></em></span></p> \n<h3>18. Take candids.</h3> \n<p>Posed photos can be great for the sake of memories — happy moments with friends, family, or the occasional run-in with a celebrity. But sometimes, candid shots of people doing things, or people with people, can be far more interesting.</p> \n<p>That's because candid photos are better able to effectively capture the emotion and essence of a moment. One of the best ways to capture this kind of shot is to just take as many photos as possible. You'll have more to choose from, and the best photos often happen when the \"stars align,\" so to speak, in a single moment — everyone's eyes are open, one person is tilting their head just so, and you finally got a shot of your chronically closed-lip friend smiling with his teeth.</p> \n<p><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/eating-candid.png?width=597&amp;name=eating-candid.png\" alt=\"eating-candid.png\" title=\"eating-candid.png\" width=\"597\" style=\"width: 597px; margin: 0px auto; display: block;\"></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><span style=\"font-size: 12px;\"><em>Source: <a href=\"https://www.instagram.com/aguynamedpatrick/\">Patrick Janelle</a></em></span></p> \n<h3>19. Be non-conventional.</h3> \n<p>Composition is a huge part of what makes a photo great, but so is the photo's subject. Some of the most delightful and remarkable photos come out of cool, unique ideas. <a href=\"https://www.liveplan.com/blog/2016/01/scientific-reasons-why-you-should-present-your-data-visually/\">Images are more effective than text at evoking emotion</a> from your viewers — that often means getting your photos to <em>say </em>something.</p> \n<p>Try thinking outside of the box when it comes to what you're capturing — your viewers could be pleasantly surprised by a cool or unexpected subject.</p> \n<p><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/leaf-dog-constellation.png?width=599&amp;name=leaf-dog-constellation.png\" alt=\"leaf-dog-constellation.png\" title=\"leaf-dog-constellation.png\" width=\"599\" style=\"width: 599px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\"></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><span style=\"font-size: 12px;\"><em>Source: <a href=\"https://www.instagram.com/pauloctavious/\">Paul Octavious</a></em></span></p> \n<h3>20. Make 'em laugh.</h3> \n<p>Speaking of evoking emotion, sometimes the most memorable photos are the ones that make us giggle. The image below of an older woman wearing a brightly-colored shirt stating \"Hi hater\" is funny because it's unexpected — and there's a part of us that admires her, too. The second image of the dog toy on a dinner plate pokes fun at classic Instagram food shots, but it's from a dog's perspective. If you can make your audience laugh, they're likely to enjoy your photo.</p> \n<p><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/pug-eating-toy.png?width=597&amp;name=pug-eating-toy.png\" alt=\"pug-eating-toy.png\" title=\"pug-eating-toy.png\" width=\"597\" style=\"width: 597px; margin: 0px auto; display: block;\"></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><span style=\"font-size: 12px;\"><em>Source: <a href=\"https://www.instagram.com/p/4R-6wiCgy7/?taken-by=jermzlee\">Jeremy Veach</a></em></span></p> \n<h3>21. Clean your phone's lens.</h3> \n<p>A smartphone camera might be more convenient to carry around than a full-fledged photojournalist's camera, but it comes at the cost of protection.</p> \n<p>Your phone is usually in your pocket or your bag when you're out of the house. All the while, the device's camera lens is collecting all kinds of dust and lint. Be sure to clean this lens with a soft handkerchief before taking a photo. You might not be able to tell just how dirty the lens was until you start editing your picture, and making sure the lens is crystal clear before taking a shot can keep you from starting from scratch.</p> \n<h3>22. Attach an external lens.</h3> \n<p>Want to get really fancy? External lenses are for you. There are actually several out there that can be attached to the top of your smartphone's native camera lens — from fish-eye to wide-angle lenses, these add-ons can bring an entirely new quality and perspective to your photos.</p> \n<p><a href=\"http://thewirecutter.com/reviews/best-lenses-for-iphone/\">According to Wirecutter</a>, the best camera lenses for iPhone photography are made by <a href=\"https://momentlens.co\">Moment</a>, a manufacturer of mobile lenses. Start there, or do some research to find the lens add-ons that fit your smartphone photography needs.</p> \n<p><img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/fish-eye-horses.jpg?width=504&amp;name=fish-eye-horses.jpg\" alt=\"Horses looking into fisheye external lens attached to phone camera\" title=\"fish-eye-horses.jpg\" width=\"504\" style=\"width: 504px; margin: 0px auto; display: block;\"></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><span style=\"font-size: 12px;\"><em>Source: <a href=\"http://www.mobilefun.co.uk/thumbsup-fish-eye-lens-for-iphone-4-5-5s-p39297.htm\">MobileFun.co.uk</a></em></span></p> \n<h3>23. Don't be afraid to edit.</h3> \n<p>Composing and taking your smartphone photo is just the first step to making it visually compelling. Editing your photos is the next step — and a very critical one, at that. Filters can be a valuable photographic tool, particularly when it comes to two goals: 1) Removing blemishes from a picture, and 2) making food look even more delicious.</p> \n<p>For the first, <em>InStyle</em> magazine compiled a fun list of \"<a href=\"http://www.instyle.com/news/instagram-filters-beauty-complaints\">The Best Instagram Filters for Every Beauty Complaint</a>\" — and now, the <a href=\"http://www.apple.com/ios/photos/\">iPhone photos app</a> offers many similar filters. There are also apps like <a href=\"http://makeup.pho.to/\">Pho.to</a>, which can automatically retouch facial photos without a lot of work. And when it comes to those photos of your daily meals? One of the latest apps available is <a href=\"https://linecorp.com/en/pr/news/en/2016/1236\">Foodie</a>, which comes with its own set of filters optimized for different types of food.</p> \n<p>But there are many other great photo and video editing apps out there for mobile devices — check out <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/photo-video-editing-apps-mobile?_ga=1.120640904.1053898511.1470656920\">this post</a> to see some of the best ones out there.</p> \n<img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/51b3f40f.png?width=730&amp;height=365&amp;name=51b3f40f.png\" alt=\"51b3f40f.png\" width=\"730\" height=\"365\"> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><em><span style=\"font-size: 12px;\">Source: <a href=\"http://official-blog.line.me/en/archives/1052175945.html\">LINE Corp.</a></span></em></p> \n<p>Want more tips on creating visual content? Check out these <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/explainer-videos\">examples of explainer videos</a>.</p> \n<p>Editor's note: This post was originally published in November 2018 and has been updated for comprehensiveness.</p>  \n<div>\n <a class=\"close\"> </a>\n</div>  \n<img photo-1.jpg?width=600&name=crop-photo-1.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn65@2020_3/2020/10/27/16-53-53-796_a786feaf65c36084.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/tile-patterns.png?width=599&name=tile-patterns.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn11@2020_3/2020/10/27/16-53-47-984_7b8e28cc8ff3ff13.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/no-flash-flower.png?width=596&name=no-flash-flower.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn18@2020_4/2020/10/27/16-53-52-897_1af562824ac35af9.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/abstract-architecture.jpg?width=560&name=abstract-architecture.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn79@2020_3/2020/10/27/16-53-47-823_5f104735490305c5.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/eating-candid.png?width=597&name=eating-candid.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn56@2020_5/2020/10/27/16-53-50-925_d7aa5aff7a9cd294.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/leaf-dog-constellation.png?width=599&name=leaf-dog-constellation.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn32@2020_4/2020/10/27/16-53-50-775_b895a5ba5415fe4a.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/pug-eating-toy.png?width=597&name=pug-eating-toy.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn25@2020_2/2020/10/27/16-53-54-729_5d7387560aac529f.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/fish-eye-horses.jpg?width=504&name=fish-eye-horses.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn20@2020_4/2020/10/27/16-54-12-278_42c6d94930239307.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/51b3f40f.png?width=730&height=365&name=51b3f40f.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn70@2020_5/2020/10/27/16-54-02-509_5d669ba300a614e9.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fgood-pictures-phone-tips&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn21@2020_6/2020/10/27/16-54-05-123_4af96071cf52ad8a.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1603817624923},{"createdTime":"2020-10-28 00:53:44","updatedTime":"2020-10-28 00:53:44","title":"60 Best Free Online Courses For Whatever You Want to Learn","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/free-online-courses","description":"<p>Benjamin Franklin once said, “An investment in knowledge always pays the best interest.”</p> \n<p>That’s never been truer than it is today. With new technology emerging at breakneck speeds, there's a palpable pressure to continuously upskill.</p> \n<p>Whether you want that job promotion or to sidestep into a new field, you'll need to commit to learning new skills.</p> \n<p>However, learning new skills can be both time-consuming and challenging. In fact, according to Josh Kaufman, international bestselling author of <em><a href=\"https://personalmba.com/\">The Personal MBA</a></em>, it takes 20 hours to go from knowing nothing about a particular subject to being pretty good at it. Of course, if you want to become an expert -- well, that takes even longer.</p> \n<p>Blog posts and podcasts are great starting points for exploring a particular topic. But <a href=\"https://academy.hubspot.com/?_ga=2.260036746.1838187926.1557323413-644648569.1551722047\">online business courses</a> will provide you with the time and space you need to go deep and truly <em>master</em> a new skill. Plus, most courses are made up of on-demand videos and exercises that you can progress through at your own pace.</p> \n<p></p> \n<p>Below, we've gathered 60 of the best free online business courses. These cover the main business skills you'll need to advance in today's rapidly changing workplace -- from digital marketing and coding to selling, leadership, and more.
