It doesn't matter whether you are a first time manager in a shop or a middle manager in an office environment -- the same skills apply to every work place.</p> \n<h4><strong>47. <a href=\"https://alison.com/course/What-Great-Leaders-Do\">What Great Leaders Do</a> by Alison</strong></h4> \n<p><strong>Length: 1.5-3 Hours</strong></p> \n<p>Professor Bob Sutton outlines the hallmarks of great leaders, why leaders need to hear the truth, and how to deal with team disagreements. You will learn the types of habits practiced by those who fail to lead, and gain a strong understanding of how to become a better group leader.</p> \n<h4><strong>48. <a href=\"https://www.udemy.com/course/project-management-101-pm101/\">Introduction to Project Management</a> by Udemy</strong></h4> \n<p><strong>Length: 1:37 Hours</strong></p> \n<p>This course offers essential project management tools and techniques.</p> \n<h4><strong>49. <a href=\"https://www.coursera.org/learn/conflict-resolution-skills\">Conflict Resolution Skills</a> by Coursera</strong></h4> \n<p><strong>Length: ~4 Hours</strong></p> \n<p>Learn listening skills, verbal and non-verbal communication skills, and how to assemble a conflict management plan likely to yield positive resolutions.</p> \n<h4><strong>50. <a href=\"https://www.coursera.org/specializations/career-success\">Career Success Specialization</a> by Coursera</strong></h4> \n<p><strong>Length: ~1 Hour / Week (11 Months)</strong></p> \n<p>Build essential skills for the workplace. Improve your employability and advance in today's dynamic workforce.</p> \n<h4><strong>51. <a href=\"https://www.edx.org/course/the-science-of-happiness-0\">The Science of Happiness</a> by EdX</strong></h4> \n<p><strong>Length: 4-5 Hours / Week (11 Weeks)</strong></p> \n<p>A free eight-week Science of Happiness course that will offer practical, research-backed tips on living a happy and meaningful life.</p> \n<h4><strong>52. <a href=\"https://www.coursera.org/learn/the-science-of-well-being\">The Science of Wellbeing</a> by Coursera</strong></h4> \n<p><strong>Length: ~19 Hours</strong></p> \n<p>The purpose of this course is to not only learn what psychological research says about what makes us happy, but also to put those strategies into practice.</p> \n<a></a> \n<p>&nbsp;</p> \n<h3 style=\"text-align: center;\"><strong>Design Courses</strong></h3> \n<h4><strong>53. <a href=\"https://academy.hubspot.com/courses/graphic-design\">Graphic Design Essentials</a> by HubSpot Academy</strong></h4> \n<p><strong>Length: 44 Minutes</strong></p> \n<p>Need to become a graphic designer? Have less than an hour? This course by HubSpot Academy offers basic concepts in graphic design that have proven to be excellent marketing strategies.&nbsp;</p> \n<h4><strong>54. <a href=\"https://www.eduonix.com/adobe-illustrator-for-absolute-beginners?coupon_code=OSUFREE\">Adobe Illustrator for Absolute Beginners</a> by EduOnix</strong></h4> \n<p><strong>Length: 5 Hours</strong></p> \n<p>Learn how to master Adobe Illustrator with real world examples.</p> \n<a></a> \n<p>&nbsp;</p> \n<h3 style=\"text-align: center;\"><strong>Business &amp; Finance Courses</strong></h3> \n<h4><strong>55. <a href=\"https://smart.ly/the-free-mba\">Free Online MBA</a> by Smartly</strong></h4> \n<p><strong>Length: 5-15 Hours / Week (11 Months)</strong></p> \n<p>Designed with business professors from top residential MBA programs, Smartly's proprietary curriculum combines a self-guided software approach with collaborative online case studies and group projects. It's flexible, yet structured for the modern professional.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Screen%20Shot%202019-05-08%20at%2012.31.18%20PM.png?width=1492&amp;name=Screen%20Shot%202019-05-08%20at%2012.31.18%20PM.png\" alt=\"Smartly screenshot\" width=\"1492\" style=\"width: 1492px; display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\" /></p> \n<h4><strong>56. <a href=\"https://www.coursera.org/learn/uva-darden-foundations-business-strategy\">Foundations of Business Strategy</a> by Coursera</strong></h4> \n<p><strong>Length: ~9 Hours</strong></p> \n<p>Develop your ability to think strategically, analyze the competitive environment, and recommend firm positioning and value creation. In this course, you'll explore the underlying theory and foundation of a successful business strategy, and gain the tools you need to understand that strategy.</p> \n<h4><strong>57. <a href=\"https://www.udacity.com/course/how-to-build-a-startup--ep245\">How to Build a Startup</a> by Udacity</strong></h4> \n<p><strong>Length: ~1 Month</strong></p> \n<p>In an introduction to the basics of the famous Customer Development Process, Steve Blank provides insight into the key steps needed to build a successful start-up.</p> \n<h4><strong>58. <a href=\"https://alison.com/course/Diploma-in-E-Business\">Alison Free Diploma in E-Business</a> by Alison</strong></h4> \n<p><strong>Length: 6-10 Hours</strong></p> \n<p>This course is designed to boost your understanding of what e-business involves and how to implement a successful e-business strategy, so that the website you manage truly delivers.</p> \n<h4><strong>59. <a href=\"https://www.udemy.com/the-beginners-guide-to-the-stock-market/\">Stock Market Investing for Beginners</a> by Udemy</strong></h4> \n<p><strong>Length: 1:29 Hours</strong></p> \n<p>Learn the basics of the stock market through comprehensive, interesting and fun lectures.</p> \n<h4><strong>60. <a href=\"https://itunes.apple.com/us/course/corporate-finance-spring-2015/id959944936\">Corporate Finance by New York University</a> by iTunes</strong></h4> \n<p><strong>Length: Self-Paced</strong></p> \n<p>Corporate Finance is a big picture class. It looks at the financial principles that govern how businesses raise funds, invest those funds in assets and projects, and return those funds to investors.</p> \n<h3><strong>Learning is an investment that continues to pay </strong></h3> \n<p>We hope you find the online business course you need to take the next step in your career -- whether you're looking for a promotion or a sidestep into an entirely new field.</p> \n<p>Whatever your reason, learning new skills will give you a competitive advantage in today's rapidly changing workplace. Plus, the more you invest in your learning, the better you'll grow.</p> \n<p>If you're looking for one single place to learn how to take your career to the next level and/or grow your business, check out HubSpot Academy. It contains tons of free certified courses on everything from inbound and content marketing to social media and sales.</p> \n<p><em>Editor's note: This post was originally published in January 2020 and has been updated for comprehensiveness.</em></p> \n<p></p> \n<img src=\"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&amp;k=14&amp;r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Ffree-online-courses&amp;bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&amp;bvt=rss\" Toner)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/The%2060%20Best%20Free%20Online%20Courses%20For%20Whatever%20You%20Want%20to%20Learn-2.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn44@2020_4/2020/10/27/16-53-45-172_f314df80808968fb.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/The%2060%20Best%20Free%20Online%20Courses%20For%20Whatever%20You%20Want%20to%20Learn-6.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn73@2020_3/2020/10/27/16-53-56-552_8fab64b0d521efe4.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/The%2060%20Best%20Free%20Online%20Courses%20For%20Whatever%20You%20Want%20to%20Learn-5.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn66@2020_1/2020/10/27/16-53-54-999_e6904bd5ca2c04a6.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/The%2060%20Best%20Free%20Online%20Courses%20For%20Whatever%20You%20Want%20to%20Learn-4.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn5@2020_1/2020/10/27/16-53-52-833_44de8a308995afbf.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Screen%20Shot%202019-05-08%20at%2012.30.10%20PM.png?width=1512&name=Screen%20Shot%202019-05-08%20at%2012.30.10%20PM.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn87@2020_3/2020/10/27/16-53-51-163_3e9fe2ddb2d8d355.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/The%2060%20Best%20Free%20Online%20Courses%20For%20Whatever%20You%20Want%20to%20Learn-3.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn25@2020_1/2020/10/27/16-54-05-339_b59322bbab9be936.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Screen%20Shot%202019-05-08%20at%2011.59.35%20AM.png?width=1492&name=Screen%20Shot%202019-05-08%20at%2011.59.35%20AM.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn81@2020_4/2020/10/27/16-53-57-120_17a7c56326ad4c0a.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/The%2060%20Best%20Free%20Online%20Courses%20For%20Whatever%20You%20Want%20to%20Learn.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn68@2020_3/2020/10/27/16-54-08-835_55e6b9a4773958b4.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/The%2060%20Best%20Free%20Online%20Courses%20For%20Whatever%20You%20Want%20to%20Learn-1.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn81@2020_1/2020/10/27/16-54-00-762_308c738183367b89.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Screen%20Shot%202019-05-08%20at%2012.31.18%20PM.png?width=1492&name=Screen%20Shot%202019-05-08%20at%2012.31.18%20PM.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn74@2020_5/2020/10/27/16-54-00-417_d87ba7915264687a.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Ffree-online-courses&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn27@2020_6/2020/10/27/16-53-48-696_1c39e073922adbac.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1603817624925},{"createdTime":"2020-10-28 00:53:44","updatedTime":"2020-10-28 00:53:44","title":"16 of the Best Shopify Stores to Inspire Your Own","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/best-shopify-stores","description":"<p>Ecommerce is <a href=\"https://www.digitalcommerce360.com/2017/08/09/e-commerce-grow-17-us-retail-sales-2022/\">predicted</a> to account for 17% of all U.S. retail sales by 2022. As ecommerce grows, so does competition, making it hard to differentiate your website from everyone else's.</p> \n<p>It isn't enough to have a one-of-a-kind product: to attract your ideal audience — and more importantly, to turn that audience into passionate brand ambassadors — you need a one-of-a-kind website.</p> \n<p>A sleek and captivating Shopify website can attract a large audience and even act as your start-to-finish marketing pitch.</p> \n<p>But you need to know what makes one Shopify website better than the rest. Here, we've curated a list of 16 best of the best <a href=\"https://www.websitetooltester.com/en/reviews/shopify/\">Shopify</a> stores to inspire your own.</p> \n<p>Whether you're new to ecommerce and about to design your first website, or an ecommerce veteran considering a redesign to outshine your competitors in 2018, this list offers plenty of creative ideas.</p> \n<p></p> \n<div class=\"hsg-featured-snippet\"> \n <h2>Top Shopify Stores</h2> \n <ol> \n  <li>UgMonk</li> \n  <li>Pipcorn</li> \n  <li>Taylor Stitch</li> \n  <li>Happiness Abscissa</li> \n  <li>Skinny Teatox</li> \n  <li>HELM Boots</li> \n  <li>BioLite</li> \n  <li>Pop Chart Lab</li> \n  <li>Luca and Danni</li> \n  <li>Harris Farm Markets</li> \n  <li>So Worth Loving</li> \n  <li>Great George Watches</li> \n  <li>Choose Muse</li> \n  <li>Brilliant</li> \n  <li>Holstee</li> \n  <li>Kylie Cosmetics</li> \n </ol> \n</div> \n<h3>1. <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/company-news/-hubspot-becomes-one-of-the-first-marketing-software-companies-to-integrate-with-linkedin-company-pages\">UgMonk</a></h3> \n<p>Jeff Sheldon starts the \"About\" section on his UgMonk website with a simple question: \"Why was it so difficult to find fresh, high-quality, unique items in a modern aesthetic?\" His Shopify site is simple and fresh, and exhibits UgMonk's clothing, workplace items, bags, and prints in the same modern aesthetic style he sought while designing his unique products.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/ugmonk.png\" alt=\"UgMonk Shopify store\"></p> \n<h3>2. <a href=\"https://www.pipsnacks.com/\">Pipcorn</a></h3> \n<p>When you think about popcorn, I'm betting the first concern that comes to mind isn't \"is it healthy?\" Pipcorn knows this, so their homepage features a simple slogan: \"Most tender, crunchy, delicious popcorn … and it won't destroy your teeth like the ‘generic' stuff.\"&nbsp;<span style=\"font-size: 1.1rem;\">The best websites know their target audience's primary concerns (in this case, the taste of popcorn and the kernels in teeth), and sell them on those solutions upfront. </span></p> \n<p><span style=\"font-size: 1.1rem;\">If you look on their \"About Us\" page, you'll find Pipcorn's products are also non-GMO, vegan, gluten free, and whole grain. Even though this could have easily been incorporated into their slogan, they chose to exclude it in favor of tackling our bigger concern: </span><em style=\"color: inherit; font-size: 1.1rem;\">Does it taste good?</em></p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/pipcorn.png\" alt=\"Pipcorn Shopify store\"></p> \n<h3>3. <a href=\"https://www.taylorstitch.com/\">Taylor Stitch</a></h3> \n<p>The inner child in me loves Taylor Stitch's website because of the creative alternatives displayed when you hover over a product: a jacket, for instance, flips to an image of a model posing with the jacket on a motorcycle.</p> \n<p>The Taylor Stitch website does something else really cool, too: it almost immediately calls more attention to its message than its products, with \"Three Simple Ingredients\" written across most of the images you see on the homepage. Taylor Stitch doesn't just make high-quality clothing. It also aims to reduce waste and help the environment by creating clothing with recycled or 100% natural products.</p> \n<p>On their website, you can't miss their environmental efforts, and I'm betting this is a differentiating factor for most buyers when they come across the site.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/taylor%20stitch.png\" alt=\"Taylor Stitch Shopify store\"></p> \n<h3>4. <a href=\"https://www.happinessabscissa.com/\">Happiness Abscissa</a></h3> \n<p>Many of the websites I mention on this list have clean, straight lines. Happiness Abscissa is unique. It shows a playful side by displaying a layout with bright abstract images, and even products hanging from different angles.</p> \n<p>The company's logo, a crooked \"Ha,\" draws in the viewer's attention, and then they use Ha in a sentence without defining the word, further stimulating viewers' curiosity. You get the sense they don't take themselves too seriously, affording the viewer a cheerful and fun experience.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/happinessabscissa.png\" alt=\"Happiness Abscissa Shopify store\"></p> \n<h3>5. <a href=\"https://skinny-teatox.com/\">Skinny Teatox</a></h3> \n<p>I myself was tempted to purchase the Teatox product when I checked out this site (in my defense, they were having a one-day flash sale I did not want to miss). The Skinny Teatox homepage immediately confronts your biggest concerns (\"Is it natural? Yes. Will it work? Yes.\"), and uses pastel colors and cute icons of bikinis and mugs to convey a fresh vibe.</p> \n<p>As I've noticed with a few other Shopify websites, Skinny Teatox places its products on the homepage with an easy \"buy now\" call-to-action. For a company that isn't too complex to figure out (\"All Natural Detox Weight Loss Tea\" is written beside the company name in search engines), I think it makes sense to offer the viewers what they want upfront.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/skinnyteatox.png\" alt=\"Skinny Teatox Shopify store\"></p> \n<h3>6. <a href=\"https://helmboots.com/\">HELM Boots</a></h3> \n<p>\"Our boots give men confidence from the ground up, confidence to take steps they've never taken before.\" Immediately, HELM incentivizes viewers through emotion: <em>I might just be a guy looking to buy some boots, but yes, I'd definitely also like some confidence and bravery while I'm at it.</em> The website looks elegant, and you can find everything from the homepage, which is designed to convert viewers at various stages of the buyer's journey and assuage doubts as you scroll.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/helm-1.png\" alt=\"HELM Boots Shopify store\"></p> \n<h3>7. <a href=\"https://www.bioliteenergy.com/\">BioLite</a></h3> \n<p>I might be a sucker for the little details, but the product images on BioLite's website are enough to make me want to buy something (they look 3-D and illuminated, and some even look wet from rain!).</p> \n<p>Since BioLite's major selling point is its humanitarian impact (the products bring affordable energy access to places in India and Africa), the first thing on the homepage is their slogan, \"Gear That Brings Energy Everywhere,\" which will appeal to their target audience.&nbsp;<span style=\"font-size: 1.1rem;\">The navigation bar at the top also has a clever twist: beside each product title, there are little black-and-white cartoon drawings of the product.</span></p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/biolite.png\" alt=\"BioLite Shopify store\"></p> \n<h3>8. <a href=\"https://www.popchartlab.com/\">Pop Chart Lab </a></h3> \n<p>This site looks like one of the vintage and trendy prints they sell. It's also organized in different categories depending on a viewer's browsing preference.</p> \n<p>First, Pop Chart Lab's Shopify store has a scroll-down navigation with sub-categories ranging from, \"NYC\" to \"Kids\" to \"Hip Hop\" to \"Wine.\" They also have a carousel with some of their top prints on display. Below the carousel, they offer \"wholesale,\" \"gift guides,\" and \"scratch-off\" collections, for viewers who are having a difficult time discerning what they want. The shop manages to appear simple, despite its vast array of different print products, which is no easy feat.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/popchart.png\" alt=\"Pop Chart Lab Shopify store with Marvel superhero promotion\"></p> \n<h3>9. <a href=\"https://lucadanni.com/?gclid=EAIaIQobChMIlJL7gvuU2gIVhLrACh2YXw8VEAAYASAAEgI7wPD_BwE\">Luca and Danni </a></h3> \n<p>There's something addictive about an ecommerce store that changes as you scroll. Luca and Danni's page is highly interactive: as you scroll, some images get bigger and others get smaller, boxes of bracelets open up within images, and some images follow you down the page. It can be tricky to offer so much movement on a page while remaining coherent, but somehow, Luca and Danni accomplish this. There's also a very zen vibe to the whole layout, with images of palm trees and cactuses, and calls-to-action with language like \"brighter days: shop soil to sky,\" and \"find what speaks to you.\"</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/lucadanni.png\" alt=\"Luca and Danni Shopify store\"></p> \n<h3>10.<a href=\"https://www.harrisfarm.com.au/\"> Harris Farm Markets</a></h3> \n<p>This is a family-owned company, something you can't miss from the homepage. It's casual and playful, with text that looks like a child's handwriting and colorful drawings of fruit (there's even an adorable drawing of a bee with animated wings!). Even the calls-to-action sound laid-back, like \"What's nature been up to?\" It's so genuine, you can imagine a family building the site together.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/harrisfarms.png\" alt=\"Harris Farm Markets Shopify store\"></p> \n<h3>11. <a href=\"https://shop.soworthloving.com/\">So Worth Loving </a></h3> \n<p>Sometimes, being evasive pays off. While it's not always a good idea to hide your products from the viewer, it can be a very smart move if your product doesn't make sense without understanding the backstory. With So Worth Loving's site, you don't even see the t-shirts for sale until a third of the way down the page. By that point, you've already read their slogan, a little bio from the founder, Eryn, and a full narrative about how the site began.</p> \n<p>The site leans into personal touches, with handwritten-looking quotes scrawled across images and very normal looking images of people posing in t-shirts. This is a great example of knowing your audience enough to break the rules.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/soworthloving.png\" alt=\"So Worth Loving Shopify store\"></p> \n<h3>12. <a href=\"https://www.greatgeorgewatches.com/\">Great George Watches</a></h3> \n<p>I'm not an experienced watch shopper, so when I first read, \"Made with Swiss parts and 100% square,\" on Great George Watches' homepage, I thought maybe \"square\" was a fancy term I'd understand if I knew watches. But as I scrolled and read, \"Think outside the circle,\" I realized these terms were unique to Great George Watches, which are all square-faced.</p> \n<p>By emphasizing what makes their product unique before even showing the produce, Great George Watches captivates the viewer. I love this shop because it has a refined and polished look, with black-and-white photos and an attention-grabbing red call-to-action button.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/george.png\" alt=\"Great George Watches Shopify store\"></p> \n<h3>13. <a href=\"http://www.choosemuse.com/\">Choose Muse </a></h3> \n<p>Choose Muse incorporates a full-display video of a man putting headphones on and using Choose Muse's product right from the homepage. The video starts playing immediately (as opposed to offering a play button option), which is especially eye-catching. I usually think <em>simple is better</em> when it comes to design, but Choose Muse proves me wrong, incorporating compelling designs with a ton of images and text, while still retaining a clean and enjoyable viewer experience.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/choosemuse.png\" alt=\"Choose Muse Shopify store\"></p> \n<h3>14. <a href=\"https://brilliant.org/\">Brilliant</a></h3> \n<p>For a math and science website, Brilliant is surprisingly easy-to-navigate (even for someone like me, an English major … ), with big, colorful block buttons to choose the math concept you want to learn. This shop is also a fantastic example of using a call-to-action button wisely: there's a big \"sign up for free\" button prominently displayed in the top right, and then another at the bottom of the page, after you've scrolled past the information you need.</p> \n<p>The site doesn't have a navigation bar, but instead uses the web page to answer all the questions a viewer might have.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/brilliant.png\" alt=\"Brilliant Shopify store\"></p> \n<h3>15. <a href=\"https://www.holstee.com/\">Holstee</a></h3> \n<p>Holstee does a fantastic job of designing their site in tiers depending on a person's initial level of interest in the product. For starters, you see the text, \"We help you along your journey to live more fully and mindfully.\" If you're already convinced, you can click \"Join today\" right below the text. If not, you can continue to scroll down the homepage to find pain points this product reduces, read a \"Holstee Manifesto,\" see Membership benefits, check out testimonials, and find publications Holstee's been featured in.</p> \n<p>Throughout the page, there are various calls-to-action, like \"Choose a plan that's right for you,\" and then, at the end, \"Become a member today.\" I love this site because it becomes increasingly convincing and in-depth as you scroll: it's clear they use their homepage as a start-to-finish marketing pitch.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/holstee.png\" alt=\"Holstee Shopify store\"></p> \n<h3>16. <a href=\"https://www.kyliecosmetics.com/\">Kylie Cosmetics </a></h3> \n<p>As one of the top <a href=\"http://www.businessinsider.com/instagram-top-10-people-2017-2017-11\">10 most followed accounts on Instagram</a>, Kylie Jenner's Cosmetic brand is one of the bigger brands using Shopify today. Her site has a very distinct girly-girl vibe, with a bubble-gum pink background showing off her lip kits and gloss.</p> \n<p>Kylie's site is also well-organized for her audience: the lip kits, her best-known items, are shown first on the homepage, with \"top sellers\" below that. I didn't feel overwhelmed looking through the various cosmetic products like I thought I would, and what really stood out to me about Kylie's site is the fun, colorful layout. It might not be everyone's cup of tea, but I'm betting it appeals to her target audience.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/kylie.png\" alt=\"Kylie Cosmetics Shopify store\"></p> \n<p>See a store design above that you like? First, grab the guide below to find out how user-generated content can give your business the gusto it needs to attract and retain online shoppers.</p> \n<p><em>Editor's note: This post was originally published in October 2018 and has been updated for comprehensiveness.</em></p> \n<p></p> \n<p></p>  \n<img src=\"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&amp;k=14&amp;r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fbest-shopify-stores&amp;bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&amp;bvt=rss\" alt=\"\" width=\"1\" height=\"1\" style=\"min-height:1px!important;width:1px!important;border-width:0!important;margin-top:0!important;margin-bottom:0!important;margin-right:0!important;margin-left:0!important;padding-top:0!important;padding-bottom:0!important;padding-right:0!important;padding-left:0!important; \">","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Mon, 19 Oct 2020 11:00:00 +0000","feedId":54,"bgimg":"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/ugmonk.png","linkMd5":"84cbc550eb4009536cbdc7a429305807","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx14/cdn55@2020_1/2020/10/27/16-53-45-279_e0086256a9a11dd9.webp","destWidth":1000,"destHeight":742,"sourceBytes":277894,"destBytes":277894,"author":"Caroline Forsey","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/ugmonk.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx14/cdn55@2020_1/2020/10/27/16-53-45-279_e0086256a9a11dd9.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/pipcorn.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn25@2020_6/2020/10/27/16-54-01-712_04049475147e44f2.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/taylor%20stitch.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn21@2020_3/2020/10/27/16-53-56-030_db86a4b17ead9c17.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/happinessabscissa.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn89@2020_3/2020/10/27/16-53-53-714_eaa493e80a3cfddf.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/skinnyteatox.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn24@2020_2/2020/10/27/16-54-12-264_52f8d1dda0ea982a.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/helm-1.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn23@2020_5/2020/10/27/16-53-51-591_ba16a7b21dd972e6.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/biolite.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn3@2020_6/2020/10/27/16-53-49-238_5e1e5af66d5fc579.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/popchart.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx33/cdn71@2020_5/2020/10/27/16-53-50-136_18a1328445f13119.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/lucadanni.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn33@2020_3/2020/10/27/16-54-05-461_0ab8e98291f61100.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/harrisfarms.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx33/cdn33@2020_6/2020/10/27/16-54-11-157_102a70686e0e84b9.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/soworthloving.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn77@2020_5/2020/10/27/16-53-58-774_e982dafb845b2c2a.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/george.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn9@2020_2/2020/10/27/16-54-03-299_ef9f31fa0ffa7451.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/choosemuse.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn53@2020_3/2020/10/27/16-54-00-585_07b93312d7447676.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/brilliant.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn53@2020_2/2020/10/27/16-54-13-740_3c4105d428a8b148.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/holstee.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn71@2020_3/2020/10/27/16-54-08-780_95b76d76c9be29df.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/kylie.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn57@2020_6/2020/10/27/16-54-02-349_2cd18e0c94445094.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fbest-shopify-stores&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn57@2020_6/2020/10/27/16-54-13-735_009d3158c43ea1fd.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1603817624919},{"createdTime":"2020-10-28 00:53:44","updatedTime":"2020-10-28 00:53:44","title":"How to Insert Google Calendar, Apple Calendar & Outlook Event Invites Into Your Marketing Emails","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/calendar-invites-ical-outlook-google","description":"<p>Have you ever registered for a webinar and then totally forgotten about it? Or perhaps you got an email about an upcoming workshop, but you were busy and forgot to put a reminder in your calendar for it? Yep, I'm guessing that's happened even to the most type-A of us.</p> \n<p>Well, if you're an email marketer, you've been on the other side of this, when half of the registrants for an event you promoted never showed up. It sucks.</p> \n<p>Luckily for you, you don't have to worry about that anymore, because we're about to share a marketing hack with you: how to insert Outlook, Apple Calendar, and Google Calendar invites right into your email in a few easy steps. That way, registrants can add the event directly to their calendars, and then be much less likely to forget about your event.</p> \n<h3 style=\"text-align: center;\"><a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/products/sales/schedule-meeting?hubs_campaign=freemiumacquisition&amp;hubs_content=blog.hubspot.com/marketing/calendar-invites-ical-outlook-google&amp;hubs_cta=blog.hubspot.com/marketing/calendar-invites-ical-outlook-google-text\">Get instant access to our free meeting scheduling software. No more wasting time with back and forth emails or setting up calendar invites.</a></h3> \n<p>Unless you somehow magically know what type of calendar your target audience uses, your best bet is to include all three major calendar invites in your email, giving recipients a choice that works for them. Outlook and Apple Calendar users will get an .ics file and Google Calendar users will use a URL-based custom invitation.</p> \n<p><strong>Note:</strong> All screenshots and steps were taken on a Mac, but if you're on a PC, the process is similar.</p> \n<h2><strong>Step 1: Create a New Event</strong></h2> \n<p>If you have a Mac, you can create your invitation in Apple Calendar. If you have a PC, you can create it in Outlook. For Google Calendar, you'll create the URL directly from your calendar application (you'll need to be logged into your Google account to do this) -- it doesn't matter which type of computer you have.</p> \n<h3><strong>Apple Calendar</strong></h3> \n<p>Open <a href=\"https://www.icloud.com/calendar/\">Apple Calendar</a> and click on the \"+\" sign in the bottom right corner of the window. A pop-up will appear. Enter the name of your event in the \"New Event\" text box and hit return/enter on your keyboard. This will create an event on your calendar, but it will place the event on the current date and time and leave the rest of the details blank. You'll need to change this information to reflect the details of your event (more on that in the next section).</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/apple%20calendar.jpg?width=2872&amp;name=apple%20calendar.jpg\" alt=\"the apple calendar homepage with an arrow to the new event button in bottom right corner\" width=\"2872\" style=\"width: 2872px;\"></p> \n<h3><strong>Outlook</strong></h3> \n<p>Open up <a href=\"https://outlook.live.com/calendar/0/view/month\">Outlook Calendar</a>, then click on the \"New Event\" icon in the top left corner. An event pop-up will open for editing — simply include the title of the event, time and date, location, and whether or not you want to set a reminder. To find the option to \"Invite attendees\", click \"More options\".&nbsp;</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/outlook%20calendar.jpg?width=2766&amp;name=outlook%20calendar.jpg\" alt=\"outlook calendar homepage with arrow pointing to new event button\" width=\"2766\" style=\"width: 2766px;\"></p> \n<h3><strong>Google Calendar</strong></h3> \n<p><a href=\"http://www.google.com/calendar/\">Open Google Calendar</a> in a new browser window. You'll need to be logged into your Google account. Click the \"Create\" button on the top left side of the screen. A new event window should open.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/google%20chrome.jpg?width=2444&amp;name=google%20chrome.jpg\" alt=\"google calendar homepage with arrow pointing to create button\" width=\"2444\" style=\"width: 2444px;\"></p> \n<h2><strong>Step 2: Set Details for Your Event</strong></h2> \n<p>While Outlook, Apple Calendar, and Google Calendar events have slightly different formats, you'll still need the same components for each one:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>Event name</li> \n <li>Location</li> \n <li>Time</li> \n <li>Event description</li> \n <li>URL of your event's landing page</li> \n <li>Optional event alert</li> \n</ul> \n<p>Below are examples of how these details look in the different applications, as well as a clarification of what information and format to use for each of these components.</p> \n<h3 style=\"text-align: left;\"><strong>Apple Calendar</strong></h3> \n<p><strong><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/apple%20calendar%20event.png?width=420&amp;name=apple%20calendar%20event.png\" alt=\"apple calendar event\" width=\"420\" style=\"width: 420px; display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\"><br></strong></p> \n<h3 style=\"text-align: left;\"><strong>Outlook</strong></h3> \n<p><strong><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/outlook%20calendar.png?width=1062&amp;name=outlook%20calendar.png\" alt=\"outlook calendar event\" width=\"1062\" style=\"width: 1062px;\"></strong></p> \n<h3 style=\"text-align: left;\"><strong>Google Calendar</strong></h3> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/hubspot%20calendar.png?width=1190&amp;name=hubspot%20calendar.png\" alt=\"google calendar event\" width=\"1190\" style=\"width: 1190px;\"></p> \n<h3><strong>The Details You Need to Include</strong></h3> \n<h4><strong>Event Name&nbsp;</strong></h4> \n<p>Make sure the name reflects what your actual event name is called on your website and in your other promotions (this is a no-brainer, but we're being thorough here). You may want to also include your company name at the end so registrants can quickly remember who is hosting the event when they stumble on it in their calendar later<strong>.</strong></p> \n<h4><strong>Location</strong></h4> \n<p>Physical address of the event (one line, such as \"123 Business Ave, Springfield, TX\") or the landing page URL, in the case of an online event.</p> \n<h4><strong>Time</strong></h4> \n<p>Enter the start and end dates and times of the actual event. Adjust the timing of the event to <strong>your time zone</strong>, as you're the one creating the .ics file. It will automatically change the time to correspond with each person's time zone. For example, if you're creating the event file in Boston for a webinar in San Francisco that starts at 10 a.m. PST, you should enter the start time as 1 p.m. EST.</p> \n<h4><strong>Alert (Optional)</strong></h4> \n<p>You can set up alerts so attendees don't forget about the event between when you sent the invite and the time of the event. In Outlook, you can set a time for one reminder to go off (such as one hour before). In Apple Calendar and Google Calendar you can set multiple alerts.</p> \n<p>It's important to not overwhelm people with too many alerts, as this creates a negative, intrusive experience. Below is an example of an alert sequence in Apple Calendar that reminds folks about your event but isn't in-your-face:</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/hubspot%20alerts%20on%20calendar.png?width=882&amp;name=hubspot%20alerts%20on%20calendar.png\" alt=\"hubspot alerts on calendar\" width=\"882\" style=\"width: 882px;\"></p> \n<h4><strong>URL of Event Landing Page</strong></h4> \n<p>Do you have a specific landing page for your event or webinar? Include its URL, as it acts as a refresher for those who may be fuzzy on the details of what the event is about. Include it in the URL section of an Apple Calendar invite as well as in the body text of your Gmail or Outlook invites if you haven't already included it in the Location section.</p> \n<h4><strong>Description</strong></h4> \n<p>Here, you should include a snippet of the event's details. This goes in the \"note\" section of your Apple Calendar invite, in the body of your Outlook invite, or in the \"description\" text box in Google Calendar.</p> \n<p>It's also helpful to provide your contact info in this section. That way, people can reach out if they have any questions.</p> \n<h2><strong>Step 3: Save and Send Your Event</strong></h2> \n<p>Once you're all set editing the invite, you can save it to use as an attachment in your marketing email.</p> \n<h3><strong>Outlook</strong></h3> \n<p>Click on your event in Outlook, select \"Edit\", and then click \"More options\". Once you see the pop-up (shown below), type the emails of people you'd like to invite into the text bar \"Invite attendees\". When you're ready, click \"Send\" in the top left of the screen to send the invite to people in your recipient list.&nbsp;</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/outlook%20save%20and%20send.png?width=1426&amp;name=outlook%20save%20and%20send.png\" alt=\"outlook save and send\" width=\"1426\" style=\"width: 1426px;\"></p> \n<h3><strong>Apple Calendar</strong></h3> \n<p>Double click on your Apple event to open it up, and then type emails into the \"Invitees\" text box. When you're ready, click \"OK\", and the invite will automatically be sent to the emails you've included in the event details.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/apple%20save%20and%20send.png?width=740&amp;name=apple%20save%20and%20send.png\" alt=\"apple save and send\" width=\"740\" style=\"width: 740px;\"></p> \n<h3><strong>Google Calendar</strong></h3> \n<p>Click on your event in your Google calendar and click \"Edit event\". Then type emails into the \"Add guests\" text box to the right of your event details (next to \"Rooms\"). When you're ready, select \"Save\". If you've done it correctly, Google Calendar will show you a pop-up confirming you'd like to send the event to guests. Click \"Send\" to ensure it gets sent to the emails you've included.&nbsp;</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/gmail%20save%20and%20send.png?width=2058&amp;name=gmail%20save%20and%20send.png\" alt=\"gmail save and send\" width=\"2058\" style=\"width: 2058px;\"></p> \n<h2><strong>Step 4: Insert Invites Into Your Marketing Email</strong></h2> \n<p style=\"text-align: left;\">The easiest way to send an event via email for Outlook, Apple, and Gmail is to do it directly from the event invite itself. Each of these email providers give you the opportunity to type emails directly into the event, and include additional text, attachments, etc.</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: left;\">Best of all, the invite you'll receive is clean and offers you the opportunity to accept or deny the invite directly from your email inbox:&nbsp;</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: left;\"><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/invite-Oct-26-2020-03-44-36-08-PM.png?width=998&amp;name=invite-Oct-26-2020-03-44-36-08-PM.png\" alt=\"invite-Oct-26-2020-03-44-36-08-PM\" width=\"998\" style=\"width: 998px;\">However, there are a few workarounds you can try if you'd prefer to include the event URL in a marketing email.&nbsp;</p> \n<h3 style=\"text-align: left;\">Gmail Calendar</h3> \n<p style=\"text-align: left;\">For Gmail calendar, click \"Edit\" to open the event in a new window, and then select the \"More actions\" dropdown. From there, click \"Publish event\":&nbsp;</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: left;\"><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Screen%20Shot%202020-10-26%20at%2011.27.57%20AM.png?width=2284&amp;name=Screen%20Shot%202020-10-26%20at%2011.27.57%20AM.png\" alt=\"Screen Shot 2020-10-26 at 11.27.57 AM\" width=\"2284\" style=\"width: 2284px;\"></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: left;\">In the pop-up screen, you'll see an HTML code or a link to the event. Simply click \"Copy\" beside the link to copy the link, and then open the email you intend to send and paste the URL.</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: left;\"><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Screen%20Shot%202020-10-26%20at%2011.28.07%20AM.png?width=1178&amp;name=Screen%20Shot%202020-10-26%20at%2011.28.07%20AM.png\" alt=\"Screen Shot 2020-10-26 at 11.28.07 AM\" width=\"1178\" style=\"width: 1178px;\"></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: left;\">You'll want to ensure, however, that each email recipient has been included on the event invite list, as well.&nbsp;</p> \n<h3 style=\"text-align: left;\">Apple Calendar</h3> \n<p style=\"text-align: left;\">If you're using Apple Calendar, alternatively, you'll need to get a little more creative. To workaround the option of sending the event to a recipient directly from the event details, simply send the event&nbsp;<em>only&nbsp;</em>to your own email. When you open the invite, you'll see a .ics link attached to the email:</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: left;\"><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Screen%20Shot%202020-10-26%20at%2011.50.16%20AM.png?width=476&amp;height=98&amp;name=Screen%20Shot%202020-10-26%20at%2011.50.16%20AM.png\" alt=\"Screen Shot 2020-10-26 at 11.50.16 AM\" width=\"476\" height=\"98\" style=\"width: 476px; display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\"></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: left;\">Simply download the .ics attachment, and then drag-and-drop that calendar event into an email to send it to recipients.&nbsp;</p> \n<h3 style=\"text-align: left;\">Outlook Calendar</h3> \n<p style=\"text-align: left;\">Finally, if you're using Outlook, you'll need to open your inbox and select \"New Items\" &gt; \"Meeting\":</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Screen%20Shot%202020-10-26%20at%2012.15.22%20PM.png?width=524&amp;name=Screen%20Shot%202020-10-26%20at%2012.15.22%20PM.png\" alt=\"Screen Shot 2020-10-26 at 12.15.22 PM\" width=\"524\" style=\"width: 524px; display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\"><span style=\"font-size: 11px; font-style: italic;\"><a href=\"https://support.microsoft.com/en-us/office/schedule-a-meeting-with-other-people-5c9877bc-ab91-4a7c-99fb-b0b68d7ea94f\">Image Source</a></span></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: left;\">Click \"New Meeting\", and finally, select \"Reply with Meeting\" from within an email itself:&nbsp;</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Screen%20Shot%202020-10-26%20at%2012.13.48%20PM.png?width=492&amp;name=Screen%20Shot%202020-10-26%20at%2012.13.48%20PM.png\" alt=\"Screen Shot 2020-10-26 at 12.13.48 PM\" width=\"492\" style=\"width: 492px; display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\"><span style=\"font-size: 11px; font-style: italic;\"><a href=\"https://support.microsoft.com/en-us/office/schedule-a-meeting-with-other-people-5c9877bc-ab91-4a7c-99fb-b0b68d7ea94f\">Image Source</a></span></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: left;\">And that's it! You're all set. Use these tips to send marketing events to leads, prospects, and customers alike. Take a look at <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/event-marketing\">The Ultimate Guide to Event Marketing</a> to learn more about the types of events you might consider creating to engage and delight potential customers.&nbsp;</p> \n<p><em>Editor's Note: This post was originally published in June 2014 and has been updated for freshness, accuracy, and comprehensiveness.</em></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><em></em></p>  \n<div>\n <a class=\"close\">&nbsp;</a> \n <p>&nbsp;</p> \n</div>   \n<img \">","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Mon, 19 Oct 2020 11:00:00 +0000","feedId":54,"bgimg":"","linkMd5":"4f5637c79c90c4464f1d4bedd42e1f5b","bgimgJsdelivr":"","metaImg":"","author":"nshah@hubspot.com (Niti Shah)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/apple%20calendar.jpg?width=2872&name=apple%20calendar.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx23/cdn74@2020_4/2020/10/27/16-54-03-200_5f0f4ab6a51b29bf.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/outlook%20calendar.jpg?width=2766&name=outlook%20calendar.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn55@2020_6/2020/10/27/16-54-07-176_adf5e9394b781752.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/google%20chrome.jpg?width=2444&name=google%20chrome.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn87@2020_3/2020/10/27/16-54-10-533_2ef12d8b788e6d56.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/apple%20calendar%20event.png?width=420&name=apple%20calendar%20event.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn88@2020_4/2020/10/27/16-54-14-218_30b78b22f39e434f.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/outlook%20calendar.png?width=1062&name=outlook%20calendar.png":null,"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/hubspot%20calendar.png?width=1190&name=hubspot%20calendar.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn77@2020_4/2020/10/27/16-54-12-896_c895f2fa10bd3934.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/hubspot%20alerts%20on%20calendar.png?width=882&name=hubspot%20alerts%20on%20calendar.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn53@2020_5/2020/10/27/16-54-12-567_cf6f6b22030a55ff.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/outlook%20save%20and%20send.png?width=1426&name=outlook%20save%20and%20send.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn15@2020_5/2020/10/27/16-54-12-196_e9dc44f0b6d7f0d9.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/apple%20save%20and%20send.png?width=740&name=apple%20save%20and%20send.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn93@2020_5/2020/10/27/16-54-04-595_8c094960bbd99b08.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/gmail%20save%20and%20send.png?width=2058&name=gmail%20save%20and%20send.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn7@2020_6/2020/10/27/16-53-51-427_b231b51019ff831f.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/invite-Oct-26-2020-03-44-36-08-PM.png?width=998&name=invite-Oct-26-2020-03-44-36-08-PM.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx33/cdn15@2020_6/2020/10/27/16-54-09-214_366501f8963ffc63.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Screen%20Shot%202020-10-26%20at%2011.27.57%20AM.png?width=2284&name=Screen%20Shot%202020-10-26%20at%2011.27.57%20AM.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn88@2020_3/2020/10/27/16-54-13-454_c33579483bd3de68.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Screen%20Shot%202020-10-26%20at%2011.28.07%20AM.png?width=1178&name=Screen%20Shot%202020-10-26%20at%2011.28.07%20AM.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn69@2020_2/2020/10/27/16-53-58-695_2ad575eb57310c2a.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Screen%20Shot%202020-10-26%20at%2011.50.16%20AM.png?width=476&height=98&name=Screen%20Shot%202020-10-26%20at%2011.50.16%20AM.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn20@2020_2/2020/10/27/16-54-07-807_fc81f4fa4d4d9d32.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Screen%20Shot%202020-10-26%20at%2012.15.22%20PM.png?width=524&name=Screen%20Shot%202020-10-26%20at%2012.15.22%20PM.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx14/cdn33@2020_2/2020/10/27/16-53-54-624_bec7f96f690f55cb.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Screen%20Shot%202020-10-26%20at%2012.13.48%20PM.png?width=492&name=Screen%20Shot%202020-10-26%20at%2012.13.48%20PM.png":null,"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fcalendar-invites-ical-outlook-google&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn99@2020_3/2020/10/27/16-53-54-258_b38a2d54cc5c2244.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1603817624905},{"createdTime":"2020-10-28 00:53:44","updatedTime":"2020-10-28 00:53:44","title":"The Ultimate Guide to Amazon Advertising","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/amazon-advertising","description":"<p>I'm willing to bet, whenever you have marketing strategy discussions with your team, you typically discuss the same three or four social platforms — Facebook? Check. Instagram? Check. Pinterest? Check.</p> \n<p>But — what about Amazon?</p> \n<p>In 2018, Amazon launched <a href=\"https://advertising.amazon.com/blog/amazon-advertising-simplified\" style=\"color: #0091ae;\"><span>\"Amazon Advertising\"</span></a>, (formerly Amazon Marketing Services, or AMS), as a search advertising solution for Amazon vendors. Similar to pay-per-click ads on Google, sellers only pay when shoppers click on ads.</p> \n<p>AMS is rapidly growing. In fact, Amazon's ad revenues are projected to amount to <a href=\"https://www.statista.com/statistics/259811/net-us-advertising-revenues-of-amazon/\"><span>12.75 billion in 2020</span></a>, with an impressive <a href=\"https://www.statista.com/statistics/259811/net-us-advertising-revenues-of-amazon/\"><span>23% growth since 2019</span></a>.&nbsp;</p> \n<p>If you're already not using <span>AMS</span>, your team should consider it. Amazon Advertising could become a core advertising platform for many businesses, as well as a good alternative to Google and Facebook.</p> \n<p></p> \n<p>To help you get started advertising on Amazon, we've created this ultimate guide that fleshes out each type of ad you can run on Amazon and some of their best practices. Read on to learn how to advertise on the ecommerce platform in 2020.</p> \n<p>Keep reading, or jump to a specific type of Amazon advertising:</p> \n<p><strong>1. <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/amazon-advertising#amazon-sponsored-ads\">Amazon Sponsored Ads</a></strong></p> \n<p><strong>2. <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/amazon-advertising#Amazon-Headline-Search-Ads\">Amazon Headline Search Ads</a></strong></p> \n<p><strong>3. <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/amazon-advertising#amazon-product-display-ads\">Amazon Product Display Ads</a></strong></p> \n<p><strong>4. <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/amazon-advertising#amazon-native-ads\">Amazon Native Ads</a></strong></p> \n<p><strong>5. <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/amazon-advertising#amazon-video-ads\">Amazon Video Ads</a></strong></p> \n<p><strong>6. <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/amazon-advertising#amazon-stores\">Amazon Stores</a></strong></p> \n<h2><strong>Amazon Advertising Strategy</strong></h2> \n<p>Even though we'll be describing five unique types of Amazon advertisements that all have different best practices, here are seven general tips for shaping a successful <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/amazon-marketing-strategy\">Amazon advertising strategy</a>:</p> \n<h3><strong>1. Determine your goals.</strong></h3> \n<p>Whether you want to drive more sales or boost brand awareness, Amazon allows you to align your targets with your goals. For instance, you can deem your <a href=\"https://sellercentral.amazon.com/gp/help/external/201528520\"><span>Advertising Cost of Sales</span></a> (ACoS) as your metric of success if you're focusing on driving more sales.</p> \n<p>Alternatively, you can deem impressions as your metric of success if you're focusing on boosting brand awareness.</p> \n<p>Fortunately, Amazon divides its product page up into \"Objectives\" if it's easiest for you to figure out which Amazon ad product works best for you depending on your goals. For instance, video ads, display ads, audio ads, and custom advertising solutions are <a href=\"https://advertising.amazon.com/solutions/objectives/brand-advertising?ref_=a20m_us_hnav_obj_brd\"><span>recommended if your goal is to grow brand awareness</span></a>.&nbsp;</p> \n<p>By working backwards from your goals, you'll ensure the strategy you implement on Amazon is best-suited for your business needs.&nbsp;</p> \n<h3><strong>2. Choose the right products to advertise.</strong></h3> \n<p>Advertising your most popular products gives you the best chance to convert clicks into purchases. You should also make sure these products are in stock and priced competitively.&nbsp;</p> \n<p>Alternatively, perhaps you have a new product or service for which you'd like to increase awareness. When choosing the right products or services to advertise, you'll want to keep your goals in-mind, and also ensure you've done your research to determine <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/amazon-marketing-strategy\"><span>whether Amazon is the right platform</span></a> to showcase your products in the first place.&nbsp;</p> \n<h3><strong>3. Craft clear, concise, and compelling product detail pages.</strong></h3> \n<p>Amazon ads can entice shoppers to visit your product detail pages, but the product detail page is what will ultimately turn those shoppers into customers. To craft a persuasive product detail page, consider including accurate and descriptive titles, high-quality images, and relevant and useful product information.</p> \n<h3><strong>4. Choose where you want to place your ads.</strong></h3> \n<p>Amazon offers a variety of products within its full advertising suite — for instance, you can create voice ads to display across Alexa-enabled devices, video ads to stream across Fire TV or Amazon-exclusive sites like IMBD, or display ads to attract Amazon users to your brand.&nbsp;</p> \n<p>Once you've determined whether voice, video, or search is right for you, you'll want to investigate various options, including sponsored brand ads versus sponsored product ads (which we'll discuss in the next step).&nbsp;</p> \n<p>Keep in mind, there are tons of opportunities to place your ads on various devices or sites with Amazon, so consider getting creative. Perhaps an audio advertisement that plays on Alexa-enabed devices is best-suited for your business, or maybe you'll find the highest ROI with Amazon DSP, which allows you to reach Amazon audiences on both Amazon-owned and third-party sites and apps.</p> \n<h3><strong>5. Test out sponsored brands versus sponsored products.</strong></h3> \n<p>To explore the differences between sponsored brands versus sponsored products, let's consider the following example.</p> \n<p>When I search <a href=\"https://www.amazon.com/s?k=baby+food&amp;ref=nb_sb_noss_2\"><span>\"baby food\" on Amazon</span></a>, the first sponsored placement I see is <a href=\"https://www.gerber.com/about/\"><span>Gerber's</span></a> sponsored brand post, which highlights a few different Gerber products to increase brand awareness and drive sales:&nbsp;</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/gerber%20sponsored%20brand%20on%20amazon.png?width=1752&amp;name=gerber%20sponsored%20brand%20on%20amazon.png\" alt=\"gerber sponsored brand on amazon\" width=\"1752\" style=\"width: 1752px;\" /></p> \n<p>However, consider what happens when I click on an individual Gerber baby food product. In the bottom right of the product screen right below the \"Buy Now\" button, I see a <a href=\"https://www.happyfamilyorganics.com/tot/\"><span>Happy Family Organics</span></a> advertisement for an individual product — Stage 4 Fiber &amp; Protein baby food pouches:</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/happy%20tot%20sponsored%20product%20on%20amazon.png?width=444&amp;name=happy%20tot%20sponsored%20product%20on%20amazon.png\" alt=\"happy tot sponsored product on amazon\" width=\"444\" style=\"width: 444px; display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\" /></p> \n<p>This is the difference between a sponsored brand versus a sponsored product post. Simply put, a <a href=\"https://advertising.amazon.com/solutions/products/sponsored-brands\"><span>sponsored brand</span></a> post can display a few of your products or services, and is ultimately best-suited for companies aiming to increase brand awareness around an entire product line.&nbsp;</p> \n<p>Alternatively, a <a href=\"https://advertising.amazon.com/solutions/products/sponsored-products\"><span>sponsored product</span></a> post is a cost-per-click (CPC) ad that promotes individual product listings on Amazon. If you're hoping to drive sales to a specific product or you'd like to target a niche audience (for instance, anyone who's already clicked on a competitor's product), this might be the better option for you.</p> \n<h3><strong>6. Use category-specific targeting.&nbsp;</strong></h3> \n<p>Amazon offers <a href=\"https://advertising.amazon.com/blog/new-bidding-and-targeting-options-for-sponsored-products\"><span>advanced targeting functionality</span></a> to help you display your products alongside top-rated products, or even alongside tangentially-related products — for instance, if you sell K-cups for a keurig, you might serve your ad to Amazon users who've searched for \"keurig\".&nbsp;</p> \n<p>By using Product Attribute Targeting, you're able to show ads to shoppers who've shown interest in other products within your industry. This advanced targeting capability helps you maximize effectiveness of your ads. Plus, it allows you to increase brand recognition with a high-intent audience.&nbsp;</p> \n<p>For instance, when I search for basketballs on Amazon and click on a Wilson product, I can scroll down and see a section labelled \"Sponsored products related to this item\":&nbsp;</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/sponsored%20products%20related%20to%20basketball%20on%20amazon.png?width=2332&amp;name=sponsored%20products%20related%20to%20basketball%20on%20amazon.png\" alt=\"sponsored products related to basketball on amazon\" width=\"2332\" style=\"width: 2332px;\" /></p> \n<p>Avid basketball players are likely more inclined to take a look at knee braces or sports cones, making this an effective ad placement. Even if shoppers arent' in the&nbsp;</p> \n<p>even if I'm not in the market right now, I'll ideally keep these brands in-mind for the future.&nbsp;</p> \n<h3><strong>7. Take advantage of negative keywords to reduce wasted spend.&nbsp;</strong></h3> \n<p>It's important you avoid wasting ad spend by including negative keywords — or which keywords you <em>don't </em>want to appear for — to avoid serving your ad to people who won't convert.&nbsp;</p> \n<p>Consider, for instance, the difference between a search for \"granola bars\" and a search for \"KIND granola bars\". You don't want to appear in a search for \"KIND granola bars\", when the user is clearly determined to find a specific granola brand.</p> \n<p>For this reason, you might want to include brands like \"KIND\" or \"Chewy\" in your negative keywords list, so your ad can be served to users with a more general interest in perusing various granola brand products.&nbsp;</p> \n<p>You'll also want to include negative keywords if they don't relate to your product to avoid wasting your ad spend towards people who aren't interested in your product. For instance, if your product isn't gluten-free, you'll want \"gluten free\" on your negative keywords list.&nbsp;</p> \n<p>Additionally, you might consider getting more specific to target your ads at a smaller, more high-intent group of people. Rather than simply targeting \"granola bar\", you might try targeting \"low-sugar granola bar\", for instance.</p> \n<a></a> \n<h2><strong>Amazon Sponsored Ads</strong></h2> \n<p>Amazon Sponsored Product Ads are pay-per-click, keyword-targeted display ads for individual products that appear on the search results and product detail pages. With <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/amazon-sponsored-product-ads\">Sponsored Product Ads,</a> there are three types of keywords you can bid on if you decide to leverage manual targeting — broad, phrase, and exact.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/sponsored%20sock%20product%20on%20amazon.png?width=2008&amp;name=sponsored%20sock%20product%20on%20amazon.png\" alt=\"sponsored sock product on amazon\" width=\"2008\" style=\"width: 2008px;\" /></p> \n<p>Broad keywords can include words before and after the target keyword, like \"white hand mixers\", if you sell hand mixers. Targeting these keywords will expose your ads to the greatest amount of traffic.</p> \n<p><strong>Phrase keywords</strong> focus on how the sequence of the words you use changes the context of a query. For example, \"stainless steel hand mixer\" indicates you sell hand mixers. But \"hand stainless steel mixer\" indicates you sell stainless steel mixers, but not necessarily stainless steel hand mixers.</p> \n<p><strong>Exact keywords</strong> are the most constraining type of targeted keyword — a shopper's search query must contain the exact keyword for your ad to show up and no words can come before or after the keyword. For example, if you choose to target exact keywords, you can target an ad for \"hand mixer\", but it won't show up for the query \"electric hand mixer\".</p> \n<p>Using Sponsored Product Ads, you can also use automatic keyword targeting, which leverages an algorithm to target the most relevant keywords for your product ads.</p> \n<p>To gauge the performance of your ads, Sponsored Product Ads offers a reporting tool that displays your ads' clicks, spend, sales, and advertising cost of sales (ACoS).</p> \n<h3>Amazon Sponsored Ads Best Practices</h3> \n<h4>Targeting</h4> \n<p>With Amazon Sponsored Product Ads, you can find keywords that have low conversion rates and flag them as negative. This way, Amazon will stop showing your ad to shoppers who search for those queries. Ensuring you flag certain keywords as negative is critical — even if these keywords have a high click-through-rate, their low conversion rate means they're probably not reaching the right type of shoppers.</p> \n<h4>Bidding</h4> \n<p>Available in Manual Targeting ad campaigns, you can leverage Bid+ to boost the odds of your ad appearing at the top of search results. You can only use Bid+ on ads that are eligible to appear at the top of search results, but when you do, you can increase your default bid by up to 50%, keeping your top performing campaigns competitive, without having to constantly adjust your bids manually.</p> \n<a></a> \n<h2><strong>Amazon Headline Search Ads (a.k.a. Sponsored Brand Campaigns)</strong></h2> \n<img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/pasted%20image%200%20(1)-12.png\" title=\"\" width=\"100%\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\" alt=\"example of amazon headline search ad of crossbody bag\"> <p style=\"text-align: center; font-size: 11px;\"><em><a href=\"https://advertising.amazon.com/blog/sponsored-brands-6-tips\">Image Source</a></em></p> <p>Currently known as Sponsored Brand Campaigns, this type of Amazon advertising allows you to promote keyword-targeted ads of multiple products above, below, and alongside search results.</p> <p>Using Sponsored Brand Campaigns, you can target three types of keywords -- branded product keywords, complementary product keywords, and sponsored products automatic targeting keywords.</p> <p><strong>Branded product keywords</strong> are a combination of your brand name and a product you sell.</p> <p><strong>Complimentary product keywords</strong> are a bundle of two individual products that influence the demand for each other and can be sold together (like ketchup and mustard).</p> <p><strong>Sponsored products automatic targeting keywords</strong> are search queries that you've already experienced success with while running automatic targeted sponsored product campaigns.</p> <p>Sponsored Brand Campaigns also lets you feature up to three unique products in your ads, customize your ads' image, headline, and landing page, and even tests these elements.</p> <p>Below is an image from Amazon that details the keywords that you can use for your sponsored brand campaigns:</p> <p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/amazon-keywords.png?width=582&amp;name=amazon-keywords.png\" alt=\"Amazon details the various types of keywords.\" width=\"582\" style=\"width: 582px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\" /></p> <p style=\"text-align: center; font-size: 11px;\"><em><a href=\"https://advertising.amazon.com\">Image Source</a></em></p> <p>To determine how much you pay for Sponsored Brand Campaigns, Amazon uses a pay-per-click, auction-based pricing model, so you'll never pay more than you bid per click. In addition to manual bidding, you can choose automated bidding, which will optimize your ads for conversion.</p> <p>If you want to know how well your advertisements are performing, Sponsored Brand Campaigns offers a reporting feature that displays your ads' clicks, spend, sales, estimated win rate for keywords, and ACoS (Advertising Cost of Sales).</p> <p>Below, <a href=\"https://www.shirtinvaders.com/\">Shirt Invaders</a> promotes three of their T-shirts. Clicking on each of the shirts goes specifically to the product page. However, clicking on the \"Shop Now\" button below the copy takes you to its Amazon Store:</p> <p style=\"text-align: center; font-size: 11px;\"><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/headline-search-ads-amazon.jpg?width=600&amp;name=headline-search-ads-amazon.jpg\" width=\"600\" style=\"width: 600px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\" alt=\"Shirt Invaders Amazon headline search ads above the search results.\"><em><a href=\"https://www.amazon.com/\">Image Source</a></em></img></p> <h3>Sponsored Brand Campaigns&nbsp;Best Practices</h3> <h4>Ad Creative</h4> <p>It's a good idea to feature three top-performing products in your Sponsored Brands Campaign to increase the amount of clicks and sales your ads generate.</p> <p>Amazon also recommends including your product's top benefit in your ad's headline because mobile shoppers can only see the ad's main image and headline.</p> <p>Additionally, when describing your product, try not to claim your product is \"#1\" or a \"Best Seller\" -- your ad won't get approved.</p> <h4>Testing</h4> <p>To run the most accurate and fruitful tests, consider only changing one variable at a time, run them for at least two weeks, and anchor the success of your tests to business goals.</p> <h4>Landing Page Design</h4> <p>With Sponsored Brands, you can direct shoppers to your Amazon store or a customized product page. Consider testing how different product pages convert visitors into customers, as well as the order in which your products appear.</p> <a></a> <h2><strong>Amazon Product Display Ads</strong></h2> <p style=\"text-align: center;\"><strong><em><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/amazon-Product-Display-Ads.webp\" alt=\"amazon-Product-Display-Ads\" style=\"display: none !important;\" /></em></strong></p> <p>Product display ads are pay-per-click ads that appear on product detail pages, customer review pages, on top of the offer listing page, and below search results.&nbsp;</p> <p>You can also place these ads on abandoned cart emails, follow-up emails, and recommendations emails. Their main objective is to cross-sell or upsell your customers.</p> <p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/sponsored%20products%20related%20to%20razors%20on%20amazon.png?width=2396&amp;name=sponsored%20products%20related%20to%20razors%20on%20amazon.png\" alt=\"sponsored products related to razors on amazon\" width=\"2396\" style=\"width: 2396px;\" /></p> <p>Using product display ads, you can use two types of campaign targeting: product and interest. <strong>Product targeting</strong> is a contextual form of targeting, so you can target specific products and related categories. <strong>Interest targeting</strong> is a behavioral form of targeting, so you can target shopper interest and reach a larger audience.</p> <p>Product display ads also let you choose which in-category detail pages you want to advertise on, customize your creative, and offers a reporting tool that displays your campaigns' clicks, spend, sales, advertising cost of sales (ACoS), detail page views, spend, units sold, total sales, and average cost-per-click (ACPC).</p> <h3>Amazon Product Display Ads Best Practices</h3> <h4>Targeting</h4> <p>Use product targeting on competitor pages, complementary product detail pages, and your own product detail pages to cross-sell and upsell similar products. Using product targeting on related categories also extends your reach to sections of Amazon's catalogue that are related to your products.</p> <h4>Ad Creative</h4> <p>When crafting your headlines, Amazon allows you to include phrases like \"Exclusive\", \"New\", \"Buy Now\", and \"Save Now\", but making claims like \"#1\" or \"Beat Seller\" will get your ad rejected.</p> <a></a> <h2><strong>Amazon Native Ads</strong></h2> <p>Amazon Native Ads are ads that you can place on your brand's own website. There are three types of native ads: recommendation ads, search ads, and custom ads.</p> <p><strong>Recommendation ads</strong> are ads you can place in product article pages on your website. These ads are dynamic, so Amazon will populate your most relevant product recommendation based on your web page's content and visitors.</p> <p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Screen%20Shot%202020-10-13%20at%202.28.30%20PM.png?width=778&amp;name=Screen%20Shot%202020-10-13%20at%202.28.30%20PM.png\" alt=\"Screen Shot 2020-10-13 at 2.28.30 PM\" width=\"778\" style=\"width: 778px;\"><span style=\"font-size: 11px; font-style: italic;\"><a href=\"https://affiliate-program.amazon.com/home/ads/ref=amb_link_9BrQiYIcOTC6v2zRDxnBQA_1?pf_rd_p=39487255-fae5-4cf5-8219-4e0f53516f8d\">Image Source</a></span></img></p> <p><strong>Search ads</strong> are ads that populate on your website based off keywords that your customers search for on Amazon or on your website.</p> \n <div> \n  <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/pasted%20image%200%20(3)-8.png?width=600&amp;name=pasted%20image%200%20(3)-8.png\" alt=\"Search ads on Amazon.\" width=\"600\" style=\"width: 600px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\"> </img>\n </div> <p style=\"text-align: center; font-size: 11px;\"><em><a href=\"https://affiliate-program.amazon.com/home/ads/ref=amb_link_9BrQiYIcOTC6v2zRDxnBQA_1?pf_rd_p=39487255-fae5-4cf5-8219-4e0f53516f8d\">Image Source</a></em></p> <p><strong>Custom ads</strong> allow you to select your own assortment of products you'd like to promote and place them on your product article posts.</p> <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/pasted%20image%200-27.png\" title=\"\" width=\"100%\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\" alt=\"Custom ads on Amazon feature men's running shoes.\"> <p style=\"text-align: center; font-size: 11px;\"><em><a href=\"https://affiliate-program.amazon.com/home/ads/ref=amb_link_9BrQiYIcOTC6v2zRDxnBQA_1?pf_rd_p=39487255-fae5-4cf5-8219-4e0f53516f8d\">Image Source</a></em></p> <h3>Amazon Native Ads Best Practice</h3> <p>Just like a call-to-action on a blog post, make sure your native shopping ads are extremely relevant to the pages you place them on. This way, when your website visitors finish reading your post, the ads are a natural next step and can lead to more conversions.</p> <a></a> <h2><strong>Amazon Video Ads</strong></h2> <p>Amazon Video Ads are ads that you can place on Amazon-owned sites like Amazon.com and IMDb, Amazon devices like Fire TV, and various properties across the web. You can buy Amazon video ads regardless of whether you sell products on Amazon or not, and you can set your ad's landing page as an Amazon product page, your own website, or any other web page on the internet.</p> <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/pasted%20image%200%20(4)-7.png\" title=\"\" width=\"100%\" style=\"display: block; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;\" alt=\"example of peloton video ad on amazon\"> <p style=\"text-align: center; font-size: 11px;\"><em><a href=\"https://advertising.amazon.com/products/video-ads\">Image Source</a></em></p> <p>If you want to work with Amazon's video ad consultants, you can sign up for their managed-service option, but to be eligible, you usually need to spend a minimum of $35,000 on video ads.</p> <a></a> <h2><strong>Amazon Stores</strong></h2> <p>Users can promote their brand or product on your own multi-page <a href=\"https://advertising.amazon.com/products/stores?ref=a20m_blog_fs_drivetrffcstore_052819\">Amazon Store</a>. Using Amazon's templates or drag-and-drop tiles, you can showcase your brand's products or portfolio of work.</p> <p>With Amazon Stores, brands get an Amazon URL and can view traffic analytics, which enables them to keep track of sales, traffic sources, and ad campaigns.</p> <p>Additionally, creating an Amazon Store is free.</p> <h3>Amazon Stores Best Practices</h3> <p>Once you create an Amazon Store, you can use the analytics tool to find the top performing keywords which have converted to sales. Additionally, the analytics tool will let you know which products sell.</p> <p>This lets you know which products you might want to consider for a paid ad campaign. Plus, it also shows what potential buyers are interested in.</p> <p>Below is an example of an Amazon Store:</p> <p style=\"text-align: center; font-size: 11px;\"><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/amazon-stores.jpg?width=600&amp;name=amazon-stores.jpg\" width=\"600\" style=\"width: 600px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\" alt=\"Kitchen Smart Amazon Store featuring their best products.\"><a href=\"https://advertising.amazon.com/products/stores?ref=a20m_blog_fs_drivetrffcstore_052819\"></a></img></p> <p style=\"text-align: center; font-size: 11px;\"><em><a href=\"https://advertising.amazon.com/products/stores?ref=a20m_blog_fs_drivetrffcstore_052819\">Image Source</a></em></p> <p>When you create an Amazon Store, the best practices are similar to best practices of any landing page — use clear photos, easy-to-read captions, and clear pricing. Additionally, make sure you showcase your highest performing products. Or you could opt to introduce new products on your Store as well.</p> <p>Before you craft your Store, come up with the products you want to feature on your navigation. Then, list all your products that you will showcase on those pages. Lastly, gather the clear, professional photos of your product, write your captions, and list your prices.</p> <p>Ultimately, <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/how-to-sell-on-amazon\">selling on Amazon</a> can be an impactful marketing strategy for ecommerce brands. As consumers continue to lean into online shopping, Amazon advertising can play a large role in your online sales.</p> <p><em>Editor's note: This post was originally published in February 2019 and has been updated for comprehensiveness.</em></p> <p></p> <p></p> <img
