8&name=youtube_googletrends_2.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn49@2020_2/2020/10/27/16-54-02-089_c84efc4afe673c26.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/youtube_history.png?width=730&height=183&name=youtube_history.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn42@2020_4/2020/10/27/16-53-56-283_0bc7572730f2bc3e.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/youtube_library.png?width=320&name=youtube_library.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn39@2020_6/2020/10/27/16-54-14-891_000de026c94ceb6b.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/youtube_history_mobile.png?width=320&name=youtube_history_mobile.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx14/cdn57@2020_6/2020/10/27/16-53-58-534_e47fd564275028e9.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/youtube_features_clear_watch_history.png?width=555&height=232&name=youtube_features_clear_watch_history.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn91@2020_6/2020/10/27/16-54-13-177_f15c044a944057d4.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/youtube_delete_history_mobile.png?width=320&name=youtube_delete_history_mobile.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn89@2020_3/2020/10/27/16-54-06-397_051fb31194b86daa.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fyoutube-features-hacks-tricks&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn25@2020_5/2020/10/27/16-54-10-922_07f95c7a5a3b798a.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1603817624901},{"createdTime":"2020-10-28 00:53:44","updatedTime":"2020-10-28 00:53:44","title":"The 9 Best Cover Letter Examples: What They Got Right","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/best-cover-letter-examples","description":"<p>Let’s face it: A job search is, typically, anything but fun.</p> \n<p>It’s almost as if it carries its own five stages of grief. At first, there’s denial of its demoralizing nature. Then comes the anger over either radio silence or rejection from prospective employers. Of course, there’s bargaining -- “I promise to never complain about work again, if I can find a new job!”</p>  \n<p>That’s often followed by depression, and the idea that one is simply just unhireable. Then, there’s acceptance: “This is awful, but I have to keep trying, anyway.”</p> \n<p></p> \n<p>But we have good news. It <em>is</em> possible to have a little fun with your job search -- and maybe even make yourself a better candidate in the process. The magic, it turns out, could be in your cover letter.</p> \n<p></p> \n<p>It may be true that only <a href=\"https://www.jobvite.com/jobvite-news-and-reports/2017-job-seeker-nation-survey-finding-fault-lines-american-workforce/\">26% of recruiters have deemed cover letters important</a>, but that doesn't mean yours has to contribute to that statistic. In fact, it might be that cover letters are deemed insignificant because so few of them stand out. Here's an opportunity for you to exercise your creativity at the earliest stage of the recruitment process.</p> \n<p>Personalization, after all, goes beyond replacing the title and company name in each letter you send to recruiters.</p> \n<p>What does that look like in practice, and how can you make your cover letter stand out? We found six examples from job seekers who decided to do things a bit differently.</p> \n<p></p> \n<p><em>Note: Some of these cover letters contain real company names and NSFW language that we've covered up.</em></p> \n<h2>Best Cover Letter Examples</h2> \n<h3>1. The Cover Letter That Explains 'Why,' Not Just 'How'</h3> \n<p>We’ve already covered the importance of addressing <i>how</i> you’ll best execute a certain role in your cover letter. But there’s another question you might want to answer: Why the heck do you want to work here?</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://www.themuse.com/advice/31-attentiongrabbing-cover-letter-examples\">The Muse</a>, a career guidance site, says that it’s often best to lead with the why -- especially if it makes a good story. We advise against blathering on and on, but a brief tale that illuminates your desire to work for that particular employer can really make you stand out.</p> \n<img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Why%20Example.png?width=524&amp;name=Why%20Example.png\" alt=\"Why Example.png\" width=\"524\" title=\"Why Example.png\" style=\"width: 524px;\">\n<span style=\"font-size: 13px;\">Source: <a href=\"https://www.themuse.com/advice/31-attentiongrabbing-cover-letter-examples\">The Muse</a></span> \n<p>Here’s another instance of the power of personalization. The author of this cover letter clearly has a passion for this prospective employer -- the Chicago Cubs -- and if she’s lying about it, well, that probably would eventually be revealed in an interview.</p> \n<p>Make sure your story is nonfiction, and relatable according to each job. While we love a good tale of childhood baseball games, an introduction like this one probably wouldn’t be fitting in a cover letter for, say, a software company. But a story of how the hours you spent playing with DOS games as a kid led to your passion for coding? Sure, we’d find that fitting.</p> \n<p>If you’re really passionate about a particular job opening, think about where that deep interest is rooted. Then, tell your hiring manager about it in a few sentences.</p> \n<h3>2. The 'We're Meant for Each Other' Cover Letter</h3> \n<p>This cover letter example is a special one because it was submitted to us here at HubSpot. What does the letter do well? It makes a connection with us before we've even met the letter's author.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/we're%20meant%20for%20each%20other%20cover%20letter%20example%20(1).png\" alt=\"We're meant for each other cover letter submitted to HubSpot\"></p> \n<p>\"Content Marketing Certified\" indicates the applicant has taken the content marketing certification course in our HubSpot Academy (you can <a href=\"https://academy.hubspot.com/content-marketing-training\">take the same course here</a>). Our \"records\" indicate he/she did indeed give an interview with us before -- <em>and</em> was a HubSpot customer.&nbsp;</p> \n<p>The cover letter sang references to a relationship we didn't even know we had with the candidate.</p> \n<p>The letter ends with a charming pitch for why, despite him/her not getting hired previously, our interests complement each other this time around.</p> \n<p>(Yes, the applicant was hired).&nbsp;</p> \n<h3>3. The Cover Letter with H.E.A.R.T.</h3> \n<p>HubSpot has a lot of H.E.A.R.T. -- Humble, Empathetic, Adaptable, Remarkable, Transparent. Our <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/blog/tabid/6307/bid/34234/the-hubspot-culture-code-creating-a-company-we-love.aspx?_ga=2.257739915.122841317.1562677793-527251855.1560789477\">Culture Code</a> is the foundation of the company's culture, the driving force behind our mission to <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/our-story?_ga=2.257739915.122841317.1562677793-527251855.1560789477\">help millions grow better</a>, and serves as the scaffolding for our hiring practices. Recruiters at HubSpot look for applicants that demonstrate how they embody the Culture Code and job description, paying extra attention to cover letters that are <i>super</i> custom to HubSpot.</p> \n<p>In another HubSpot submission, a HubSpot applicant writes about how she found out about HubSpot, why she likes the company, and how her professional experience aligns with H.E.A.R.T.</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Best-cover-letter-example.jpg?width=600&amp;name=Best-cover-letter-example.jpg\" alt=\"Best-cover-letter-example\" width=\"600\" style=\"width: 600px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\"></p> \n<p>HubSpot's recruiting team was impressed with her dedication to the company and how she went beyond what was asked for by link her portfolio in her closing paragraph.</p> \n<h2>Short Cover Letter Examples</h2> \n<h3>4. The Short-and-Sweet Cover Letter</h3> \n<p>In 2009, David Silverman penned an article for <i>Harvard Business Review</i> titled, “<a href=\"https://hbr.org/2009/06/the-best-cover-letter\">The Best Cover Letter I Ever Received.</a>” That letter contained three complete sentences, as follows:</p> \n<img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/short-and-sweet.png?width=680&amp;name=short-and-sweet.png\" alt=\"Short and sweet cover letter example\" width=\"680\" title=\"short-and-sweet.png\" style=\"width: 680px;\">\n<span style=\"font-size: 13px;\">Source: <a href=\"https://hbr.org/2009/06/the-best-cover-letter\">Harvard Business Review</a></span> \n<p>One might argue that this particular letter is less than outstanding. It’s brief, to say the least, and the author doesn’t go into a ton of detail about what makes him or her qualified for the job in question. But that’s what Silverman likes about it -- the fact that the applicant only included the pieces of information that would matter the most to the recipient.</p> \n<p>“The writer of this letter took the time to think through what would be relevant to me,” writes Silverman. “Instead of scattering lots of facts in hopes that one was relevant, the candidate offered up an opinion as to which experiences I should focus on.”</p> \n<p>When you apply for a job, start by determining two things:</p> \n<ol> \n <li style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Who might oversee the role -- that’s often included in the description, under “reports to.” Address your letter to that individual.</li> \n <li style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Figure out what problems this role is meant to solve for that person. Then, concisely phrase in your cover letter how and why your experience can and will resolve those problems.</li> \n</ol> \n<p>The key here is research -- by looking into who you’ll be reporting to and learning more about that person’s leadership style, you’ll be better prepared to tailor your cover letter to focus on how you provide solutions for her. Not sure how to learn more about a leader’s personality? Check out any content she shares on social media, or use <a href=\"https://growthbot.org/\">Growthbot’s</a> Personality Profile feature.</p> \n<p>Insert incredible compelling writing here</p> \n<h3>5. The Bare Bones Cover Letter</h3> \n<p>In today's job market, cover letters aren't always necessary. Even though many recruiters won't ask for or even read them, cover letters can still be effective and convey personality to a reader. Writing a strong cover letter can help you better convey your interest in the position and company.&nbsp;</p> \n<p>This template from <a href=\"https://www.thebalancecareers.com/best-cover-letters-a-z-list-of-examples-2060172\">The Balance Careers</a> puts together the essential components of a short cover letter: excitement about the position, your qualifications, and a call-to-action for the recruiter to follow up with you. Combining these central aspects in a well-written, compelling narrative will go a long way in convincing readers to hire you.</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/best%20short%20cover%20letter%20example.jpg?width=492&amp;name=best%20short%20cover%20letter%20example.jpg\" alt=\"best short cover letter example\" width=\"492\" style=\"width: 492px; display: block; margin: 0px auto;\"><span style=\"font-size: 13px;\">Source: <a href=\"https://www.thebalancecareers.com/best-cover-letters-a-z-list-of-examples-2060172\">The Balance Careers</a></span></p> \n<h2>Creative Cover Letter Examples</h2> \n<h3>6. The Brutally Honest Cover Letter</h3> \n<p>Then, there are the occasions when your future boss might appreciate honesty -- in its purest form. Livestream CEO Jesse Hertzberg, by his own admission, is one of those people, which might be why he called this example “<a href=\"http://titleneeded.com/blog/the-best-cover-letter\">the best cover letter</a>” (which he received while he was with Squarespace):</p> \n<img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/brutally%20honest%20cover%20letter%20example.png?width=562&amp;height=405&amp;name=brutally%20honest%20cover%20letter%20example.png\" width=\"562\" height=\"405\" style=\"width: 562px;\" alt=\"Brutally honest cover letter example\">\n<span style=\"font-size: 13px;\">Source: <a href=\"http://titleneeded.com/blog/the-best-cover-letter\">Title Needed</a></span> \n<p>As Hertzberg says in the blog post elaborating on this excerpt -- it’s not appropriate for every job or company. But if you happen to be sure that the corporate culture of this prospective employer gets a kick out of a complete lack of filter, then there’s a chance that the hiring manager might appreciate your candor.</p> \n<p>“Remember that I'm reading these all day long,” Hertzberg writes. “You need to quickly convince me I should keep reading. You need to stand out.”</p> \n<h3>7. The Straw (Wo)man Cover Letter</h3> \n<p>When I was in the throes of my own job search and reached one of the later stages, a friend said to me, “For the next job you apply for, you should just submit a picture of yourself a stick figure that somehow represents you working there.”</p> \n<p>Et voilà:</p> \n<img class=\"alignCenter shadow\" src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/AZWstrawCoverLetter.jpg?width=432&amp;name=AZWstrawCoverLetter.jpg\" alt=\"Funny illustration cover letter by Amanda Zantal-Wiener\" width=\"432\" title=\"AZWstrawCoverLetter.jpg\" style=\"width: 432px;\"> \n<p>I never did end up working for the recipient of this particular piece of art, but it did result in an interview. Again, be careful where you send a cover letter like this one -- if it doesn’t match the company’s culture, it might be interpreted as you not taking the opportunity seriously.</p> \n<p>Be sure to pair it with a little bit of explanatory text, too. For example, when I submitted this picture-as-a-cover letter, I also wrote, “Perhaps I took the ‘sense of humor’ alluded to in your job description a bit too seriously.”</p> \n<h3>8. The Overconfident Cover Letter</h3> \n<p>I’ll admit that I considered leaving out this example. It’s rife with profanity, vanity, and arrogance. But maybe, in some settings, that’s the right way to do a cover letter.</p> \n<p>A few years ago, <a href=\"http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2011/05/23/epic-cover-letter_n_865569.html\"><i>Huffington Post</i></a> published this note as an example of how to “get noticed” and “get hired for your dream job”:</p> \n<img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/epic%20cover%20letter%20example.jpg?width=479&amp;height=647&amp;name=epic%20cover%20letter%20example.jpg\" width=\"479\" height=\"647\" style=\"width: 479px;\" alt=\"Overconfident cover letter example\">\n<span style=\"font-size: 13px;\">Source: <a href=\"http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2011/05/23/epic-cover-letter_n_865569.html\">Huffington Post</a></span> \n<p>Here’s the thing: if the Aviary cited in this letter is the same Aviary I researched upon discovering it, then, well, I’m not sure this tone was the best approach. I read the company’s blog and looked at the careers site, and neither one indicates that the culture encourages this -- or lowercasing proper nouns like \"Google,\" for which I personally cannot forgive the applicant ...</p> \n<p>However, <a href=\"https://techcrunch.com/2014/09/22/adobe-acquires-aviary/\">Aviary was acquired by Adobe in 2014</a>, and this letter was written in 2011. So while it’s possible that the brand was a bit more relaxed at that time, we wouldn’t suggest submitting a letter with that tone to the company today. That’s not to say it would go unappreciated elsewhere -- <a href=\"https://velocitypartners.com/blog/how-to-use-swear-words-in-your-content-marketing/\">Doug Kessler</a> frequently discusses the marketers and brands that value colorful language, for example.</p> \n<p>The point is, this example further illustrates the importance of research. Make sure you understand the culture of the company to which you’re applying before you send a completely unfiltered cover letter -- if you don’t, there’s a good chance it’ll completely miss the mark.</p> \n<h3>9. The Interactive Cover Letter</h3> \n<p>When designer Rachel McBee applied for a job with the Denver Broncos, she didn’t just write a personalized cover letter -- she designed an entire digital, interactive microsite:</p> \n<span style=\"font-size: 13px;\">Source: <a href=\"http://www.pondertart.com/broncos/\">Rachel McBee</a></span> \n<p>This cover letter -- if you can even call it that -- checks off all of the boxes we’ve discussed here in a remarkable way. It concisely addresses and organizes what many hiring managers hope to see in any cover letter: how her skills lend themselves to the role, why she wants the job, and how to contact her.</p> \n<p>She even includes a “traditional” body of text at the bottom, with a form that allows the reader to easily get in touch with her.</p> \n<h2>Take Cover</h2> \n<p>We’d like to add a sixth stage to the job search: experimentation.</p> \n<p>In today’s competitive landscape, it’s so easy to feel defeated, less-than-good-enough, or like giving up your job search. But don’t let the process become so monotonous. Have fun discovering the qualitative data we’ve discussed here -- then, have even more by getting creative with your cover letter composition.</p> \n<p>We certainly can’t guarantee that every prospective employer will respond positively -- or at all -- to even the most unique, compelling cover letter. But the one that’s right for you will. That’s why it’s important <i>not to copy these examples</i>. That defeats the purpose of personalization.</p> \n<p>So get creative. And, by the way -- <a href=\"https://www.hubspot.com/jobs\">we’re hiring</a>.</p> \n<p></p> \n<div>\n <a class=\"close\">&nbsp;</a>\n</div>  \n<img \">","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Thu, 22 Oct 2020 19:17:00 +0000","feedId":54,"bgimg":"","linkMd5":"8f8125049e2a4b3468819609fce2a3d0","bgimgJsdelivr":"","metaImg":"","author":"Amanda Zantal-Wiener","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Why%20Example.png?width=524&name=Why%20Example.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn90@2020_4/2020/10/27/16-53-59-893_fd565b67afa643c0.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/we're%20meant%20for%20each%20other%20cover%20letter%20example%20(1).png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn34@2020_4/2020/10/27/16-54-01-874_04ff5cbdf949c997.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Best-cover-letter-example.jpg?width=600&name=Best-cover-letter-example.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn8@2020_1/2020/10/27/16-53-49-275_3a6d7ba50abfe57b.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/short-and-sweet.png?width=680&name=short-and-sweet.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn45@2020_6/2020/10/27/16-54-12-591_4a5d532e1e26a8e7.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/best%20short%20cover%20letter%20example.jpg?width=492&name=best%20short%20cover%20letter%20example.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx23/cdn28@2020_6/2020/10/27/16-53-50-552_2ae1e38a1de29742.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/brutally%20honest%20cover%20letter%20example.png?width=562&height=405&name=brutally%20honest%20cover%20letter%20example.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn100@2020_2/2020/10/27/16-53-52-536_e3409e745526062a.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/AZWstrawCoverLetter.jpg?width=432&name=AZWstrawCoverLetter.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn62@2020_6/2020/10/27/16-54-04-031_ab9d8444aad84010.webp","https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/epic%20cover%20letter%20example.jpg?width=479&height=647&name=epic%20cover%20letter%20example.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn65@2020_3/2020/10/27/16-54-07-479_2bc227eb48d9f7f0.webp","https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&k=14&r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fbest-cover-letter-examples&bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&bvt=rss":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn85@2020_1/2020/10/27/16-53-58-887_7eb5429d663a4acc.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1603817624891},{"createdTime":"2020-10-28 00:53:44","updatedTime":"2020-10-28 00:53:44","title":"The 12 Best Graphic Design Portfolios We've Ever Seen, & How to Start Your Own","link":"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/graphic-design-portfolio","description":"<p>Whether you're a full-time graphic designer or simply someone who's interested in dabbling in design as a side project in her free time, it's critical you create a sleek graphic design portfolio to showcase your work to potential clients.</p> \n<p>A graphic design portfolio is typically the only element a client needs to see when choosing a graphic designer -- which means a portfolio is vital for proving your skill as a designer.</p> \n<p>Additionally, a graphic design portfolio, much like a resume, provides necessary contact information, and any case studies you care to include from past employers.</p> \n<blockquote> \n <p>Simply put, a graphic design portfolio can establish your legitimacy as a designer worth hiring.</p> \n</blockquote> \n<p>With all that said, you're probably thinking -- <em>gee, thanks, no pressure or anything. </em></p> \n<p>Fortunately, we've cultivated a list of 12 impressive graphic design portfolios, followed by instructions on how you can create your own. Keep reading to get all the tips you need to curate the perfect space to showcase your work.</p> \n<p></p> \n<div class=\"hsg-featured-snippet\"> \n <h2>Graphic design portfolio website examples</h2> \n <ol> \n  <li>Heather Shaw</li> \n  <li>MDZ Design</li> \n  <li>Nicolas Paries</li> \n  <li>Gleb Kuznetsov</li> \n  <li>Chris Tammar</li> \n  <li>Stefanie Brueckler</li> \n  <li>Mingfei Yang</li> \n  <li>Chip Kidd</li> \n  <li>Kate Moross</li> \n  <li>Brook Perryman</li> \n  <li>Tobias van Schneider</li> \n  <li>Ling K</li> \n </ol> \n</div> \n<p>1.<a href=\"http://heathershaw.com/\"> Heather Shaw</a></p> \n<div>\n <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/The%2012%20Best%20Graphic%20Design%20Portfolios%20Weve%20Ever%20Seen,%20%26%20How%20to%20Start%20Your%20Own-4.png\" alt=\"\">\n</div> \n<p>2. <a href=\"https://www.mdzdesign.com/projects\">MDZ Design</a>&nbsp;&nbsp;</p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Screen%20Shot%202019-03-14%20at%201.12.06%20PM.png?width=2716&amp;name=Screen%20Shot%202019-03-14%20at%201.12.06%20PM.png\" alt=\"Screen Shot 2019-03-14 at 1.12.06 PM\" width=\"2716\" style=\"width: 2716px;\"></p> \n<p>3. <a href=\"http://nicolasparies.com/\">Nicolas Paries</a></p> \n<p><img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hs-fs/hubfs/Screen%20Shot%202019-03-14%20at%201.15.20%20PM-1.png?width=2822&amp;name=Screen%20Shot%202019-03-14%20at%201.15.20%20PM-1.png\" alt=\"Screen Shot 2019-03-14 at 1.15.20 PM-1\" width=\"2822\" style=\"width: 2822px;\"></p> \n<p>4. <a href=\"https://dribbble.com/glebich\">Gleb Kuznetsov</a></p> \n<div>\n <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/The%2012%20Best%20Graphic%20Design%20Portfolios%20Weve%20Ever%20Seen,%20%26%20How%20to%20Start%20Your%20Own-7.png\" alt=\"\">\n</div> \n<p>5. <a href=\"https://www.christammar.com/\">Chris Tammar</a></p> \n<div>\n <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/The%2012%20Best%20Graphic%20Design%20Portfolios%20Weve%20Ever%20Seen,%20%26%20How%20to%20Start%20Your%20Own.png\" alt=\"\">\n</div> \n<p>6. <a href=\"http://stefaniebrueckler.com/#projects\">Stefanie Brueckler</a></p> \n<div>\n <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/The%2012%20Best%20Graphic%20Design%20Portfolios%20Weve%20Ever%20Seen,%20%26%20How%20to%20Start%20Your%20Own-2.png\" alt=\"\">\n</div> \n<p>7. <a href=\"https://www.1monkeyarmy.com/home\">Mingfei Yang</a></p> \n<div>\n <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/The%2012%20Best%20Graphic%20Design%20Portfolios%20Weve%20Ever%20Seen,%20%26%20How%20to%20Start%20Your%20Own-5.png\" alt=\"\">\n</div> \n<p>8. <a href=\"http://chipkidd.com/home/portfolio-3/\">Chip Kidd</a></p> \n<div>\n <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/The%2012%20Best%20Graphic%20Design%20Portfolios%20Weve%20Ever%20Seen,%20%26%20How%20to%20Start%20Your%20Own-6.png\" alt=\"\">\n</div> \n<p>9. <a href=\"https://www.katemoross.com/\">Kate Moross</a></p> \n<div>\n <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/The%2012%20Best%20Graphic%20Design%20Portfolios%20Weve%20Ever%20Seen,%20%26%20How%20to%20Start%20Your%20Own-9.png\" alt=\"\">\n</div> \n<p>10. <a href=\"https://brook-perryman.pixpa.com/\">Brook Perryman</a></p> \n<div>\n <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/The%2012%20Best%20Graphic%20Design%20Portfolios%20Weve%20Ever%20Seen,%20%26%20How%20to%20Start%20Your%20Own-3.png\" alt=\"\">\n</div> \n<p>11. <a href=\"https://www.vanschneider.com/\">Tobias van Schneider </a></p> \n<div>\n <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/The%2012%20Best%20Graphic%20Design%20Portfolios%20Weve%20Ever%20Seen,%20%26%20How%20to%20Start%20Your%20Own-8.png\" alt=\"\">\n</div> \n<p>12. <a href=\"https://www.hellolingk.com/\">Ling K</a></p> \n<div>\n <img src=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/hubfs/The%2012%20Best%20Graphic%20Design%20Portfolios%20Weve%20Ever%20Seen,%20%26%20How%20to%20Start%20Your%20Own-1.png\" alt=\"\">\n</div> \n<div class=\"hsg-featured-snippet\"> \n <h2>How to make a graphic design portfolio</h2> \n <ol> \n  <li>Curate your best work, and show a wide breadth of skill.</li> \n  <li>Choose the right platform to showcase your work.</li> \n  <li>Include a professional case study, or client recommendations.</li> \n  <li>Integrate your personality.</li> \n  <li>Describe the creative process.</li> \n  <li>Show non-client work, or side projects.</li> \n </ol> \n</div> \n<h3>1. Curate your best work, and show a wide breadth of skill.</h3> \n<p>Lindsay Burke, a HubSpot Product Designer, emphasizes the importance of quality over quantity when it comes to curating a graphic design portfolio. She says, \"I recommend selecting your strongest projects and making these the primary focus of your portfolio website.\"</p> \n<p>Ideally, your portfolio will feature your sharpest, most impressive 10-20 designs -- undoubtedly, someone pursuing your portfolio won't have the time to look at more, and if your first couple projects are impressive enough, they shouldn't need to. However, it's equally critical you show potential clients your versatility. If you've dabbled in logo design as well as video animation, it's good to include both kinds of projects in your portfolio.</p> \n<h3>2. Choose the right platform to showcase your work.</h3> \n<p>Investing in a quality website with a custom domain URL will pay-off in the long run by demonstrating your professionalism to potential clients. Having your own website helps you organize your portfolio to suit all your business needs -- for instance, perhaps you'll include 'Projects', 'About Me', and 'Contact Me' sections, so visitors can peruse your content and then contact you without ever leaving the site.</p> \n<p>Take a look at <a href=\"https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/website-builder\">7 of the Best Website Builders for 2019</a> if you need help choosing the best platform for your portfolio.</p> \n<h3>3. Include a professional case study, or client recommendations.</h3> \n<p>Lindsay Burke told me it's incredibly valuable to write out a case study to complement any website visuals -- \"Through a written case study, your site visitors can get a sense of your project's background, the problem you were aiming to solve through design, and the process you took to arrive at a final deliverable. A lot of time, effort and iteration goes into design solutions, and a written case study will help communicate your unique process.\"</p> \n<p>To cultivate a strong case study, consider including the background of the project, the problem, the process, your deliverable, and any next steps. In the process section of your case study, Burke suggests including research, experience mapping, persona development, wire-framing, sketching, usability testing, and iteration.</p> \n<p>For further inspiration, check out <a href=\"http://www.lindsayjoburke.com/#/school-lunch-application/\">one of the case studies</a> Lindsay Burke uses for her personal website.</p> \n<p>Additionally, it will impress future clients if you can include recommendations from prior employers, which allows you to demonstrate a level of professionalism.</p> \n<h3>4. Integrate your personality.</h3> \n<p>As the examples above indicate, each portfolio is drastically different depending on the artist's unique style. Someone checking out Tobias van Schneider's portfolio will expect something vastly different than someone looking at Ling K's site. Ensure your portfolio -- including layout, background, and website title -- reflect who <em>you </em>are as a designer.</p> \n<h3>5. Describe the creative process.</h3> \n<p>Each designer has a unique process when working with clients -- and the sooner a potential client can learn about your process, the better. It's important you include context, so visitors can get a sense for how you handle challenges, and how your designs solve real-world problems.</p> \n<p>Plus, including a description of your creative process can help a potential client determine whether you're capable of handling the scope of their project. For instance, they might be unsure of your ability to handle graphic designs for mobile until they read how you single-handedly brainstormed and created the designs for another client's mobile site. In this case, context is critical.</p> \n<h3>6. Show non-client work, or side projects.</h3> \n<p>Amanda Chong, a HubSpot Designer, says, \"side projects are a great way to demonstrate your will to take initiative and your ability to balance multiple things at once. They're also a great way to show some of the more experimental, creative ideas that you might not be able to show through your day-to-day work.\"</p> \n<p>If you're just starting out, it's acceptable to include side projects or non-client work so potential customers can get a sense for your ability and style. Consider incorporating school work, a logo you designed for your aunt's company, or an internal design you created for your current company -- ideally, your designs will negate any concerns potential clients have over your lack of career experience.</p> \n<div class=\"hsg-featured-snippet\"> \n <h2>Ideas for graphic design portfolio projects</h2> \n <ol> \n  <li>Reach out to local businesses or start-ups and ask if they need help with a marketing campaign or packaging materials.</li> \n  <li>Create content for your own personal brand, and ensure that your content is cohesive across all your personal marketing materials.</li> \n  <li>Implement a mock website redesign for a brand you love.</li> \n  <li>Put together a creative brief for a fake website, and create graphic design materials for the fictitious company.</li> \n  <li>Design a logo for a brand you love.</li> \n  <li>Create a stock theme for WordPress.</li> \n  <li>Participate in a design challenge.</li> \n </ol> \n</div> \n<h3>1. Reach out to local businesses or start-ups and ask if they need help with a marketing campaign or packaging materials.</h3> \n<p>One of the easiest ways to begin building your client base is by reaching out to non-profits or local businesses in your area. Consider implementing mock-ups or sketches in advance, so you can give these businesses a sense for your skill and vision. Perhaps you think a local restaurant needs a new menu logo, or want to help a gift shop with their online marketing materials. Ideally, in exchange for your services, these businesses will offer to leave a testimonial on your portfolio.</p> \n<h3>2. Create content for your own personal brand, and ensure that your content is cohesive across all your personal marketing materials.</h3> \n<p>Take the time to ensure your own marketing materials are cohesive and sleek. Create a unique design for your website, and implement that same design or logo across various materials, including your business card and resume. A client is more likely to work with you if they can see the type of high-quality work you're able to create for yourself.</p> \n<h3>3. Implement a mock website redesign for a brand you love.</h3> \n<p>If you're still waiting for the day LuLuLemon gives you a call to redesign their website, well … why wait? Consider creating a complete website redesign for a well-known brand to demonstrate your skills to future clients. This is a well-known strategy already implemented by plenty of designers -- just take a look at some of the impressive Behance mock-ups for designers like <a href=\"https://www.behance.net/gallery/57746935/Michael-Kors-Website-Redesign-concept\">Michael Kors</a>.</p> \n<p>Additionally, Amanda Chong told me, \"If you're creating mockups for established brands to use as part of your portfolio, it's important to pair this with a case study or description of the process that helped you arrive at your proposed design. Talk about what you think wasn't working with the existing design, some of the constraints that you think the designers were working with, and why you made the decisions that you did.\"</p> \n<p>Chong added, \"Mockups are great at showing your visual design skills, but don't necessarily demonstrate your ability to work in a real-world context, so you'll want to take the time to explain how you would have approached it in a true business setting.\"</p> \n<h3>4. Put together a creative brief for a fake website, and create graphic design materials for the fictitious company.</h3> \n<p>If your designs are impressive enough, potential clients won't necessarily care whether you created them for a fictitious company -- and, in fact, they could be impressed with your innovativeness and creativity. Consider demonstrating your skills by putting together a creative brief for a fake company, complete with wireframes and sketches. In due time, real companies will take notice.</p> \n<h3>5. Design a logo for a brand you love.</h3> \n<p>Stick to the type of content you enjoy designing. If you're particularly adept at creating logos, and are often inspired by the logos used by real brands, consider designing an alternative logo for a brand you like. Just take a look at some of these inspiring <a href=\"https://www.cultofmac.com/415115/uber-logo-design/\">potential Uber logos</a> -- while they ultimately weren't used by Uber, they're nonetheless good examples of the designers' skills.</p> \n<h3>6. Create a stock theme for WordPress.</h3> \n<p>WordPress, a popular content management system, allows users to develop stock themes for WP -- best of all, if your theme is approved, you can sell it as a premium theme for extra cash. Begin by studying WordPress's most popular themes, and considering how you can create an impressive alternative. Take a look at <a href=\"https://make.wordpress.org/themes/handbook/review/required/\">WordPress's Theme Review Requirements</a> to learn more.</p> \n<h3>7. Participate in a design challenge.</h3> \n<p>To get inspired, practice your skills, or interact with other designers in a community and build your portfolio at the same time, you might consider participating in a design challenge. Design challenges can also help you uncover skills you didn't know you had by forcing you to step outside your design comfort-zone. There are various daily, weekly, or monthly challenges which will send you prompts on things to design -- for instance, try checking out <a href=\"https://www.dailyui.co/\">Daily UI Design Challenge</a>.</p> \n<div class=\"hsg-featured-snippet\"> \n <h2>Graphic design portfolio tips</h2> \n <ol> \n  <li>Show your versatility.</li> \n  <li>Quality over quantity -- display your best work.</li> \n  <li>Include case studies.</li> \n  <li>Make it clean and easy-to-navigate.</li> \n  <li>Prominently display contact information.</li> \n  <li>Display your unique personality.</li> \n </ol> \n</div> \n<p><em>Editor's note: This post was originally published in March 2019 and has been updated for comprehensiveness.</em></p> \n<p></p> \n<p></p>  \n<img src=\"https://track.hubspot.com/__ptq.gif?a=53&amp;k=14&amp;r=https%3A%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fgraphic-design-portfolio&amp;bu=https%253A%252F%252Fblog.hubspot.com%252Fmarketing&amp;bvt=rss\" alt=\"\" width=\"1\" height=\"1\"
